games.name: Blue Prince
review: Daaaaamn this game is so good! This is another one of those rare information games where you have to understand stuff about the lore and how things work in order to progress. I read somewhere people call them 'Metroidbrainias' which I thoroughly enjoy. Although this game is actually a roguelike! You go through a explore this mansion by drafting new rooms as you go. Each room is full of secrets about what's actually going on and it makes you want to learn everything about the game.

At the time of writing this I found the 46th room and decided to call it a day because the scope of the game is terrifying. I had many amazing eureka moments throughout my playthrough but one of them was learning about a crazy chess puzzle, thanks to happening to have the device you need to light candles on me when I finally got the basement key and was able to go down the fountain to the special area at the back. When I saw that those notes I had made about chess pieces in different rooms were about to be used... wait I have to draft them ALL? On top of this, my mate Rodrigo revealed at this point that he had over 150 hours in the game. For my sanity and my safety, I have to say no to the chess puzzle. I'll probably just get another sanctum key anyway, and that puzzle where I have to learn about all the history in order to make those sigils, my GOD. I wrote like 20 pages of notes for this, and I would have needed a new book to solve that one.
Anyway shout-outs to this game. So many highlights. I loved the logic puzzles, Alzara, the Aquarium puzzle, the computer system, the excitement of going to a brand new room. So much to enjoy!
I highly recommend this puzzle game! Puzzle games are the best!

games.name: Deltarune: Chapter 4
review: I took a short break before this chapter which was good. I was motivated and hopped in and really loved it! The vibe this time round is entirely different - way darker and very beautiful. I love the music of this area's dark world, and the story got me really hooked on the lore. There were some amazing moments with the main character. I finished the chapter with a bunch of ideas about this prophecy, and felt the magic of Deltarune begin to take shape.

This game has 3 more chapters coming still. It's going to be the world's first decade-long game and I'm in for the ride. It's wild how Toby Fox operates only at the highest level. It's all class, it's all so fun to play and the music is always 10/10. Can't wait for more.

games.name: Donkey Kong Bananza
review: I love Donkey Kong Bananza! I'm so glad they went all-in on Donkey Kong. They totally smashed it! It's a game all about destruction and it's soooo fun to destroy things! The amount of chaos on the screen is just great. And it comes with all these cool movement options. When I figured out that you can jump forwards on a rock, stop doing that and bounce of the rock, and then roll forwards and punch in the air to go a bit further, I started to do that to get to all sorts of faraway places. It was so awesome! And there are bananas and fossils everywhere. It never gets boring finding them!

I was a little worried about the vibes of the levels when I first saw the game. It really didn't make sense that they were underground and there was so much sunlight, but that stuff straight up isn't important. You still get a bunch of fun, distinct levels to go through. Personal highlights are the ice layer with the gay zebras, the beach layer and the part where the lava falls down like rain.
And of the course THE ENDING! What a fun way to end the game! If you've played it, send me a message and we can enthuse about it!

I have one main gripe with it, which is one of the transformations you find in that place with the falling lava. I ended up choosing not to use it because it sucked the fun out of finding stuff a bit. But that's honestly a non-issue.

games.name: Deltarune: Chapter 3
review: After so many years it's time to play Deltarune again! The quality remains just as high as before, but maybe we've made it to chapter 3, its starting to become same-y? The music is still great, the new funny character is great, I like the artstyle of the TV stuff. There's a lot to enjoy! Toby Fox has a way with humour. The storyline with the throuple was a highlight for me. I look forward to looking for secrets in this game further down the line! ...or maybe just watching a youtube video about it later.

games.name: Super Mario Strikers
review: Well, I gave it a go on the Switch 2's Gamecube feature, but didn't vibe with it at all. Just not my kind of game. But I love Daisy in this game and it was cute to watch my friend Franz get so excited while playing it.

games.name: Mario Kart World
review: Incredible! They just went and made the best Mario Kart ever. Mario Kart 8 really perfected the formula so I was asking myself how they would top it. By making it open world and having you drive between tracks, it has completely changed the formula and breathed new life into the series. At first I was skeptical about only going around the tracks for one lap and spending two or more laps travelling to the next one, but actually that's what this game is all about: all the crazy shit they throw at you between the tracks. No longer can you get good at Mario Kart by just learning all the tracks because you'll never learn this entire world. Instead, you have to react to all the new twists and turns awaiting you in every race. It means this will be replayable for ages!

I really love the VS mode where you can select literally any stage and go from anywhere to anywhere. There are infinite possibilities! The other mode, Knockout tour, is also great, especially when playing online. However how come I can't make my own knockout tours out of my favourite tracks? That would be my one main wish for the game. Then I love the open world free roam mode! You can just explore all these cool places and it's absolutely covered in references to old Mario Kart games, which I love to soak up.

But the real crown jewel of this game is the SOUNDTRACK! Holy shit!!! Not only does this feature absolute banger music for the 30 or so official tracks they have (including awesome intro music as you approach the stage), but it also features of 200 tracks of remixes of old mario and mario kart songs!! Between tracks and especially in the free roam and even on the main menu, you can just hear all this music. It's amazing! We've got reimaginings and modernisations of old and forgotten tracks, favourites, and just well everything in between. The sheer volume is insane, and each one has been made with such love. Playing this game and just hearing something like the Mario Kart DS credits theme, or Bowser's Castle GBA, or many obscure tracks just sets me off. Playing this game with me is insufferable because I will stop the conversation to point out the name of the track and how much I love it.

Also, the characters! I love playing as Cheep Cheep, Snowman, Piranha Plant... I mean what an honour. I love it. I think this is gonna be a huge game on this system and I can't wait to keep playing it over the next decade!

games.name: Astrobot
review: Sure, this game is a game design paradise, full of great ideas, easy controls, satisfying everything... sure...

I just can't get enthusiastic about it. The premise is literally advertising the PS5. The vibe is that everything is a cute robot. Apart from that, there is nothing going on here! I feel like this game is missing the heart and the soul. It's like Mario Galaxy without the Nintendo magic. My friend Macs lent me this game but I'm giving it back without finishing it because it just feels like work.

games.name: Game of Life
review: Fab made this game! It's available on the Community page. I feel like the vibes of the game are great, and it's really good for zoning out and thinking about other stuff. I made the music for it, the first time I've ever done such a thing!

Gameplay-wise it has absolutely no progression, just a constant stream of enemies. The player has no choice but to keep firing at the enemies, easy when paying attention, but difficult when vibing with the music so hard that you get distracted. Maybe it's called Game of Life because the hardships just keep coming without end, just like in real life.

games.name: Star of Providence
review: This is a very intense tiny bullet hell game! Your little spaceship can navigate really well through all the bullets, but there are just so many bullets! I was a little disappointed to learn that this was a roguelike. These days roguelikes make me upset because I would get a really good run then feel like I could never reach those heights again. This game offers next to nothing in terms of 'roguelite' elements, i.e. things that will make future runs easier. Instead you just have to git gud. I kinda have gotten better, but the element of luck involved is kinda putting me off. I'm sticking with it because I want to know about the lore and what some of these secrets mean.

games.name: Gravity Circuit
review: I watched a youtube video that recommended this game and I figured why not give it a go, but I didn't realise it was a Mega Man clone. I really don't vibe with the selecting which boss to beat first thing. I just kept losing and it felt bad not to complete the levels. I didn't love the grapple hook thing.

games.name: Miitopia
review: The reason I played this game is because somebody left its physical cartridge at a Smash tournament and didn't pick it up. It's definitely not the kind of game I would willingly buy, although I do have an appreciation for the Wii-era Nintendo Mii vibe, and I did play Tomodachi Life back then on the DS.

This game is totally fucked up and I cannot recommend it in good conscious. It's a turn based RPG, although there is little to no strategy, and all the characters fight on their own, not really requiring your input. Playing this game you quickly realise it's not about gameplay, it's about the relationships between all the Miis you create. They all have little personalities and are very sassy with one another, early animal crossing style. I have it say, it's funny as fuck. I can really imagine this being hilarious if you take mushrooms. The sheer amount of nonsense is just insane.

I spent a ridiculous amount of time at the start of the game making a bunch of high quality Miis, and realised that there are so many NPCs in the game, and you can make Miis for them all. I just felt invested because these Miis were all so good, I couldn't just drop the game, even if there isn't really a game here. So I would progress, and every now and then, another one of my horrible creations would turn up and it would just be hilarious.

My main character is a drag queen called Stacy (pictured here) and what can I say I love her. She is a popstar, and is getting very close to deadly warrior Nikita (pictured next to her). I enjoy it when they fight together in battle because I've invested so much in their relationship. Recently they started fighting and I was genuinely upset about it. Luckily, the horse that you befriend some ways into the game broke up the fight.

I thought I gave up on the game but somehow I keep coming back. It's really good for when you're in a call with friends and you want to chat and not be distracted, since the game is just pressing A over and over.

games.name: Kuru Kuru Kururin
review: Jack and I played this on the Switch online on a whim having smoked a bunch of weed and it was fucking great. You play as a tiny alien that drives a constantly rotating spaceship flying through tight gaps. You have to time your passage through all these tight spots and obstacles so that your rotating arms doesn't hit the walls. It's a totally novel concept and I can't imagine why it didn't take off.

It's very tricky, for sure, but it isn't impossibly hard. I managed to beat the game, even if Star Land is fucking bullshit. I learned at the end that you can customise your paddle as well, they totally should have communicated that earlier on.

games.name: Isles of Sea and Sky
review: After I fell in love with Void Stranger last year and then found myself drawn to Block Koala no less when playing UFO 50, it finally hit me that I fucking love block puzzle games! Like puzzle games in general are totally my shit and specifically these sukopan-style games slap so hard.

This one is special because there is a whole world full of puzzles that you can walk around freely. If a puzzle is too difficult, you can just find something else to do and come back to it. This is great most of the time, but this game does have power ups which make certain puzzles possible, and sometimes when I'm tackling a tough puzzle I doubt myself whether I'm just too dumb to solve it, or if I actually need to collect a power-up from somewhere else first. It's led to a couple of moments of frustration, but it's totally forgivable given how good the puzzles are.

Soundtrack is fab as well. It comes with a difficult-to-understand story which is communicated with some sparse pixel art cutscenes after solving particular puzzles. I managed to beat the final puzzles and didn't really understand what was going on. But it's fine the game is about the puzzles after all. Part of me would like to go back and 100% but I do feel like the game might be too insanely hard, especially with some of the later areas.

games.name: Rift of the NecroDancer
review: What made the original, Crypt of the Necrodancer, so special was that it was something entirely new, a dungeon crawling roguelike rhythm game. Fucking sick. So when I saw this sequel I was sceptical because it's just a plain old rhythm game. Nonetheless I like me a rhythm game and it's a been a while so I got it and it's so good. This might be the most polished rhythm game I've ever played.

It's hard as nails, but also so reasonable! The timings are forgiving, and there's this system where you lose health if you get hit by an incoming monster, so if you don't press the right button in time. But if you press the wrong button at any given point, you don't lose health, instead you lose your combo. So it means that you can kind of mash on the difficult bits, and at first this bothered me, but it just means that you can get through the levels without dying, just with a low score. So you can kinda play the game how you want, going for the high score or not. Going for the high score is insanely difficult but those leaderboards are tempting me, that's for sure.

When I accidentally started a song on hard mode near the start, I was so shook. You're meant to be able to follow all that?? But by the end of playing through the story, I got so good at the game. Things which seemed impossible like those jumping harpies, I've totally got down now. I just needed to practice them and the songs they come in. I've since gone through and beaten (almost) everything on hard mode and it feels great. It feels so good to get good at the game, and this game lets you do that. The progression through the track is pretty great for that.

There are some other things like minigames and bosses, but they're nothing compared to the actual core gameplay, it's all about the normal rhythm game stuff. I will say there is a really cool thing in 'remix mode' which randomises the monsters, so you kinda have serious replayability. And the difficulty levels will keep you going for a long time.

I will admit, in terms of vibes, there is another rhythm game which has this beat: Everhood. Everhood had an actually fascinating story, lots of funny and wacky nonsense and all around great vibes. This game is far more generic in terms of presentation, and the story is actually a joke. I would have loved some funny writing. But at least the music is good! I didn't love the heavy metal tracks because I'm just not a fan of the genre, but also because they tended to be too fast, making reactions really hard. But most of the tracks were delightful. Personal favourites were from 'Sam Webster' and 'Nick Nausbaum'.

games.name: Split Fiction
review: This is a co-op game 100% designed for you and your partner to play together on the couch. The game features two characters who develop a friendship throughout the game and I imagine they thought it would a great way for people to bond while playing the game. I don't think achieves it though. Firstly because the game has a 3D camera, a double jump and a air-dash, and multitasking - it's hard for people who don't know how to play games. Secondly because the vibes are off. Let's talk about the vibes.

The premise is good: two female writers are trapped in their own made-up stories and have to escape. It's both sci-fi and fantasy and the worlds are great. Actually there are tons of great ideas in general, especially in terms of gameplay mechanics. But the two characters are so insufferable it hurts. One of them is happy-go-lucky and the other is sarcastic and rude. And as I learned playing the Final Fantasy 7 Rebirth, it drives me insane to see characters who have no social skills. This bitch Mio is so rude it blew me away. You are literally trapped in a fantasy land with a stranger and you don't take a moment to appreciate your never-seen-before surroundings or the fact that magic exists and just talk about it! If I were Zoe I would be pissed.

Then as the story goes on, the girls inevitably become friends in the most trope-y and predictable way possible. The writing is just so annoying. It's clearly a game for normies! The bonding on the couch really becomes laughing at the game instead of laughing with the game very quickly. For a game with so many great ideas, it's a shame they put no time into the story. Also there is absolutely no lesbian energy.

games.name: CLICKOLDING
review: This game is terrifying in a way I have never experienced before. This game is a sex thing. I straight up don't recommend it, unless you're interested in real weird shit. I really liked it though I won't lie. I definitely can't stop thinking about it.

games.name: Case of the Golden Idol
review: This is a detective game! You have a short moment in time and you have to collect all the evidence and then fill in the gaps in the story, Obra Dinn style. It's so good!
There is a bunch of these scenes and you get to see this wild overriding story over the course of many years. Great vibes and really fun to finally get the answer.

games.name: Metroid Prime Remastered
review: Decided to start off my year by replaying this absolute banger of a game. I really recommend this to anyone who hasn't played it. It's a timeless and wonderful game which really is more puzzle than action. Samus is a badass, and the vibes of the game are immaculate. She is totally alone on an alien planet and has to deal with a bunch of bullshit and take down this insane monster by herself, and she does it because she's fucking Samus. I really enjoyed reliving the soundtrack, and this time I particularly vibed with the music from Phendrana Drifts Depths.

This remake on the Switch is so fucking good. I'm not normally paying attention to performance and technical stuff, but I read that this game is kind of a miracle - it looks insanely good and also runs super smoothly at 60fps. The boys and girls at Retro Studios much be super experts at making video games, and the new Metroid Prime game is definitely gonna be so fucking good. I just need to know what they were working after they finished Donkey Kong Country. It's driving me crazy.
I am still pissed about this one chozo artifact though. Had to look up the thing with the tower, super lame!

games.name: Advance Wars 1+2: Re-Boot Camp
review: I loved this game, specifically the second one as a child playing on the GBA. I got into this way before becoming a Fire Emblem fan! It took a bit of time for me to pick it up because I genuinely thought it would be crap. I thought the gameplay would have aged badly and the new look isn't exactly that appealing, but I'm totally hooked again!

Gameplay-wise this is super fun. It's super satisfying to go for a specific strategy and see it pay off. One-shotting units with bombers or submarines or medium tanks... man there's nothing better. I will say though that it's tough! And the enemy AI has pulled off some genius shit. One gripe I do have is that some of the later battles with lots of bases and cities tend to go on for ages... I'm not finished playing the game as I'm writing this, but the map pictured below took me all afternoon. I have some strong memories of the end of the second game, so I guess I have that to look forward to next...

Vibes-wise this game has a super weird direction. It's war but it also feels like playfighting between kids. The toy-box aesthetics and comically extreme characters really laugh in the face of the horrors of war. I'm not trying to criticise the game for this, it's just jarring! It's not trying to make any points about war or even tell a good story, it's just trying to be a banger strategy game, which it is. The soundtrack is a bop too - all the old themes I loved from back then, remade and with special individual tracks for when you activate your CO power (a much needed change).

games.name: Still Wakes The Deep
review: I played a horror game! It was so scary! I really am not into horror stuff but I was interested by this one because of it's unique setting. It takes place on an oil rig in the North Sea in the 70s. It's historically accurate and features some great Scottish voice acting. Then at the beginning of the game, the drill hits some kind of otherworldly monster which then proceeds to transform this open platform in the middle of the sea into terrifying deathtrap. It's good for people who aren't faint of heart like me.

games.name: 13 Sentinels: Aegis Rim
review: Daaaaamn this game is wild! It's a visual novel unlike any other, and honestly worth checking out for the innovative way it tells a story alone. You have 13 whole-ass protagonists who all have intricately interconnected lives and stories, and you get to follow all their journeys in any order you like. Octopath Traveler, eat your heart out! Unlike that stiff storytelling with 8 entirely separate stories, hear all the characters interact and it is so exciting. I admit that it relies on some of those classic anime tropes a lot, but I allow it because the actual story is so wild and unpredictable. It's got all these great plot twists and because you decide what order to learn about them, discovering them makes it feel like YOU figured it out, or that you stumbled onto some juicy information that you shouldn't have found already. Delicious.

It also has some real time strategy gameplay to mix up all the dialogue scenes which looking back were quite refreshing and nice. I didn't enjoy it so much when playing them, especially at the start, but actually they weren't too bad, and by the end I was getting quite good at it. Focus of this game is on the incredible and absolutely wild story though. Highly recommended.

games.name: Rivals of Aether 2
review: Finally, a platform fighter that's just as fun as smash to play! It's so good! At first I wasn't vibing with the characters, I mean it's not like smash where you already know the characters because it's motherfucking princess peach. But after you play around a bit, you'll eventually gravitate towards one character or another. For me, I landed on Maypul, a fast and tricky character who has some fun kill setups. At first I was drawn to her because of the duck hunt-like plant combos but I also really vibe with the pikachu-style small fast character energy.

The learning curve is really nice - it's not like smash melee in the sense that you can get good really quickly and it's so satisfying. And I still have so far to go, like all this ledge movement stuff I've barely even touched. I played with some pros at a smash tournament recently and I got absolutely fucked up, and I dunno it's hard to describe but it was a total honour. I really do just need to git gud.

There's also a nice online matchmaking system, but that's not really my thing because I need to debrief about my games with someone IRL otherwise I get frustrated. Luckily I have some friends that I can play with from time to time.
I will say I think this game is missing some kind of story mode/lore about the characters, but I heard that that's coming later.

games.name: UFO 50
review: Holy crap, is this game real? Dear visitors to this website, please consider dropping everything and buying this collection of 50 arcade games for the low price of 20 euros. You have to understand, this isn't just any old collection of NES/arcade-style games, these are all brand-new games! They've been developed with modern game design philosophy and ALL of the games are bangers. All 50 of them!

This collection has everything: platformers, puzzle games, action games, top down strategy, RPGs, and plenty of wacky, hard-to-define-genre games as well. Each of them bring something new to the table, to the point where most of them could be expanded into their own indie games and they would be fucking great. Inevitably, not every game will be for everyone, but that's the beauty of UFO 50 - everyone can find something that suits their tastes in there, and everyone will also end up trying out different kinds of games that they would otherwise never touch.

Personally I love puzzle games so I was delighted when the very first game I picked happened to be a block puzzle game called Block Koala. I got so into block koala and although I recognise why most people wouldn't rate the game very high, I totally clicked with it and very quickly 100%ed it. Camouflage was another banger puzzle game, so good.

Other highlights for those who are interested were definitely Rail Heist, Vainger, Mortol 2, Night Manor, Party House and Hyper Contender. Block Koala still #1 though, maybe it's because it was the first one I picked. Feels like Block Koala and I have a special bond.

One last thing I wanted to point out: this game has a huge and incredible chiptune soundtrack! Many of the tracks are even microtonal, which is something you hear almost never in video games. Hugely inspired and hugely inspiring. I couldn't pick a single recommendation so enjoy the <a href="https://youtu.be/O-5JriuYm8s?feature=shared">banger start-up music<a>.

games.name: The Legend of Zelda: Echoes of Wisdom
review: I was so excited to learn about this game, because I loved the Link's Awakening remake that much. The team did deliver on another high-standard zelda game, but I can't say I enjoyed playing through it as much as other zelda games. It's hard to say why, because the vibe is very much the same as Link's Awakening. I guess this vibe is closer to the beaten track. There's much less weird shit.

The gameplay stuff is quite fun though, if a bit broken in the second half of the game. I'm not sure they should give you access to that water block or that cloud. Battle was great though! Everytime I found a new monster I got excited about its echo, but always went back to my beloved, deku baba. I would describe my playstyle as Deku baba only. It's just so fast!

I appreciated that we could finally play as zelda, but they made her a silent protagonist! There is no need. Link is already a silent protagonist and then they put the two of them together in the end and they literally couldn't have a conversation. It's gone too far! It also felt like I might as well have been playing as Link the whole time. Only when your name is cleared and you can start going round in your pink dress did I feel a swell of pride about playing as a princess.

games.name: Kingdom Hearts: Birth By Sleep
review: Using the last ounce of my fading strength, I launched into the next game in the collection, a prequel spinoff which follows three new characters. This game has even more battle systems than usual, and I was punished pretty quickly for not engaging with them. I managed to get quite far, but at some point it became clear that I would have to grind levels, and level up these commands, and worse, in order to do so, I would have to play a mario party-style minigame. I noped out of that, finally took a step to preserve my health and sanity, and put kingdom hearts down forever.

games.name: Age of Mythology: Retold
review: Some friends convinced me to try this and we played it together in a LAN-format which was fun. I wasn't able to keep up with all the tactics though and didn't feel great about grinding the game to get good at it. Wasn't keen on the length of the games - would rather have either a quick run so I can easily jump in and out, or super long like Factorio or Civilisation.

games.name: Kingdom Hearts HD 2.5 Remix
review: Having suffered through Kingdom Hearts 1, Chain of Memories and 358/2 Days last year, everyone was telling me to grit my teeth and play Kingdom Hearts 2 because it's "actually good" but lord these fans are blinded by nostalgia. This game is equally as bad as the first game, except it has more stuff in it!

However, I have to hand it to them for making this game real. Having such a ridiculously convoluted story, bewildering cameos from disney characters and final fantasy characters just hanging out. Incredible that it happened. I can imagine that at the time, this game would have been so fucking crazy.

The game features so many cameos it's actually ridiculous. All the stories and worlds are short and shallow so they can fit in more content. I think the appeal is more like "wow I am riding Aladdin's magic carpet" rather than "this carpet minigame is fun".

One thing I appreciate about Kingdom Hearts is the stilted dialogue, which leads to the funniest cutscenes ever. I watched a "kingdom hearts out of context" video and it had me cackling. The comedic timing on some of the nonsense that the characters spout really does tickle me.

I admit, I didn't engage with the battle system as much as I could have. I played on normal mode and mashed X to get through the game. Only at the very end of the game I realised you could increase your ability points by using items. In the final world I had a ridiculously difficult boss fight (Roxas) where the game suddenly turned into Elden Ring and I had to spend two hours increasing my level and learning his attack patterns. I was utterly unprepared and it didn't feel good to have to learn how to play the game then to beat him. In my defence, the player has to put in a lot of work to understand how stuff works. I'm used to modern games where things are properly explained.
Well, I beat the game, which is saying something, I guess.

games.name: Thank Goodness You're Here
review: I heard about this game having good british humour so I found one of my few actual british friends at around 4:20pm and blazed through this game and it was so fucking funny. I do feel like the average German won't enjoy the vibe as much as we did but let me tell you we were in absolute stitches. The game itself is pretty bad, like it's just walking around trying to figure out what to do by prodding everything, but that's made up for by the outrageous nonsense happening on screen all the time.
But yeah I do recommend it, the writing is genius and it's pretty cheap.

games.name: Harold Halibut
review: My neighbour Fab and I enjoy playing indie games together when we hang out and this year we played a visual novel called Harold Halibut which he had on his gamepass. It was a nice time! The main thing to note about it is the stop motion/clay animation style. It gives it a vibe of being somewhat of a parody, like Team America or something. It means even the serious parts you have to enjoy with a smile. This combined with some honestly excellent dialogue makes for a delightful little experience.

You play as a very plain and boring person who has a heart of gold, and he is a bit of a jack-of-all-trades handyman on a spaceship that is stuck in the sea of an alien world. All his colleagues speak down at him but in a loving way, and it's fun to see him deal with that. It's presented in a way that he might be depressed, but then he does find pleasure in the little interactions, because there are many delightful little quirks in the story to enjoy. After some twists in the story, you can see how his outlook changes, and it's handled quite maturely.

It's got a nice little soundtrack, a lovely setting, and great characters. I really recommend it, although not if you're looking for a game. This is a visual novel through and through, you will only be pressing A!

games.name: A Little to the Left
review: Tried out this little thing on Fab's Xbox. It's a game where you have to line things up neatly. I think it's great for people with OCD but I don't have that so I was left unsatisfied.

games.name: Chained Echoes
review: I was recommended this JRPG and was kinda feeling like playing a good one after being disappointed by Sea of Stars, and although I recognise that this is good, I wasn't able to finish it.

It's got plenty of interesting characters, and you play as lots of different constellations of them, and the world seems interesting, and the music good. I just felt like playing it was work and coming back into it after a break was really hard. Maybe it's because I was also playing Balatro at this time and I just always wanted to play that instead.

games.name: Metal Gear Solid
review: This isn't my first Kojima game but it's definitely the first one I've committed to and played through to the end, and I have to say, I don't vibe with his sense of humour! Making fun of otakus, action films and... women, it's all a bit much for me. This game is for fans of Die Hard or Terminator, and not people like me who like nice things.

That being said I have to hand it to Metal Gear Solid for creating an action film game that actually works. The atmosphere and soundtrack is fantastic! Snake is ridiculous, but funny and kinda cool. He needs to stop hitting on every woman he sees though he genuinely sounds desperate. I also enjoy how over-the-top all the characters are, especially Liquid Snake, as well as the plot twists. They're genuinely hilarious.

Gameplay-wise it isn't for me, stealthing around and then just murdering people isn't very fun, so I don't think I'll play any more of these games. But it was nice to see where Snake from Smash came from. I'm still on my journey to play, complete and understand every game that all the smash characters come from, so it's nice to tick off another character. Only a handful remain!

games.name: Punchout
review: As part of my continued effort to play, complete and truly understand the games that all the smash characters came from, I took it upon myself to beat Punchout on the NES. This game is good, has aged very well, and is really hard. I haven't beaten it yet, but goddamn it I will. I wanted to get it done before I post this list but I can't get past Bald Bull, who is about halfway through the game. I have a long journey ahead of me...

games.name: Tongue Tale
review: A friend of mine made this! So I was curious how it was going to be. Imagine being a solo dev on a hobby project and having it release on switch! Awesome. So shoutouts to Remke - you can buy the game and support him.

The game itself is heavily inspired by Celeste - super difficult platforming designed to be super satisfying when you finally get it, and made more fun by restarting failed levels faster than you can blink. It's based on a pretty interesting mechanic of swinging on your tongue, where you use momentum and timing to propel yourself through hand-crafted levels. It's something that you can get better at and is really satisfying when you get right. Many of the puzzles are based on timing jumps and letting go of your tongue at the precise moment when you will fly at just the right angle, which requires a good spatial understanding.

Shit's not easy, which in theory isn't a problem - Celeste is similar. However, where this game fails is finding that difficulty balance in the level design. Celeste somehow manages to find the sweetspot between "this is kinda easy" and "this is bullshit", presumably through a hell of a lot of playtesting. Tongue Tale doesn't manage to do that (sorry Remke). The first world is a lot of fun, but somewhere in the second or third world the difficulty spikes so insanely quickly into the "this is bullshit" realm that it kinda detracts from the experience. I eventually did beat the game, but I have to admit it was a struggle.

games.name: Paper Mario: The Thousand Year Door
review: Holy moly is this a dream come true? I loved this game when I was younger and they've only gone and made it even better. The first and most important thing to talk about is the insane glow-up that the soundtrack got. It has truly gotten the Origami King treatment and I mean that in the best possible way. They've added new tracks, new variations of existing tracks, and boldly updated the old favourites which is almost always tasteful and successful. The battle theme has multiple variations depending on the region you're in and it's touches like that which turn a good game into a special game. You're in a mysterious off-colour forest and run into an enemy? Consider the vibe MATCHED.

I will say that they added an Erhu (a very recognisable Chinese string instrument) to the Glitz pit music and it honestly sounds a bit off. In my opinion they should have gone for more of a lucha libre/WWE vibe but whatever it still sounds good.

Another amazing update is the new expressions and animations all the characters have. Still the same as the original and yet injected with flair and love and care. Gameplay-wise they nerfed Power Bounce which thinking about it is probably a good thing. Some of the later boss battles can't be cheesed with it anymore.

The OG game is so strong that you really can't go wrong and yet still my expectations were exceeded. The locations, the characters, the humour, the VIBE, it's all great, and absolute bonus it's a lot of fun to play too.

I loved beating this game. I don't have the time that I used to for these things so I did it in little bursts. I even completed chapter 6 while on an overnight train! And beating the final boss was difficult just like I remember, but this time you can skip the cutscenes!!

games.name: Cassette Beasts
review: This is an indie game inspired by Pokemon where it's very much the same as Pokemon in many many ways but brings in some cool new gameplay features. In this game it's possible to fuse monsters together and they straight up made designs and names for every single combination (and there are over 100 of the things!). That alone is an incredible achievement and I was thoroughly enjoying seeing new combinations of my favourite mons even at the end of the game. However, there are so many of them that their specialness does kinda wear off after a while.

It must have taken so long to do all the fusions... and I think the Dev time they spent on that should have been spent on... the rest of the game. It really is a technical mess! This game is glitchier than the newer Pokemon games which is impressive and the crazy loading screens and bad graphics is just on a different level. Normally I'm not too much of a bitch when it comes to this stuff, but it negatively affects the vibe of the game and is impossible to ignore. I can't recommend the game for that alone.

One good thing was the open world aspect, you can go to any area whenever, which is great for catching cool mons. The worst thing about Pokemon (Well maybe not but for me a super annoying thing) is not being able to get a team of your faves early on in the game. All my faves are late game Pokemon and I'm pissed about that. The best thing about Pokemon is curating a team of my favourite mons and giving them all the love and attention that they deserve, watching them grow and beating the game with them. In cassette beasts I was able to find my faves (of course the dumbest designs ever, and this game has plenty of goofy ass mons that I'm immediately drawn to) and I was also able to swap them out easily because the levelling up is based on your character, not your mons, a great idea.

To end this with another fat negative, the writing is terrible and generic. The premise is very forced, and even the interesting boss characters don't make much sense really. Also, I was not vibing at all with the soundtrack, some cheesy soft rock/indie songs with vocals. I was told it had a good OST but it wasn't good for my tastes and I ended up muting the game.

Actually I'll end with a fat positive, the game features a delightful companion character who joins you towards the end, who single handedly brings a fantastic energy to the game, and when he comes with you at the end... just great.

games.name: Animal Well
review: This game has such a strong vibe it's insane. Everything is bioluminescent and dripping with water and it just looks so fucking rad. I love that you play as a tiny blob which can neatly fit through every gap. It's very polished and I respect that (just before this I played Cassette Beasts which is a bit of a technical mess so the contrast was there).

This game has little to no background music which shocked me at first, because I am a lover of video game music. But it didn't take long for me to understand that that is crucial to the vibe of the environment. The sound design is super good even without the music - there is so much going on in terms of water dripping sounds, ambient noises, squelchy sounds as you move, it makes it all sound so real. And without the music it does give it that lonely metroid vibe. And on the occasions where music does play, it hits hard because of it. Interesting choice and although I'm a little upset because I'm sure a game with this vibe and colour scheme would have a beautiful twinkly soundtrack, I understand that not having music goes a long way to set this game apart from all the other super similar metroidvanias.

This game is super similar to other metroidvanias, like it gave me heavy Axiom Verge vibes, which isn't a bad thing. It's got some very creative power-ups which are delightful, and focuses more on puzzle solving than combat, which I personally really appreciate. But there's another game which this clearly takes lots of inspiration from: Fez. Fez is this puzzler (also with a strong vibe) which you play through once, then it slowly dawns on you, that was just the beginning, and you are assaulted with many higher-level meta puzzles which turn the whole game on its head. Tunic was kinda similar too. Animal Well has the same thing going for it - you beat the game, and realise huh, there's more to it than this... you start digging and keep digging, and by the time you've reached some of the "deeper" parts of the well, you've already made a whole bunch of notes and are starting to go a bit crazy. I love that shit.

games.name: Balatro
review: Holy crap I finally did it, I found a game that lives up to Slay the Spire. Now that I finally beat the heart on A20 which every character, I felt good about putting StS down and it was around this time that I picked up Balatro. It's so addicting. I love getting exactly the right card you need for the moment. The higher difficulties are super hard! I know I'm going to be playing this for a long time... at least until Slay the Spire 2 comes out next year.

I'm also into the hypnotic music that plays - they really made a great vibe with the game too. It's great because I enter in an obsessive trance, just looking for the the numbers to go higher and higher as my eyes glaze over.

games.name: Final Fantasy VII: Rebirth
review: I've got a lot to say about this one so buckle up. As an enjoyer of the original FF7 and... I think I was an enjoyer of the previous game (Final Fantasy VII Remake), I felt the desire to play this game too. But I've been shocked by how horrifically sanitised it is. I think Remake was much the same but here it's even more so! I realised pretty quickly during this game that I'm not actually playing a game, I'm playing a product. I'm being served content and I'm supposed to enjoy it. After all this is a triple AAA big budget game that I paid full price for, and consumers like me have certain expectations. So the game gives me open world, generous dollops of fan-service, a whole ass card game, one thousand million mini games, a whole bunch of playable characters (including big seph), orchestral remixes of beloved old songs...

It just all feels so forced! You can't escape it. Sure, this game has magic and love but it all stems from the very strong base of the original game. The world of FF7 is so fucking cool, with the world being overtaken by an energy company after they monopolise a new environment-destroying energy source. It's so topical, I love it. Seriously, play the original, it still holds up today and tells such a cool story about this fascinating world (a whole-ass planet, by the way). Rebirth isn't bad as such because it's built on this base. But what it adds is either annoying, superfluous or made without love.

The worst offender is the open world. Don't get me wrong, I really don't mind an open world. But this one is less of an open world and more of a to-do list of pointless tasks in a big area. I have to go to the various spots and complete menial tasks in order to get a rush of dopamine as it is ticked off. Most aggravating for me was Chadley, the AI robot child character who sends Cloud off to do these super scripted ~I'm playing a video game~ tasks. Go defeat these monsters, go take a photo here, go activate this tower. What do I actually get out of this? Luckily I'm not actually invested enough in the gameplay to be interested in the materia you get from Chadley.

One thing the open world does do is give the sense that you're exploring the whole planet. And I have to say it looks quite nice. The various towns all look fantastic as well. This is really a feast for the eyes, especially for those who played the original. Seeing Costa del Sol, Gold Saucer, Cosmo Canyon all looking so good is a treat. There are also lush, orchestral versions of the original soundtrack in these places, which is delightful.

But while I'm talking about the soundtrack, I have to say that it's all over the place. The general vibe appears to be orchestral, but then it throws in the wacky stuff (certain sidequests, chocobo music, moogles, cactuars...) and the music goes all electronic and wild. There is also gratuitous jazz music here and there, and other random shit depending on what's going on. It feels like they're just cramming in as much content as possible. This is a recurring theme.

Similar topic, this game switches from serious to silly so casually, it's jarring. The chocobos really are completely ridiculous! And there's something about seeing them in HD which makes it even wilder. In the OG, things happen so quickly and switch themselves up so regularly and you don't even bat an eyelid if you need to ride a chicken through the swamp. The vibe is so strong that silly things can coexist with the serious main story. In this remake, the silly, cartoonish things simply look so out of place, I can't take anything seriously.

Two of the main characters (Red 13 and Cait Sith, my fave from the OG) are so outlandish in this game that it takes away any hopes of seriousness when they're involved. Actually despite that, I'm super happy with how they did Cait Sith because that really isn't easy to translate from the PS1 version and he looks and sounds great. Red 13 though, god the thing with his voice in Cosmo Canyon is so dumb, and he doesn't have any personality apart from that. He was way cooler in the OG I can't even describe. As for the other characters, Aerith and Barret are fine, they're both delightful. Tifa I can't even say anything because any semblance of a personality is completely eclipsed by her humongous knockers. Those badockadonks have their own field of gravity they are that huge. Whenever she's on screen I can't help but make an out-loud comment about how needlessly massive her tits are. Yuffie is beautifully animated, but her outfit from the original really needed an update. She's really a ninja, and trying to make a sleeveless, crop-top, turtlenecked, knitted woollen jumper work.

The worst offender though is Cloud. God I hate how useless he is in social situations. They made him stand-offish and distant so that he looks like a badass, but to me he's just a dickhead. Aerith is trying so hard to make conversation and she is just suffering because Cloud just leaves her on read constantly. And somehow, the group all still tolerate him, nay revere him?? He literally does bad spoiler thing in the Gongaga reactor and Tifa is like, you good Cloud no worries babe. AT LEAST Cloud has some decent sexual tension with Sephiroth, who spends 80% of his screen time just glaring. I'm kinda into that.

That was a lot of words about the vibe of the game, here's my review of the gameplay: The battle system in the game is really good. It took me a while to get into it (I'd forgotten everything from the previous game) but it's satisfying and fun. I also enjoy the Queen's Blood card game a lot. It's cool that there aren't any loading screens.

games.name: Penny's Big Breakaway
review: I was drawn to this game because of its colour scheme of all things. Everything is saturated in blue which gives it a very special vibe. It's the colours you see first thing when you wake up in the morning when you're still woozy and coming to. It reminds me of this game I played as a child "Zool 2" in terms of vibe. Something very special!

I do feel like the character of Penny is a bit random. Her design is just a bunch of elements thrown together and doesn't have so much of a personality. There is some missed potential there, especially with the "big breakaway" part of the game. It doesn't feel like you're running away, but rather like you're going through some levels. If it were me, I would have gone for Penny running away constantly, with animations reflecting her fear/excitement, kinda like in Pizza Tower.

The game itself is pretty fun, it's a momentum game kinda like Sonic, which makes sense because it's from the same devs as Sonic Mania (one of the best games ever). And by the end of the game I kinda got it with the loop, dash and jump moves. At the start though it was really hard, and I kept hitting walls and being bad and it was frustrating. I didn't feel the need to replay levels and do them better.

One thing about the game is that you can choose whether you go through slowly and find all the collectibles and unlock difficult levels, go for mega points by having a big combo, or speedrunning. Different strokes for different folks but I was totally unsure about what I wanted! I wish I could have been told what to do in that regard, but that's just me.

One last thing: I regret playing this on the switch. The graphics and framerate are bad and not in a good way. When I watched some gameplay from the PC version after finishing the game I was so shook!

games.name: Metroid Fusion
review: Compared with other Metroid games this one is different but the same. The same because you're metroidvania-ing around just like Zero mission or Super Metroid, fighting similar bosses, living your normal life. Gameplay-wise I did think to myself, this game is just like the others. But that's not a bad thing, it's a great formula.

What it does differently is the vibe. This game is way more of a horror game than other ones - you can see where the blueprint for Metroid Dread is. There are some genuinely horrible & creepy moments. The first time you see the SA-X, or when you encounter a certain someone encased in ice, the introduction of one of the bosses towards the end where you first see its corpse... It's so good. Terrifying. The music really adds to it as well.

It's way more linear in the sense that this computer tells you what to do at any point but I really appreciated that because I didn't enjoy in Super metroid how sometimes you had to decide on your own to go to a completely different sector to progress. It still left many things open in many cases so I still felt super smart finding my way around a lot of the time. There were like two points where I had to look up the answer because to be fair it was completely ridiculous. This one hole you have to find in the water sector is just so dumb, and the comments on the youtube video which shows the whole made me feel better about looking it up.

games.name: Cobalt Core
review: I heard about this game from a list of recommendations by Lena Raine for games with great soundtracks and yes, I love the music

This is just the same as slay the spire. Instead it's got cute animals and great dialogue. One thing really nice about it is you play as three characters at once and get access to all three of their card decks, which means it's fun to pick and choose what you want.

But it's definitely not as deep as slay the spire, and I wish it had an ascension system instead of just four difficulty modes. I also wish there were more obvious goals to complete in the game, instead of just winning 18 runs to unlock these dialogues.

It was fun learning what was really broken in the game and what could be ignored. Like in slay the spire, card draw is super important, but in this game not so much - I would say energy is way more important. Also, movement is far more powerful than shielding. Pretty cool.

games.name: 1000xRESIST
review: This is a visual novel about a future in which aliens destroyed everything, but one lady somehow survived and made lots of clones of herself. Those clones learn about how things came to be, it's an interesting premise!

I got a bit of a bad start to the game because I just gave this visceral reaction to stories set in North America with American voice acting. At first glance it looks like more American TV, and I guessed it wouldn't have too much depth to it. On top of that, it was going for very abstract and indiscrete vibes, a little too arty farty for me.

As I got into it I did see its merit, it's got some interesting things to say about why bad people act the way they do, and choices as a player in the scope of a video game. That being said, I wasn't motivated to go back for other endings after I got a bad ending.
I think the emotional parts were a bit forced, and the music was kinda generic. I wouldn't recommend it.

games.name: Dave the Diver
review: This game is so kooky and fun, and made with love. It has a great art direction, and fantastic characters. You play a larger man who dives in a special location which contains all the fish in the world and then sells them as sushi. It's a wild premise and one that I really enjoy. I love that you just get real life fish and literally everything can be eaten. Even the bosses are just sharks and shit (for the most part).

Dave the character is just great, he is often sidelined and people are kinda rude to him but he just takes it in his stride. He loves what he does and has a great positive mindset and you just love to see it. He's surrounded by some other amazing characters, like the sushi chef. Their little dialogues are always great, and all the characters are beautifully characterised by these amazing short pixel art cutscenes. They are SUCH a pleasure to watch always.

Going diving and catching new fish is also super fun. First time to see and catch a shark? Awesome. And the sushi restaurant parts are also great. They're super satisfying and making more and more money each day just feels so good.

But I don't think I'd recommend this game to friends, because it is just sooooo slow. Diving in general is slow, and the story progresses really slowly. There are a million side quests, including this eco-app where you are encouraged to collect certain items. You get so little out of these quests, but I found myself obsessively getting everything all the time. It's meant to be a relatively chill game but I found myself optimising and making sure I could complete everything, which resulted in a bunch of super long dives.

As the game goes on, it continuously piles on new mechanics, minigames, stuff that is clearly designed to keep you interested, as the core gameplay of shooting your harpoon at fish will get old quick. That's cool and all but by the end you have so much shit on, that it's almost overwhelming. I spent more time farming, transferring fish from the fish farm, asking myself which recipes I wanted to upgrade, playing these dumb phone minigames than actually diving. They just cram the game full of new content, and it's not even good. Like each new mechanic is so shallow that it gets old very quickly.

This fucking phone game which is like tamagotchi was what did it for me. Like why am I spending my time on this. They literally give you a phone that you can check for all the various game content, including a sushi version of instagram, and you end up just staring at it for ages. I truly don't think this game is a comment on how we are addicted to our phones. I just think they put too much shit into the game and it got boring. This would have been way better on a smaller scale in my opinion.

games.name: Void Stranger
review: Wow this game is the best puzzle game I've ever played. There is so much going on it's insane! It may look like a Gameboy game but let me tell you it is the most engaging game ever, not just for its satisfying puzzling gameplay. It's also absolutely drowned in secrets, lore, amazing characters, twists and turns, and 10/10 music.

Similar to Outer Wilds or Tunic, you'll want to go into this game blind! Because you can progress using knowledge and skills, not with power ups or stuff like that. As you first start making your way through the puzzles, you will be blind to all the things on your screen. But at some point something will click and you'll have a moment where you say to yourself 'hold on... there's more to this than I thought'.

The vibe is on point. The music is so good. Please listen to the music of the first area. It, like many tracks, loops only after a very long time, and goes through many stages and sections, never getting boring. The imagery in the game is insane too.
If you play it, please send me a message and we can talk about how good it is together!

games.name: Dr Mario 64
review: Continuing the theme of playing games of smash characters, it was time to revisit the Dr Mario puzzle games and see what makes this game tick. As a big fan of Puyo Puyo Tetris (the best puzzle game ever) I was interested to see if this game had the same depth. Short answer: it doesn't. You have to get lucky with the pills, because there isn't a good strategy for what to do when you get the wrong pills. You have to constantly go for vertical rows of 4 because the horizontal ones are just so risky.

I don't know if it's like this in other Dr Mario games but on this one you play against an opponent and they send single blocks over and it just fucks with everything. If they fall down at the wrong time, you're fucked and you have to restart, simple as that.

I managed to get through the story mode by getting lucky, waiting for my opponent to fail or occasionally clutching it out with some good gameplay. I did end up getting quite good at it because it is really fast paced. The final battle was really hard though, you needed that combo of good RNG and good execution. I did kinda enjoy getting that W in the end I won't lie. Anyway this game isn't good but I kinda enjoyed playing it on my switch over christmas.

games.name: Marvel's Spider-Man 2
review: This game is super dumb. My friend Fab lent me the physical game and for some weird reason I ended up completing it. I admit that swinging around town is kinda fun, and towards the end I got better at the game and it was kinda satisfying using all the special abilities. That being said, I played the game on easy because I had no time for dying over and over against some goons.

Wild that this game has web slinging moments, watching a movie moments, and then they pad out the time with swinging fists at goons and even stealthing around (?). Luckily I didn't need to stealth much because I was playing on easy. But it all felt very forced when I was doing all these epic stunts and then bam I'm in a building and have to fight some dudes for a bit.

But god the story is just so ridiculous. I mean it's classic superhero nonsense and it's why I don't have any time for superhero films. There's just so much ridiculousness, like these hunters. There's this dude with too much money who likes hunting, and he has hundreds (thousands?) of loyal cultists who came with him from Foreign Country to New York, all of them willing to die for the cause. All trained in martial arts? There's this character called Black Cat who randomly finds a magic portal. Like, just magic is a thing.
Venom as a thing is fascinating to me. How is this eldritch-horror ooze thing so popular? Everything surrounding this storyline was super predictable.

The worst offender for this game is the very generic soundtrack. Boring ass movie music with no character. They should have given this game an actual vibe like the into the spiderverse film. I also resented how everything just gets destroyed all the time. Spiderman and his escapades just end up destroying every environment they're in.
I don't recommend this game.

games.name: Kingdom Hearts 358/2 Days
review: I also plowed through and started the next "game" in the PlayStation 4 collection, which by the way has the prize for the most ridiculous game title in this list.

SHIT ISN'T EVEN A GAME! This originally came out on DS and instead of remaking it like Chain of Memories, they just remade the cutscenes, and left out the gameplay. This is particularly wild because this story is part of the Kingdom Hearts lore and they put it in the collection so players can follow the story chronologically. Feels like super bad planning.

About 15 minutes in when I realised this wasn't a game but rather a 3 hour movie of these terrible graphics I decided to accept the life I chose for myself and sit through it. This was made better by getting super stoned.

I am blown away by the sheer volume of cutscenes of these characters eating ice cream while precariously balancing on the roof of a clocktower watching the sunset. It's genuinely all they ever do, their only activity. Despite this, the story continues to be baffling and bewildering. At this point I'm so far gone that I'm just letting the bizarre vibes of this entry in the series wash over me. Maybe Kingdom Hearts 2 will be a real game.

games.name: Signalis
review: This is a very cerebral, abstract survival horror game. I didn't truly understand what was going on in the story but the vibe was good. It's apparently got Resident Evil 1 energy which is cool. It has a lot of German DDR in space energy if that makes sense.

I played it together with my friend Fab which was a great idea because the game is really scary and he could play through the difficult bits. After a while you become less scared of the monsters though which is good, although they always have newer scarier monsters waiting for you.

games.name: Kingdom Hearts Re:Chain of Memories
review: I was challenged to play all the Kingdom Hearts games in order and I got the collection on playstation so I thought, why the fuck not, let's play this spin off card game. Shit is WEIRD.

It's an action game like the main one, except the attack you do depends on what your next card is. So in order to get good at the game you have to manage your cards, and also fight in a 3D arena like in the first game. All is well and good but then you meet some boss and it's impossible to get past. I personally struggled with this bitch Larxene (shown in pic) halfway through the game. She is such a bitch I hate her so much.

It completely recycles all the assets from the first game and just tells another bewildering story. At this point I'm just letting it all wash over me. We are introduced to a bizarre shadowy organisation full of villains who all speak with an irritating sarcastic tone constantly. It's a wonder that any of these characters get anything done because they don't know how to communicate at all.

At some point in the game I decided I was in too deep and committed to completing the whole thing. I was forced to look up tactics for how to cheese some of these bosses because towards the end those health bars end up being ridiculously big. Cheesing works to an extent, but I have to admit, I had to get kinda good at the game to beat the bosses... maybe it wasn't so bad.

What was bad was realising that when I completed the game, there's a whole second playthrough with Riku with a new story and new battle mechanics. I had to play it. That shit was also bullshit, just like the main game, and there were fewer opportunities to cheese opponents. Still, I did it. Beating Ansem at the end was really hard but I did it. Mickey Mouse randomly appeared. Riku is caught being edgier than ever before. I can't get over how different this game is to Kingdom Hearts 1.

games.name: Banjo Kazooie
review: One of my goals is to play, complete and understand all the games that the smash characters are from. I did play Banjo Kazooie as a child but I'm pretty sure I never completed it, so having recently got the Nintendo switch online expansion pass, I decided it was time to replay it!

Now in terms of vibes this game is off the charts. There is so much fun nonsense to enjoy. Absolute highlight for me is Brentilda, Gruntilda's "nice" sister who is SUCH a bitch. She is just all over the map and all she does is hate on Gruntilda. It is so funny and I love the energy. Sometimes she's hiding in a corner somewhere and just pops up to say that Gruntilda is disgusting because she eats maggots for breakfast. Sets me off everytime.

I have to say though. It's a terrible game, it's aged really badly. Collecting stuff isn't actually that fun. Having to collect all the music notes from the start whenever you die is miserable, and the jiggies are not signposted properly. The music is really good though, but of course I would say that as a lover of Donkey Kong 64 (proven to be a terrible game).

I loved the final boss, because it was just a quiz. And Grunty is just so funny. Although, it turns out there's a difficult actual boss battle with her if you collect almost all the collectables. I just noped out of that one and watched it on youtube in the name of self-care.

games.name: WarioWare: Move It!
review: This is a delightful party game! It really nails my humour. I played it at christmas with some friends and we had a great time. If you love motion controls, give it a go!

games.name: Kingdom Hearts 1.5 Final Mix
review: I'm on a challenge to play, complete and understand the essence of every game that the smash characters come from. This means that at some point I had to play Kingdom Hearts, and wow. This game is so so so bad. It has aged terribly.

It's at the bottom of this list because it's so bad and I wouldn't recommend it to anyone. But I would be lying if I said I didn't enjoy it. The moment the early 2000s vibe hit like a truck during the opening I knew I was in for a treat. The thought of this being the coolest game ever as a child is just so funny at every point in the game.

I should have known what I was in for in the opening section on the island, where the most annoying music ever played in a very short loop and I had to do nonsense tasks for my friends. After that I was treated to a bewildering story and game with many difficulty spikes, many points where I had no idea where to go, and many times having to look up a walkthrough.

The disney worlds, one of the most bewildering aspects of the game, are so tiny and bland it's funny. I was just amazed that they managed to secure the rights to all these characters and worlds. Although by the end, having had my standards set so low, I found myself forming opinions on them. Why does Neverland only take place on a boat? It was kinda cool that you can be a mermaid in Atlantica... and the music in Agrabah isn't too bad. Those gummi ship sections though, terrible.

I never truly understood how to use all the items. I spent a lot of the time without any proper weapons, nerfing myself to the point where bosses were endless HP sponges. I just assumed that's how the game was meant to be. I guess I've been trained by modern games to be signposted stuff like that.
The cutscenes and dialog, the edginess, the characters... the whole thing is wild. I'll never forget playing this game.

games.name: Cocoon
review: I had such a laugh playing through this game with my friend Fab. We did it in one evening, making sex jokes the whole time, seeing as it's a game about balls. As we progressed through, the game assaulted us with more and more vaginal imagery. Lots of imagery surrounding childbirth, wombs, balls shooting through tubes, phalluses. The real deal. I couldn't not see it.

The puzzles got really good towards the end. I love a good puzzle game and this one blew my mind. It was so clean and polished as well. At many points in the game we nodded and said "...game design". This had clearly been designed by a real game designer yknow. Actually I wondered if it was a little too over-engineered, taking away the magic a bit. But I couldn't deny that the little game design things they implemented were all great. Things like old paths closing off if it's definitely the wrong way to go, or pleasant music playing when you start solving a puzzle in the right way.

games.name: Anodyne 2: Return to Dust
review: This game blew me away. Very hard to describe what it's about but here we go. You start the game inside an egg and you have to be born, but not before you get some kind of seed implanted inside of you. You are tasked by what appears to be a religious entity (the Centre) to rid the world of dust and bring about the Anodyne, something like a rapture (the word "anodyne" means painkiller). As you go around removing the evil dust, the seed inside you watches as you do your job. The evil dust affects the citizens of the weird and wonderful world, and you remove it, numbing the pain and "clarifying" things for them.

As you go through the game, doing your job and meeting all these suffering people, you realise the game relates a lot to the human experience. There are many points in the game where you can draw parallels to how we grow up, how our parents affect us, our relationship with entities like "the Centre", and many many other things. The game is dripping with meaning.

It also has an immaculate vibe. The world looks like a PS1 game, polygons and everything, but it also has nice lighting. The colour palette makes it look dreamy. It also looks dumb and trashy and low budget and I love that. There are also some 2D sections for when you shrink down to a miniscule size in order to clean the dust, and they are delightful. If you're interested, give this track from an opening area a listen

games.name: Super Mario Bros Wonder
review: This game is delightful, perfect for co-op and full of great things that I greatly appreciate (elephants, nonsense, random shit). I like that the wonder flowers were like drugs. The final level was really good.

It has to be said though: this game is just another mario. Mario will always be mario... it's just the same game with more vibe, personality and style. This game is also missing any semblance of a good soundtrack.

games.name: Ghost Trick: Phantom Detective
review: This is such a charming game. It's absolutely OOZING with style. It's kooky, silly and over-dramatic, and I love it. It's a remake of a classic investigation game from the DS that came out on switch and I highly recommend it. Fans of Ace Attorney should be all over this.

games.name: Chants of Sennaar
review: This is a game perfect for fans of "Return of the Obra Dinn", languages and games with great vibes. It has an artstyle similar to that of "Sable", another game on the list that I want to play. It looks fantastic.

It's all about learning new languages! Everyone speaks using these glyphs which correspond neatly to concepts, objects and verbs. Learning vocabulary using puzzles is already really cool, but it also forces you to think about grammar to a small extent, which for me as a linguistics nerd was super fun (and easy!). It starts off pretty easy but then they introduce a second new language and shit starts getting real.
I highly recommend it!

games.name: F-Zero 99
review: Mate this game has the best music.

I'm just happy this game got some love this year and everyone played it for like a week. The F-Zero series is great and this was a great time.  It sucks that I could only ever end up playing on Mute City and Big Blue though.

games.name: Sea of Stars
review: I put 30 hours into this game. At some point when I realised this wasn't going to be the best video game ever I decided to enjoy my time with it by just vibing through it, which was easy because the vibes are so strong.

One thing I look for the most in games is a good vibe, which is often from a combination of characters, environments, colour palettes, art, dialogue and most importantly, music. Sea of stars has just such a great vibe. I really enjoy the character designs and the environments and the lighting especially. There's an ability that lets you change the time of day and it looks soooo good, I've never seen anything like it.
The music is also really good, I like the moorlands music a lot.

There's a few gameplay elements which make it not the best game ever. The battle system is a lot of fun, especially with the timed inputs and breaking of opponent's big moves, and I never groaned when I had a battle. However it doesn't have too much depth. It takes a long time before the characters learn any new attacks and when they do, they're never gamechanging. In fact I spent all the game using moonerang because it's simply the strongest attack. On top of that, one of the moves 'disorient' can really be abused to stop bosses ever doing their strong attack, which resulted in me missing all exciting animations from the final boss, which was a bit lame.
Next part has some light story spoilers...

The worst thing about this game though, is that the two main characters are plain and boring. They have no personality, they just go around winning battles and solving problems like boring heroes. How did they survive 10 years of isolation and training and then become perfectly well rounded heroes? The previous solstice warriors ended up not being well-rounded at all. The other characters are also pretty plain, with the exception of Resh'an, which was a genuine pleasant surprise. I appreciate that there was little dialogue, because it gave off those old fashioned SNES vibes, but it did mean that there was little to no character development. It's a shame because I like the designs.

When it comes to world building, I have a couple of questions. If we're dealing with multiple timelines and universes, why are we just focusing on two of them? How did we end up consistently going between these two specifically using the vast sea of stars? Considering the name of the game is sea of stars, the whole concept isn't very well explored. I mean we got this insane, super cool warp sequence there, but even though we traverse the sea multiple times, we never see that again.

One thing about the lore which I did enjoy were the stories told by Teaks. They're perfect fantasy fairytales which work really well with the minimal dialogue, set to nice music and revealed at points in the story when you haven't figured it out yourself yet.

In conclusion, this is a game which does have that X factor which is so rare in the wealth of video games we are bombarded with these days, but it has some things holding it back from being one of my favourites. I did push through all 30 hours though, which says something

games.name: The Legend of Zelda: Oracle of Ages
review: One of my video game ambitions is to complete every Zelda game! So when this was released on the Nintendo Switch online, I decided it was time. Having played Oracle of Seasons already when I was younger, I was ready to fucking enjoy the shit out of this. But I have to say it's not as good. There's a bit too much bullshit, and it's not well signposted. The seasons are cooler than the two timelines. It's also kinda hard.
If you're interested in the gameboy games, I would honestly just stick with Link's Awakening, one of the best games ever.

games.name: Death's Door
review: This was recommended to me by my friend Fab who said it would scratch the itch left behind by "Tunic" last year. However he did not understand that Tunic cannot be replaced thanks to its incredible "learning as you progress" mechanic. Nonetheless, this plays a lot like Tunic and has an alright vibe and music. One of the bosses is this old lady which is cool. But this game is lacking in heart and soul. It's a copy of this standard soulslike combat, with no new special mechanics or anything that sets it apart from other games.

games.name: Monster Train
review: Not in this list: Slay the Spire. I still love and am trying to get the elusive A20 Heart kills with characters that aren't watcher. At some point I was reminded that there are other games like Slay the Spire that I should try, so I tried Monster Train. I didn't really like it.

games.name: Vampire Survivors
review: God this game is like crack. Instantly addictive. I touched it and was sucked inside like a loser, there was nothing I could do. Once I sniffed the potential of the garlic item, and felt the excitement of ripping through endless hordes of enemies with it, I was hooked. By the end, my eyes were glazing over as I watched the screen flash very aggressively at me, the screen full of effects, enemies, GARLIC, destruction, wave after wave.
It's good.

games.name: Pokemon Trading Card Game
review: Mate. This game slaps. I never would have thought that the original Gameboy Colour version of the fucking Pokemon Trading Card Game would be so good. I'm pretty sure the actual card game is super unbalanced and bullshit, but these battles are a lot of fun. It's genuinely a pleasure to build decks and fight with them, and it's hard to describe why.

I immediately got attached to Staryu, because it can do 20 damage with one energy, and also happens to be one of my favourite pokemon. My water & rock deck took me through almost the whole game and I even felt proud of it.

The art of the pokemon is sooo good. I've already cross-stitched Horsea and Koffing from this game. And the music is super good for a gameboy game as well. It's on the switch online for free, so definitely play it!

games.name: Fire Emblem Engage
review: This game, man. It's just so camp! The theatrics of it... it definitely doesn't take itself seriously and is better off because of it. The story is about war and normal fire emblem stuff, but then the characters are just so ridiculous. Every chapter there is a new ridiculously dressed person who joins your party and you just have to take it as it is. It's actually really funny and entertaining because of that.

I'm a long time Fire Emblem fan, so I'm used to the gameplay and I enjoyed it! This time for the first time I played on casual mode (as opposed to classic mode, where you have permadeath) and it GREATLY improved my gameplay experience. I didn't have to reset when someone got hit with a critical hit! I should have used this option the whole time.
