To balance it out, I also played on hard mode, which made the game more fun, although I was resentful that my playtime extended very long because of it. Also a little bit of me is unsatisfied because I switched it to normal difficulty for the final boss... I just ran out of patience.

This game brings back 12 main characters from previous fire emblem games as the "emblems" which I thoroughly enjoyed. I am a total sucker for this kind of thing - references to older games, representation of different eras... I loved seeing Micaiah from Fire Emblem Radiant Dawn, or Eirika from Sacred Stones. So cool. I just wish the emblems actually had personalities. They are all boring as hell.
Anyway shoutouts to Goldmary who is that real bitch.

games.name: Pikmin 4
review: I love Pikmin with my whole heart. There's something special about it. The combination of the focus on nature, the soundtrack, the wacky characters, and the kinda dark elements combine to give it a certain X factor which is hard to pin down with words. When I think about whether games are good, they can get approval from me for a variety of reasons. Like Slay the spire is just great gameplay. But most of my favourite games just have great vibes.

The vibe of pikmin is so fucking strong that it's insane, and the gameplay is good enough that it's fun to spend time in the game soaking up the vibe. The first pikmin arguably had the worst gameplay but the strongest vibe. The time limit, as well as harshness of the environment, and some highlights like the first encounters with specific bosses. Lots of bullshit with pikmin killing themselves, general difficulty. It is a great time and might be my favourite pikmin.

The second pikmin game is a lot bigger and also has vibes in spades. The areas are super nice, music is fantastic (I love the piklopedia), and gameplay significantly improved with having two captains. The caves seemed pretty random though - like time stops when you're down there and then you've just got this ability to go back to the previous floor if you lose too many pikmin. I feel like it takes away from the general feeling of the game, and it's more like bonus content.

Pikmin 3 is super interesting. It's fucking gorgeous, has beautiful areas and possibly the best music of all. It also does away with the caves, and instead just has a really big overworld, which brings back that pikmin 1 vibe a lot. I never liked how the treasures were just fruits though, that seemed pointless. It also added mission mode, which was the best thing ever in terms of gameplay - these super fun little challenge modes. The final boss was also very special.

Now after 10 years we finally get Pikmin 4 and I have been excited for it, even more so than for Zelda. In terms of gameplay, everything is there. Quality of life changes to the max, meaning that pikmin actually do what they're told, all the pikmin content you could wish for. All the old bosses coming back, caves, hours of gameplay. I had a fun time collecting all the treasures and completing everything.

But something's off. The game feels like a huge collection of content being thrown in. More is more! The caves are more content, the dandori challenges (like pikmin 3 mission mode) are great but integrated into the game like extra content. They brought back the (terrifying in pikmin 2) waterwraith and it felt empty. It just dropped two of them in the final dungeon. Doing that really takes away the special vibe of that particular boss. I realised that in pikmin 4, vibe was sacrificed for more content, and that this is true for many games these days.

The quality of life changes & powered up rewind function makes it so it's very easy to get through the game without losing pikmin, so stakes are way lower now. I think I miss the chaos of the first two pikmins where one misstep can cause your whole squad to get flattened without warning. Electricity immediately killing them, the gatling groinks, yellows throwing bombs back at you. There's something delicious about that.

On top of that, the music isn't so great. The Olimar sidequest tracks are great, but otherwise it's gone a different direction: now it has ultra adaptive music (something the series is famous for and a big contributor to the X factor) but it's so adaptive to the point it's barely recognisable. There are multiple layers which fade in and out depending on what enemy you're fighting, what you're carrying etc. Nothing you can hum.

They also retconned the lore, and it was "all a dream" or something. They had Louie be the bad guy but then cleared things up after, and there were no open questions left like in Pikmin 2. There was no weird shit like the Pikmin 3 final boss. And final complaint: I wish they integrated the night time/glow pikmin sections better.

But to end on a positive, I really loved getting platinum medals in the dandori challenges, and those final ones were tough as nails. I still loved this game. I even painted a picture of Oatchi for my living room!

games.name: Super Mario RPG
review: This game is delightful! I've always been meaning to play it so I was super happy to see it remade on the switch. The whole thing is very quaint. I love the chibi characters, and I adore Mallow. Geno is by comparison very boring - I'm asking myself why so many people wanted him in Smash.

I will say the game got a little boring and also easy. It's not exactly gripping, and the battles are only a little bit fun. If you play it, I would do it for the vibe and the chill ride, and for the history. Personally I love to play classic games and learn how lots of old Nintendo stuff came to be. For example, this game is where Bowser's personality was first defined!

games.name: Pentiment
review: This is a historically accurate visual novel about the middle ages. I picked it up because my friend Colin recommended it and I saw that one of my favourite artists (Lingua Ignota) sang a song on the soundtrack. The fact is, I'm not interested enough in history to get me through this slow-paced game. I gave up after the first major event happened and it became clear where the game was going.

games.name: Street Fighter 6
review: I really enjoyed playing this game with friends this summer. I love the character designs, and enjoyed learning the special inputs for Chun-Li's moves. The single player mode is funny! It also has a fantastic vibe and soundtrack.
Sadly I don't have time for a second competitive game next to smash, so I only played it for a short while. I would like to return to it.

games.name: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom
review: Playing this game felt a lot like playing Breath of the Wild back in 2017, although it has to be said: nothing can truly recreate that feeling of magic we all felt back then. It's undeniably a better game, but some of that magic is gone the second time around. It's super interesting because it's forcing me to reflect on why I enjoyed playing BotW more, despite it being emptier and more annoying. How we enjoy games really depends on so many things, not just the game itself. In this case, it was because there really wasn't anything like it before.

Anyway here we are in 2023 playing Zelda again and it's a lot of fun. The new abilities are nice. I was actually in it for the new content, music, areas and surprises though. There was a lot to enjoy, but it really does rely on existing content a bit too much. I wish exploring Hyrule wasn't so similar to how it was before.

I really loved some of the new stuff though. The new temples, great! Especially that gorgeous Lightning Temple music, hell yes. Getting from A to B using a ratchet flying machine, great. First time falling into a chasm? Terrifying. This gorgeous version of Lookout Landing after you meet all the sages.

games.name: Pizza Tower
review: This game is amazing. Start by listening to the <a href="https://youtu.be/GHooySzFkHI?feature=shared">soundtrack<a>.
The VIBES are off the CHARTS. They really made a game that looks like it was made in Microsoft Paint? Iconic. The music has no business being this good for such a goofy looking game.

There are so many fun ideas and fun levels, and it really makes you want to play the game well. You can't die in the levels, but you WANT a good score. Going back and redoing levels for a higher score is a lot of fun. The game is based off of Wario Land 4, which happens to be one of my favourite games from my childhood. They took that concept and fucking ran with it. This spiritual successor surpasses the classic!

games.name: Kirby's Return to Dreamland Deluxe
review: A delightful game! I missed out on it when it came out on the Wii, despite adoring Nightmare in Dreamland and Amazing Mirror. It's great, and this remake looks real nice. I love the outlines on the characters. It's short, doesn't overstay its welcome and features some fun minigames.

games.name: Hifi Rush
review: I can't describe why this game didn't click with me. On paper, it looks great. I love rhythm games, and it seems innovative and funny. Looks like it was made with love. But I just wasn't enjoying it. I guess it's not my humour. And in my 2 or so hours with the game, the battle system didn't click with me.
It kinda felt like I was playing some Content made by a Content Creator. I can almost picture the dev studio putting in all the elements to make a game which is enjoyed by the masses.

games.name: Citizen Sleeper
review: This is a small scale management game (and I play one management game a year for some reason) with a great vibe and setting. I really enjoyed the story and characters, and enjoyed how I could choose what happens to me. Multiple endings, lots of exciting stuff that happens, it's a great little game!

games.name: The Looker
review: This game is made as an homage to another fantastic game "The Witness". If you loved that like me, play this! It's made by someone else but in the same style. It parodies the Witness in a really smart way. It's nice and short, and free!

games.name: Norco
review: This is a moody point and click adventure which I really enjoyed. It was all about the imagery which was cool. Some nonsense supernatural stuff in there too.

games.name: It Takes Two
review: In theory an excellent game for you and your partner! I would even recommend it to guys who are trying to get their girlfriends into games. But I dunno it's just so lame. The characters and story are so plain, no amount of fun co-op game ideas will get me interested. What I really want is a co-op game for hardcore gamers which has a real story.

games.name: Neon White
review: This game's story and characters are soooooo lame it's hard to describe. Like it's not even funny or enjoyable despite being bad like some of the games lower down on this list. And the general vibe isn't very attractive I have to say.
But it's super addictive. I really enjoyed playing it with my friend Fab and replaying the levels over and over. Deeply satisfying.

games.name: Stray
review: I played this together with my friend Fab - this is a great game to share with someone else. The premise is so good. You go around as a cat and it's awesome. You can take naps, scratch at furniture, it's really fantastic.
I really like the track that plays at the beginning of the game.

They put the cat in a crazy world with a crazy story, and you have to solve puzzles and have an understanding of your surroundings in a way that no cat ever could. The only explanation: you are a human trapped in the body of a cat! But that's never confirmed or denied. In fact, the game suggests you're just an insanely smart cat.
I found myself thinking to myself that a cat game doesn't need to go this hard. It's a bit much. But I enjoyed it a lot.

games.name: Sports Story
review: This game is straight up unfinished. It's almost embarrassing! It's a technical mess. Golf Story was such a banger with such clean gameplay, so what went wrong? Why does golf have fewer features and why is the whole thing so glitchy and unpolished? I feel bad for the studio because they clearly bit off more than they could chew with this game. It's probably enough to prevent them from making new games in the future. Pretty sad.

games.name: Pac-Man World: Re-Pac
review: Oh boy, this is a genuinely bad game. It didn't age very well. For some reason I completed it... it's that part of me that wants to play all the games of smash characters. By the end I was incredulous that a) it was real and b) I was still playing it.
Tragically, this game had a lot of influence on Pac-man's design in Smash. It's incredible that they actually remade this game.

games.name: Castlevania: Symphony of the Night
review: Went back and played one of the classics and boy do I love it. This year I also played some more Castlevania but this is far and away the best one. It's so fun and I love the 18th Century setting.

The music is amazing! How many metroidvanias have you played with actual classical music in it? And has any game ever nailed this dramatic, classy vibe like this before? Those character portraits are insane! I can only imagine how hype it must have been back then when you realise you don't play as Richter, but instead an actual vampire Alucard? So sick. Even the way he moves is just so cool. The whole game is so cool.

games.name: Scarlet Nexus
review: I was jamming to this OST for months before I decided to give the game a spin. It's pretty middle of the road in terms of gameplay, especially for me as I'm not a hack & slash fan. But I love games with good vibes and this one has a great vibe and I enjoyed it. I liked the design of the main characters and had a crush on the guy.

games.name: Castlevania: Rondo of Blood
review: I wanna play all the games from all the smash characters so I had to play Richter's game. I had to get a separate collection on playstation for this one, which is fine except that this one doesn't come with save states, so I actually got straight up stuck against Death. I couldn't beat him so I gave up.

games.name: Slice & Dice
review: It's a mobile game! Yep. Worth it. It's a super well designed little dice-based roguelike, and I got really into it this year. You can just jump in and play for a little bit at a time, and it scratches that Slay the Spire itch.
I didn't get the achievement where you have to win like two ultra-hard runs in a row. That is actually impossible and I was annoyed that I couldn't neatly complete the game 100%.

games.name: Wandersong
review: It's a game about singing but it was really boring! I thought you couldn't really go wrong if your premise was to sing to solve puzzles but yep, I switched off pretty quickly.

games.name: Castlevania
review: Decided to take the time to save-scum my way through the OG Castlevania in honour of the OG Simon Belmont. Even harder than the other one but had to do it for my education. I don't recommend this game.

games.name: Super Castlevania 4
review: It's my goal to complete the games that all the smash characters are from and to that end I got the Castlevania collection on switch. This game is great but it's hard as balls. I was only able to complete it because I used save states.
It's nice to see some castlevania classics here, but it's not even a metroidvania, rather just a series of hard-as-nails platforming challenges. Music is great though.

games.name: Everhood
review: This is a banger game. It's a rhythm game (always love a rhythm game) with a story & vibe which is undeniably similar to Undertale. If you're craving that kind of wacky, dark story along with very imaginative design and a cracking soundtrack, I highly recommend it.
Some of the later challenges are actually impossible but I guess you have to leave something for the tryhards.

games.name: LISA: The Painful
review: I'm sure this game is good... but it just has such a horrible vibe. It's miserable and it was upsetting me too much. I admit I didn't get very far into the game but I already knew that this would be nothing for me.

games.name: Rain World
review: This is a survival game with some of the craziest enemy AI I've ever seen. There is this whole ecosystem of creatures that have their own lives. You really feel like prey in a world of predators. Like the enemies are never in the same place when you respawn you have to be constantly alert.

I recognise that this is a good game. However, I found it so fucking terrifying that I had to stop playing. The monsters were so scary and sometimes it would start raining and jesus christ. The rain, and those horrible birds that pick you off, it's just all very upsetting and I decided to stop.
If you are strong, you can play this and join the chorus of people who say it's amazing.

games.name: Tunic
review: Similar to my favourite game the last two years, Outer Wilds, in this game you progress by gathering more knowledge as you play. It's so good, guys. It's such a satisfying game. I'm still thinking about it months later, it's my favourite game this year for sure

You play as a cute little fox and you have to figure out what on earth you're meant to be doing by discovering little clues as you go. It's got so many moments where you slap your knee and go 'ooooohhhhh! That's what that's for!'. And it keep escalating and escalating.
The soundtrack is also perfect. An electronic vibe, almost like you're playing inside a simulation. I listen to the soundtrack on the regular it's that good.

games.name: Kirby's Dream Buffet
review: It was a fun time playing this online with friends! However it doesn't have too much depth as a game and we only played it once.

games.name: Elechead
review: This is a super fun 3 hour platforming experience. It's a super tight, well designed little package of fun. Each puzzle makes you feel like a superstar for beating it, it's so satisfying. Give it a try!

games.name: Omori
review: This game was made with love. It's a story about being a recluse. It's very beautiful and the general vibe of the game with its presentation and music is top-notch. It's got that Earthbound energy which I always subscribe to. It's totally worth your time.
There's a battle system with emotions, a pleasant combination of pixel art and hand-drawn aesthetics, a fun soundtrack, and an upsetting ending. What more could you want?

games.name: Xenoblade Chronicles 3
review: I gave up this game during chapter 4! I feel bad about it because I made it through Xenoblade 2 when it first came out and genuinely enjoyed it, and thought that Xenoblade 1 was super good. But this one is just so MUCH! There are 6 characters all screaming out their catchphrases constantly, and there's so much going on that I can't concentrate. Sometimes I start a fight and have to put the switch down because it's all too much.

I have tried two times to resume the game because I'm told chapter 5 is really good, but it's really hard to get back into it again, because I can't remember any of the systems. And those characters are just all so loud. I do kinda like the characters this time round though, especially Eunie, who is a total babe.

Also is it just me or are the environments not as amazing as the first two games? Maybe I haven't figured out what's going on with the land (there's normally a big overarching explanation for this stuff) but where is wow-factor that I got from the Kingdom of Uraya? Or Satorl Marsh? Hmm maybe I should try to start playing again. I think would have to do it together with a Xenoblade fan who can help me. I think I'm stuck on a difficult boss fight. Maybe I should reduce the difficulty.

games.name: Mario Strikers: Battle League
review: A great party game when you have the full 8 players. We had a great time with it and the animations for the characters are fun. However there isn't much meat on the bones. I don't think it's worth buying, it wouldn't be fun on your own, but maybe I'm just bitter because I'm not a football fan.

games.name: Gorogoa
review: This is a little puzzle game that you can breeze through in one sitting. It's good!

games.name: Downfall: A Slay the Spire Fan Expansion
review: I couldn't get enough of the main game so I tried this very well established mod which was deemed to be THE mod for slay the spire and yes it is good, but it's totally unbalanced. I played through all the characters once then went back to base game

games.name: Persona 5: Royal
review: This game so fucking long. Jesus Christ. It doesn't need to be this long. For some reason I completed all of this one. It was a great game for the first 40 hours or so but my dumbass finished all 100 hours out of pure spite. When I finally beat a literal God and then had to do the 'royal' content I was so pissed. I was like, it's not over???

I will say that the vibes are immaculate, the soundtrack is class, 'Last Surprise' never gets old somehow, and Kasumi is cute. I don't normally do the anime stuff normally but I did enjoy all the nonsense. Akechi and Joker's moments together were so gay. And at one point they go to Hawaii which is hilarious.

games.name: Elden Ring
review: I gave this game, a very different kind of game for me, a good go! I recognise that it's amazing, not least because of the amazing vibe. The first area looks so stunning with the cloudy stormy sky over the lit-up landscape, and the magical elements of the huge golden trees. This world was created with a vision and I appreciate that.

But the game has multiple barriers of entry. There's Margit, who I of course had no chance against. Luckily, a friend told me about a quest I should do somewhere near the beginning, and that was great because I got a +8 spear out of it, which made me super powerful. I also enjoyed using the spear at a weapon. I used that spear to get me through Margit and also two other big bosses.

Rennala was a huge struggle, even though the vibes of her magic academy and boss fight in general were immaculate, because the +8 spear was no longer enough to carry me through the game. I managed to finally beat her and I did feel that sense of accomplishment that Dark Souls fans don't shut up about, but when I realised that I need to learn how to either upgrade the spear or start with another weapon, and also when I realised that I invested my levelled up stats all wrong, I lost interest.

The second barrier of entry is learning the stats and mechanics of the game, and that shit is not well communicated in the game. I feel like you need to have the implicit knowledge from previous FromSoft games or a friend to teach you this stuff. Or you spend ages reading the wiki, which for me a red flag when it comes to video games.
So sorry, Elden Ring fans, I didn't get into it. But I you can't tell me I didn't try, I mean I beat Rennala.

games.name: Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020
review: I can't remember when I played this but it was at Fab's place because he had just bought the Series X. I really enjoyed it! Because Google Earth is great. We flew over my street in Friedrichshain! The game is really for fans of planes, which I'm not. But for everyone else it's still fun to fly around different places.

games.name: Kirby and the Forgotten Land
review: This is a great kirby game! Perfect for playing with your partner. Co-op kirby is such a pleasure. It's very cute!

I'm impressed that they came up with the name Mouthful Mode and just made a kirby game out of it. OK I guess it's actually just more of the same Kirby as we know. One thing I appreciate about Kirby games is how it's all happy slappy until the final boss, which is consistently some kind of world-devouring cosmic horror. This game definitely doesn't disappoint in that regard.

games.name: Boomerang Fu
review: A super fun party game on switch to enjoy with your friends and family. It's got similar vibes to Towerfall, which is great. It's not the best or anything but still worth your time and money for sure. It will entertain a group for an hour or so!

games.name: Spiritfarer
review: I do enjoy a peaceful game with good vibes only and this is that. I didn't see it through to the end however because the gameplay loop didn't hook me in. It looks great though. You can fish off the end of the boat and just doing that is the highlight of the game.

games.name: Loop Hero
review: I picked it up because it looked innovating and new. But it's almost like they didn't think their loop concept through enough! It felt unbalanced and pointless. Why is there even a loop?

games.name: Unpacking
review: Do not play this game. It's literally just work. You pay money for a "game" where you have to unpack things from boxes. Who actually enjoys doing that. This isn't how you tell a story. Don't buy it.

games.name: Inscryption
review: As a lover of Slay the Spire, I was drawn to this story-driven card game. Yes it's creepy, but let me tell you it's worth your time. Don't read too much about it, just go in and enjoy all the twists the story has to offer - it's actually not as terrifying as it looks, and the game has SO MUCH to offer.

games.name: Chicory: A Colorful Tale
review: I came because I'm a massive Lena Raine fan and she did the soundtrack. The game is surprisingly good for a painting game! All the characters are named after food items and I named myself Aubergine which I thoroughly enjoyed the whole game.
There were some cheesy nonsense moments, but the vibe was consistently good the whole time. I do recommend it!

games.name: Pokemon Legends: Arceus
review: I hate to be that bitch but I couldn't enjoy this game because the graphics were so bad. And I resented how the pokemon would sit around in groups and do nothing. It was better in pokemon snap when they actually did stuff. As usual, this Switch Pokemon game would have been better if they spent more time making it. So much wasted potential!
I support them trying new things but can't they just wait 3 years between releases so they can actually release a good game which actually has some vibes.

games.name: Paradise Killer
review: Alright I'll straight up say that this game isn't a GOOD game per se... but I still rank it high because I love the vibe, the look, the music. If you don't have time to play this visual novel, I forgive you, but do take the time to listen to the soundtrack. Both the OST and the 'B-Sides' are great and available on the streaming service of your choice.
I was kinda annoyed about the ending. I have an opinion about how it should have gone down and I want to talk about it but I need at least one other friend to have played this so I can discuss.

games.name: Psychonauts 2
review: Playing this game reminded me of games which feel like I've paid for some content and am now receiving that content. I made it through to the end but it didn't make me feel much. Maybe I would have enjoyed it more if I were a child. I think I liked the first one because I was younger when I played it.

games.name: Valheim
review: I had the pleasure of sharing a Valheim server with my friend Falco and his buddies. My little computer didn't have the strength to properly compute this game but I still enjoyed building a little house and riding the boat with some cool dudes. I know that this isn't my thing really but it reminded me that playing online games co-op with friends is just a lot of fun.

games.name: Disco Elysium
review: It's a slow burner, but I have to admit that it's one of the very best stories/writing I've ever seen in a game.

The setting? An under-funded town in some empire where everything reeks of sleaze. You are a detective who has a terrible reputation and a drinking problem. You start the game by apologising after you crashed your police car. Luckily, an actual capable detective comes to be your partner, Kim Kitsuragi. He is such a babe and I would die for him.

The game is really great for forcing you to look at things with another perspective. Like when you get asked about your politic views, you get absolutely lambasted for being a centrist, it's very eye-opening. The things you'll end up doing in this game are crazy. Somehow the game made me think giving drugs to a child would be a good idea.
My tip is to not play the switch port, because the loading times are insanely long.

games.name: Fire Emblem: The Binding Blade
review: In my quest to complete all the games of all the smash characters, I had to tackle this obscure fan translation of FE6. Not gonna lie it's shit game and not nearly as good as FE7.

In the end, I didn't complete it. I got halfway through, but I was playing on an emulator and when I changed my phone I accidentally corrupted my save file. I really don't want to start it again because it's quite long and not very fulfilling. I decided that being FE7 is enough for the challenge because it features Roy as a baby boy at the end. Maybe I don't need to force myself to play bad games just for this random challenge I want to do.

games.name: Frostpunk
review: I average one new management sim game each year and this time I played this winter-themed survival game. This was good and addicting! I really enjoyed how it was about just crisis after crisis and trying to just make it through. The main storyline has the temperature drop and drop until there in an insane storm. The relief when you make it through to the other end is amazing!

games.name: Ring Fit Adventure
review: Borrowed this from a friend when I was losing motivation for those lockdown home workouts. It's great! I love the vibe of Wii Fit and this takes it further. The ring itself is pretty good, the overhead squeeze exercise is so hard.

It's not nearly as good as an actual trip to the gym, but it'll do if there's another pandemic. It's also insanely long, and despite genuinely doing loads of workouts with it, I only got through half of the worlds.

games.name: Pokemon: Brilliant Diamond
review: Nostalgia fueled my playthrough. Otherwise, I have to say it's a bad game! Why no platinum dex? Was pokemon always this easy? The most fun I had was using Metronome with my Clefairy.
I will say that in this team I had a Lickilicky, and it's when I got my strange obsession with that Pokemon. It's just so ugly!
Overall this game is a huge disappointment, because the original is so special and this is a soulless version of it. Talk about games not being made with love.

games.name: Outer Wilds: Echoes of the Eye
review: My favourite game this year was a DLC. Outer Wilds was already insanely mind-bending and amazing, and this DLC totally matches it. This is equally as good as the main game!
I implore all my followers to play this game and to do it blind. It's fascinating and terrifying, and unlike anything else you've played.

The vibe is a little more horror than the base game. 'A little more horror' I say, I was the one with my heart BEATING playing through those certain sections. I was genuinely breathless, terrified. When I thought about the game while I was at work, I would get scared thinking about it! It took so much emotional strength to get through the Starlit Cove. After writing that sentence I went and looked at someone play through Starlit Cove and I got scared again!! It's a terrifying game!!

games.name: Metroid: Dread
review: A terrifying and excellent game. The feeling when you have to go into another killer robot zone 😱. I am very weak when it comes to horror, and video game horror is just a next level for me because you have to actually escape!
Luckily, the is much more than that, it's also a huge vibe. Samus is so badass it hurts, and the planet looks so good. There's a great twist half way through for Metroid fans.

games.name: New Pokemon Snap
review: The gameplay of this game is alright, although I got frustrated from having to replay the same courses over and over again. It also has that "generic" nintendo pokemon polish which takes away the soul in this case.

I'm disappointed about the graphics, honestly, and even though they put more energy into it than your average pokemon game, it still kinda looks shit. For a photography game that is no longer on the N64, I want some next level graphics.

games.name: Captain Toad: Treasure Tracker
review: This game is great for a while, but it didn't take me too long to realise that puzzles of these kind can only have so much depth. Finding the solution is always easy when the scope is so small. I think the game overstayed its welcome a little.

games.name: Eastward
review: The presentation is 10/10, but it's trying way too hard to be Mother 3. The writing isn't good enough. Each cutscene leads me not understanding what's going on, despite pressing A through tons of dialogue. Lots of missed opportunities in the story. I was quite disappointed and overwhelmed. I was happy when it was over.

games.name: Deltarune: Chapter 2
review: Toby Fox blew it out of the water again. This only takes 3 hours or so to complete and it was such a lovely time. It has that same dark vibe to it as undertale and the first deltarune, and it also manages to bring new ideas. Particularly impactful is the focus on the controlling relationship in the Snowgrave route.
Plus the soundtrack, of course. I love "A CYBER'S WORLD" so much.

games.name: WarioWare: Get It Together!
review: This series will always have a special place in my heart. I love the very specific Wario humour. It's just got so many toilet jokes and I love it. Also it's the most fun to play in the series by far. I really enjoyed the mechanic with the playing with characters, I think it worked amazingly.

games.name: Horizon: Zero Dawn
review: A BEAUTIFUL and gorgeous-looking game. At first I was put off by it, also because I was scared of the dinosaurs, but I came back to it later and completed it. The story is really nice, although it's got this triple A video game sheen all over it which I don't like. It feels like I'm playing a video game, not that I'm actually a hunter warrior lady who shoots arrows at robot dinosaurs.

games.name: Bug Fables
review: This game has some heart, which I appreciate, but I just found it quite boring. It tries to be Paper Mario a little too much, and doesn't really make its own "bug fables" identity. I wish it just had that special X factor which elevates some games over the rest. I don't even have specific feedback I just didn't vibe with it I guess.

games.name: Subnautica
review: Imagine you crash land on a planet covered in water and the only thing there is the massive spaceship you came on, crashlanded really far away. It's a strong image! After putting out the initial fire in your escape pod, you need to somehow survive on an underwater alien planet! It's so cool!

I was really blown away by this game. The fish and the plants all look so cool. You're lucky to start in a shallow area, with the land almost poking out of the water to form an island but not quite. After you explore the immediate area, you have to go to deeper waters and let me tell you, diving deeper is fucking terrifying! Never have I felt the true terrifying power of big open spaces, deep black water beneath you, losing sight of the light hitting the surface. It's fucking terrifying.
Then there's actually a whole story to the game that you slowly uncover as you explore more. It's so fascinating and cool. I loved this game so much.

games.name: Abzu
review: I'm normally not into arty farty games, but I love fish and sea life so this one was great. The perfect chill out game. Soundtrack has Ecco the Dolphin vibes. Great to smoke weed to.

games.name: Bugsnax
review: First game I played on my new playstation. Unashamed to admit I played it because my favourite band (Kero Kero Bonito) did the theme song. I like the vibe and the game and characters are pretty cute. I do think it's all a bit forced though. I reckon the game could have benefitted from being more fucked up.

games.name: Astro's Playroom
review: Sure it's nice gameplay but it's a tech demo meant to advertise the console. Not great vibes.

games.name: A Short Hike
review: I loved this. It looks like a DS game!? So good. Love the soundtrack. Love the animal crossing/BOTW vibes. I would complain it's too short but it's literally called a Short Hike. I've replayed it like three times it's that good.

games.name: Inside
review: Hard to describe what this game is but I enjoyed it a lot. A very dark and düster vibe as you make your way through some horrible factory. One of those games that makes you feel something. The ending is really cool.

games.name: Reigns: Kings & Queens
review: This is just a mobile game really. It didn't draw me in at all.

games.name: Fez
review: A really cool puzzle game that I got totally into. I love puzzle games. And especially when they have so many layers like this one. This totally defined a genre of ultra hard indie puzzle games.
The soundtrack is by Disasterpeace who also did Hyper Light Drifter, and it's both harsh and peaceful. A great vibe all around.

games.name: Xenoblade Chronicles 2: Torna The Golden Country
review: Having enjoyed XB1, and with Pyra & Mythra coming to smash, I decided to come back to this DLC but I just couldn't get through it. The characters in XB2 are so badly designed it hurts. The writing is also bad. And they changed the battle system so I have to learn even more random things. And this one boss was randomly super difficult so I changed the difficulty to easy which made it really boring. A real struggle, this game.

games.name: Xenoblade Chronicles: Definitive Edition
review: As part of my Nintendo education, this was definitely necessary! I really enjoyed my time with the game, and it has the best locations and setting ever. The whole things takes place on the body of a massive monster that became a bit statue. All sorts of shit happens, including a lot of nonsense.
It was really long and I do wish it wasn't that long. But I was engaged enough to keep going all the way to the end.

games.name: Super Mario 3D World + Bowser's Fury
review: The base game is such a good party game with the right group. I played it online with some old friends and it was awesome. I remember enjoying the original with friends in much the same way back then and this was such as great.
Bowser's Fury was a short but really fun romp!

games.name: Rocket League
review: A lockdown party game with old friends. It's a lot of fun and honestly can totally recommend if you want to reconnect with specifically two other friends by playing online.
Definitely not a fan of the micro-transactions and monetisation. Fuck that shit.

games.name: Diablo 3
review: What the fuck is this piece of shit game? You just go around and click mindlessly. No vibes no strategy I simply don't understand.

games.name: Axiom Verge
review: A small, clean, indie metroidvania. Really enjoyed it. I was just super impressed with some of the really clever upgrades you can get. Been meaning to play the second one too.

games.name: Factorio
review: BEWARE this game. It's extremely addicting, and for what? Endless progress. Seriously this game has no end. I played multiplayer with 3 friends and we're gone for 8 hours at a time. It's actually kind of miserable.

Once I replayed it on my own to make an ultra efficient factory and I realised that it's just fucking work. It's just programming. Optimising algorithms and refactoring old code. Dealing with bugs (literally). It's just like my job as a programmer. When I realised that I promised myself to stop forever. I will not touch the DLC.

games.name: Slay the Spire
review: The first time I played this it didn't managed to get its hooks and claws into me. But I kept coming back. Why? Because this is one of the best games in the world!!!

I may have started playing in 2020, but I got so fucking into this in the 5 years after as well. It started by climbing the ascensions, then getting all the achievements, then just when I thought I was done, I set myself the challenge of beating the heart on A20 with all characters.

I managed to do it first try with the Watcher because well it's the Watcher. At that point I stopped playing her entirely because of the infinite, but the other three are all beautiful and perfect. I got Ironclad with a dead branch corruption deck of course, eventually managed to get Silent through with a poison deck, and then spent ages just grinding Defect until I finally got it in 2024. Around then, Balatro entered my life so I was able to say goodbye and officially start waiting for the second game.

games.name: Pikmin 3 Deluxe
review: I love the Pikmin series with all my heart so you KNOW I was double dipping for this one. This game looks amazing! I love the areas, the music, the bosses, the enemies, and even the characters. I love the super detailed models of the fruit, although it's a bit silly that there's just all this fresh fruit lying around, and no treasures like before.
This deluxe edition came with some extra content but I don't think it was very good. In the end I just got this to replay the Wii U game which I loved and actually felt nostalgia for.

games.name: Hades
review: I rode the Hades wave in the autumn and I loved it. This game has such a good presentation and is so accessible. Hard not to recommend this to anyone. Can't stand the Americans putting on British accents though what were they thinking.

games.name: Death Stranding
review: I just wanted to give it a try because I'd heard so much yet knew so little about it... What kind of vibe was this? The vibe was terrifying. It's like a scary, horror, dystopia vibe and they honestly nail it. You just have to walk around making deliveries in this horrible place where at any moment you could get attacked by the most terrifying monsters ever. They are literally invisible, and when they find you the whole world turns into a sea of black goop, it's terrifying.
I played about 15 hours but this game is not for the faint of heart like me. I was so terrified of those monsters that I couldn't play anymore.

games.name: CrossCode
review: What a gorgeous action RPG! What I thought would be a 10 hour indie game ended up being one of the most compelling stories and settings I've ever seen. And that Soundtrack! And it was made in Germany!

This RPG is so fun! The battling is super fun and the story is wild. The music is great and I have come back to this OST a lot. I kinda regret the non-ending, it feels like it was a bit unfinished. Then when the free DLC came it felt tacked on.

games.name: Journey
review: I blasted through this in an evening and it was alright. Again it's just soaked in imagery, but not actually making a point or leaving me with anything. Connecting with another player at one point was a nice touch. But I just don't vibe with these arty games at all.

games.name: Outer Wilds
review: I still think about this game. It was so much fun to explore this handcrafted solar system (!) while reading lore and dying in new and fantastic ways. If there was one game I wish I could play blind again it's this. I can't write too much about it here because the more you know about it, the more you ruin the experience of playing it for the first time.
So take my word for it, stop what you're doing and boot up Outer Wilds. It'll be a fun, emotional and at times scary ride. If you don't understand what's going on in the first hours, keep trying!

games.name: Unravel 2
review: Man this game is utter trash... combines the "beautiful for the sake of being beautiful" trope with bad gameplay. We couldn't stop ridiculing the game as we played it. There are better co-op games out there but this got me even thinking if co-op games are even worth it man.

games.name: Horace
review: I've been playing this surprisingly deep (& very cheap) indie game. It's littered with references to pop culture and is very British, but I must be in the narrow target audience because I'm enjoying it. It is way too long though and I straight up don't recommend it!

games.name: Super Mario 3D All-Stars
review: This game was a rip-off but I'm a nintendo slut and bought it anyway and really enjoyed playing all three games, although I was mainly just reminded of how good Odyssey is.
It consists of Mario 64, Sunshine and Galaxy. All classics. But it's pretty scandalous that they took it off the eshop and had it as like a limited game only. I hope they never do that again.

games.name: A Way Out
review: This is a silly co-op game about escaping prison that I enjoyed playing in the summer. There are absolutely no stakes, so failure doesn't mean anything. I guess it's more of a visual novel. It's gimmick is that it's co-op but I don't think it's actually that good. The story is pretty trope-y.

games.name: Katamari Damacy: Reroll
review: A crazy japanese game about rolling up junk into a ball. I like the big dude who tells you to do stuff in the game. The music is also great. Truly one-of-a-kind. But apart from that I was snoozing, and the gameplay kinda feels like work.

games.name: Paper Mario: The Origami King
review: As a fan of the originals I had some high hopes, but I was reminded that this game truly is for kids. I beat the game but I've probably outgrown it. I didn't love the battle system so it was at times a bit of a slog.

But the vibe of the game is fab. It's got some hilarious writing, and I love the music so much. This video helped me realised how fucking great the soundtrack is. I didn't realise! These covers are so good and the team at Intelligent Systems who do music just go so fucking hard every game they do. They are amazing.

games.name: The Last of Us
review: I recognise that this is a great game but as someone who doesn't do well with either violence or suffering, I found it very upsetting. I did beat it though!

games.name: Dark Souls
review: For my own education I gave the original game a try but man this game is not for me. I need some colours and some recognisable characters. I didn't want to walk all the way back to the boss room each time I died. I didn't make it past this monster on the bridge.

games.name: Final Fantasy: VII: Remake
review: After playing the original, I also figured why not play the remake too. I can totally see how people think it's amazing, especially if they've played the original, but the writing was really bad so I couldn't take it very seriously. It was also very jarring to have a lot of the cartoon elements of the original in HD. I think the vibe is missing on this game quite a bit.
I liked the remixed music tracks a lot, and I enjoyed playing as Barret. It felt a bit cheap to only play a third of the story of the original though.

games.name: Towerfall
review: I started playing this kick-ass indie fighter with my friends this summer and it's hilarious. Super good party game now that I'm too good at smash to play that with my friends. I find that it's really accessible and everyone can get into it, even if you're bad at video games. I'm also intrigued by all this unlocking I've been inadvertently doing.

games.name: Shadow of the Colossus
review: I really tried with this game, I promise. But the empty walks to the titans, and then the weird formulaic way of defeating them?? Like each one has a little puzzle "how do I get on it" and then you're set. Couldn't finish it.

But I respect that it has an excellent vibe. The emptiness and the sadness behind killing these beasts is very profound, and the steady descent into corruption is a really nice idea. I went back and watched someone else complete the game which was quite nice.

games.name: Ori and the Blind Forest
review: This is the first of the games on this list that I describe as "beautiful for the sake of being beautiful". They really put all their eggs into that basket. It looks alright, but I found myself being resentful at how much it was showing with its lovely lighting. So petty, I know.

games.name: NieR: Automata
review: Really enjoyed the aesthetic in this game. Everything looked so beautiful. The story was dramatic, the worldbuilding great, the characters great, the ending(s) cool. Music is fantastic!
Small things irritated me like you walk a bit and suddenly the forest turns into a desert.. And they make you look at 2B's ass the whole game which for me was a bit much.

games.name: Streets of Rage 4
review: Oh hell yeah this game is so fucking good. It's so much fun and such a cool game and the MUSIC! It's inspired by classic house music and goes so hard. The original SoR also had insane music and this successor totally channels the vibe perfectly.

It has such an amazing style. Beating up cops in the city, supernatural nonsense, throwing crowbars at people in the streets, eating floor turkeys. It's got everything. I played it a whole bunch and got really good with Floyd of all characters. Normally I do not vibe with heavy characters but we just connected!

games.name: One Step From Eden
review: This is a really cool indie title which has the same deckbuilding element as Slay the Spire, but it's an action game. I came for the music and I stayed for... the music. The soundtrack is such a bop! It's this maximalist, over the top music by an artist I really like called STEEL_PLUS.

games.name: Gris
review: Tbh I would buy prints of some screenshots of the later parts of this game and hang them in my apartment. But I find these kinds of games a little over the top. I guess they're meant to be emotional and to make you feel something but I just felt resentful.

games.name: The Witness
review: An environmental puzzle game on the PlayStation 4 which I got really into. The puzzles are always difficult but never impossible and the game comes with a cool message too. I just love puzzle games like this, and this was a bit different to usual because it was in 3D! So many angles to look at the puzzles.

games.name: Animal Crossing: New Horizons
review: This game is food for the soul. It will calm you down when you are feeling stressed and be there for you in hard times. I've loved this game since wild world so this new version was a dream come true.
I spent a year in this game, making the most perfect and beautiful island. I loved visiting other islands of friends during the pandemic and I loved making art in the game.

I do with the villagers were a little feistier and/or a bit more interesting. I remember the villagers saying the wildest things in older games... but it's fine because there's so much other stuff in there to make up for it.

Like the soundtrack! This time round we have a pretty upbeat set of hourly themes to enjoy. At first I was anti because there's too much peppy synth but I've come to love it. It's different but also the same. And with the 2.0 update there are a whole bunch of new KK Slider tracks, and I happen to love KK Slider tracks. I even made a ranking of them here.

games.name: God of War
review: 2020 is the year that I learned that I don't like hack and slash games. I wanted to see Kratos's character development, but the game was too boring to get far enough. Also he's a ridiculous character. I was told I should at least up until a strong female character shows up. She did and I was like, finally I can stop.

games.name: Pokemon Mystery Dungeon: Rescue Team DX
review: I loved this game as a child and this version of it is just the same but better! I love the new art style and the remixed music. Just great.

games.name: Final Fantasy VII
review: In January I played the OG FF7 and had a blast. It was slow but I pulled through, for cultural reasons. It's an amazing story and I wish I had played it as a child.

These cute little blocky fellows navigate a complex world where there was an energy revolution when Mako was harvested by an evil corporation. It turns out Mako is the lifeblood of the planet and environmental destruction might not be a great idea after all. It features Cloud, the edgiest bitch ever but in this game even he is alright. Sephiroth is amazing and there are so many great moments.
The music is legendary! Listen to this late-game track that I love.

games.name: To The Moon
review: This is a visual novel from 2011 that I tried out on a whim because it allegedly had a story that will make you cry. I love games like that but this one is a technical mess which stopped me from taking it seriously. I made it to the end but felt nothing.

games.name: Antichamber
review: A bizarre puzzle game with very conceptual and abstract puzzles. The vibe is harsh colours or lack thereof, like exploring the mind of the spirit of a colour printer. I wasn't smart enough to complete the game but I enjoyed making slow progress on it

games.name: Asteroids
review: A classic that I played with Dad when I was a child. A classic, but it's not like I would recommend it or anything

games.name: Sonic 2
review: What a banger. Huge game. A classic, and I associate it with so many good memories as a child. I remember playing this with school friends from primary school because one of them had a Sega Mega Drive. The music? Hello. Banger after banger. Check out fucking Hill Top Zone! I love the various environments like Oil Ocean or Aquatic Ruin and their bright colours and strong vibes. It sucked that there wasn't save files though, it meant that I very rarely made it past Metropolis and only when I was older was I able to beat the final boss.

games.name: Infamous
review: Not a great game. I remember playing it for a bit at some point. The main character is a classic "what people thought gamers wanted" type character: 30-year old shaven head white guy. This game is a like a power fantasy, with lots of murdering people using electrical superpowers. Wild that it exists to be honest.

games.name: Tony Hawk's Pro Skater 3
review: My true love was Pro Skater 4, but this one I distinctly remember playing at a family friend's place when I was a child. I strongly remember the Foundry, Canada, Suburbia and Toyko, although the memories are more like core memories than specific things.

games.name: Croc: Legend of the Gobbos
review: I borrowed this from my friend Oscar when I was a child because I loved Croc 2 so much, but was pretty disappointed by how the gobbos just look like fuzzballs, and the bosses were total bullshit. I never beat it but it's definitely not a good game so that's fine.

games.name: Quantum Redshift
review: Sometimes when we hung out with our friend Amy back then as teenagers, we used to play this racing game on her Xbox. It was alright. I watched a video of it again and it looks kinda shit.

games.name: Fable
review: Loved this classic game. My brother got it and at first I just played the good route and couldn't really understand why anyone would take the evil route. But then I grew up and played the evil part and it felt so fun, like breaking the rules. It was also the first game to have some kind of morality system, so this was all very exciting at the time. Looking back, it's kinda wild that games now just let you go around murdering people and living out evil fantasies. Anyway, the game is hilarious. It's old and probably aged very badly but I can imagine it would be a right laugh to play it again.

Funny story in year 10 we had to do a week's work experience somewhere, and the school gave out jobs like shelf stacking and stuff, but I wanted to be extra so I contacted a family friend who let me work at his game studio where he worked as an animator. It was sick! I didn't do any actual work I just hung out in their office. He was an animator and they were working on an Xbox game called 'Pure' so I got to see all the game dev for that. And this game studio before that made Fable! And said family friend had tons of old models and animations from all the characters and environments in Fable on his computer. It was so cool.

games.name: Super Smash Bros. Ultimate
review: I mean where do I even begin. Anyone who knows me knows I love this game and it probably is my favourite game ever. I mean, come on. Imagine you're a nintendo fanboy and then they release a game with all your favourite nintendo characters in it, all your favourite nintendo music and in general all the fan service you could ever want. And the game is actually good. It's so good that I organise all the motherfucking tournaments for it in Berlin and compete in it myself even. This game is just the bees knees, it has everything. There are so many characters, and so of course I naturally gravitate towards my favourites. There's something for everyone here.

And the game is actually so good. There are so many layers of depth! As a child I remember early smash games the difference between learning how to Up-B back to stage, or how to use roll and spotdodge, and not knowing that stuff. That was like level 1 smash. Fastforward to today and I'm on like level 10 smash, playing in competitive tournaments. Now it's all about specific match up knowledge, having a gameplan and changing your gameplan mid-game. It's about mind games and understanding what your opponent will do. It's an actual fighting game and it turns out I'm super into that. Playing in tournament has been so satisfying, and I have loved slowly getting better over the years.

In fact I can only recommend to anyone to join the smash community. Going to tournaments is just so fun, and sure the community itself is full of nerds, and mostly they are boys, there are also a bunch of cool people, and there's no money involved. So it's an actual grassroots community, all just getting together for the love the game, and that is so cool. Now I'm a community leader and I do a lot of very fulfilling work for the community. It's nice and has inspired me to look for more community in my life.

I personally main Peach because she is just stunning. Her vibes are great and her victory screens are hilarious. I love that she has the float mechanic, which makes her able to move unlike any other character. It also means she has a very good disadvantage, so I don't have to be frustrated about not being able to get back to stage. Early smash ultimate days I even got some great results with her, but that's because she was a monster in the early meta. These days, the meta has been overcrowded with bullshit characters and camping, but luckily it doesn't hinder too much my enjoyment of the local tournaments that I put on. That being said, he's hoping for a switch 2 edition which nerfs Steve!

I'm not done talking about this game. Have you seen the soundtrack? There are over a thousand tracks. Each stage from each game franchise has a whole bunch of music from their respective games, and crucially, there are banger remixes of hundreds of these tracks. All my favourite nintendo games are represented here with some of the best remixes ever. What more could you possibly want?! Well, I guess a good online, but that's fine. Having a bad online just means that people are forced to come to my offline smash tournaments hehe

games.name: Shantae and the Pirate's Curse
review: I loved this game! I think I played it during this empty Nintendo Wii U period desperately looking for something good. I was floored by the absolute bangers in the soundtrack and got hooked. I immediately made a mix of all the tracks (available on the music section of this website!) because they are so fucking good. The game itself is also great, although what is going on with the boobs? All the girls have insane boobs, and I played this on the 3DS, where the boobs literally pop out of the screen. Representation of women in video games, am I right

games.name: Pokemon Y
review: For me this game was the beginning of the end. Pokemon never really recovered from this game. This was when we all realised that they are more interested in making money than making good games.

It did have some great new pokemon in the new generation, so I'll give it that. And it had some hilarious moments, and the Team Flare music is great. But overall this game is just ridiculous, and the magic isn't really there.

games.name: World of Goo
review: A cute and fun puzzle game! These physics kind of puzzles are also great. It might be the only WiiWare game I played.

games.name: Scribblenauts
review: In this game you could type in anything, and it would make an object of it in the game. It really attempts to go for the free user input approach to make a video game, which is brave. There are many words in the world! I started small but ended up testing the limits of the system pretty quickly. It's very easy to cheese all the levels after a bit of experimenting. Kudos to the devs for trying though.

games.name: The Legend of Zelda: The Wind Waker
review: Is it my favourite Zelda? It might just be. I remember being so insanely excited for this game as a child, and when I finally started playing, exploring Outset Island, I thought it was like paradise. It was everything I could ever want from a zelda game and more! And it had this beautiful artstyle which totally captured my imagination.

There are so many moments that I love, everything about Windfall Island, setting sail for the first time, the stealth bits in Forsaken Fortress, the cool Rito characters, the dragon on the mountain, the silly music in the forest, the sad music of the deku tree, Makar, the vibe switch when you get to the tower of the gods, when Tetra winks at you, being terrified of the zombies in the earth temple, the general vibe of the wind temple, Molgera's boss theme, that one ice island when link always falls on his face, the look on Link's face when he sidles along a ridge, the feeling you get when you unfreeze time in Hyrule castle, the part with puppet ganon. The game just has so many good moments and such good music to go with it. Is it flawless? No. But the HD remake is!

games.name: The Legend of Zelda: The Wind Waker HD
review: Is it my favourite Zelda? It might just be. During the Nintendo drought of like 2013/2014, this was such a blessing. Absolute banger getting redone with a nice filter and some gameplay improvements. Perfect, stunning, and the best way to play the game. Absolutely wild that as of writing this (2025), it's still only available on Wii U.

games.name: Pokemon FireRed
review: This game is actually class. The originals are kinda unplayable so having this somewhat sensible version of Kanto was totally amazing. This also opened my eyes to the idea of a 'remake' when I was a child. It's weird because this came out when I was 11, and back then I remember being nostalgic for the original which I must have played when I was like 6.
The Sevii islands were so cool, and Jessie and James were in it. Lots of love.

games.name: GoldenEye 007
review: My brother Cam played this game more than me, but I definitely also tried it. I have some core memories associated with the first few levels, and from being forced to play the multiplayer with my brothers. Back then I didn't really like violence in games at all so was much busier playing Donkey Kong 64 instead of this. But I enjoyed using the motion sensor mines. Also I used to think that the gun pictures in the image looked like a big fancy pen.

games.name: Super Mario Land
review: I loved this game so much. It was my first mario game! Only later did I play super mario world so this was the benchmark for platformers for me. Definitely one of the very first games I ever played. Most notable is the classic music. Huge. Looking back, I appreciate that it's not in the mushroom kingdom and that there are worlds based on countries in real life. And also Daisy is the princess here, not Peach!

games.name: Super Mario Kart
review: I can't believe the first mario kart looked like this! They split the screen like this on the fucking super nintendo and straight up made a 3d game. Insane! The game itself is hard as balls but you can kinda get good at it if you keep at it. Some of these tracks are legendary, and I love it when they get remade in the newer mario kart games, it's just deeply satisfying.

I also have to shout out the soundtrack. Like 6 of the tracks is latin-inspired music! Salsa in things like Choco Island and Samba in Donut Plains, it's everywhere you listen. I love it! And of course this is where a brand new genre of music was invented: Rainbow Road music. Is there anything like it?

games.name: Super Mario Bros.
review: I mean yeah it's a classic but it's not like it's good. Still, I'm happy it exists.

games.name: Ball
review: My friend Fab had a special Super Mario Game and Watch thing and I killed some time by playing the 'Ball' game on it, which is exactly how it used to be on the original Game and Watch. This game is boring as fuck, and there's no end. At some point I gave up and let myself die because it didn't become any more difficult. Would not recommend to a friend. But I'm satisfied to have played a game featuring the character from smash Mr Game and Watch.

games.name: Jet Pack Joyride
review: God, I got so hopelessly addicted to this. I remember thinking, I just need to do a few more runs, then I can finally unlock all the stuff, but they kept releasing new stuff so quickly that I couldn't keep up. I became obsessed with just getting all the unlockables long after I stopped having fun with the game. In the end, this game taught me to never play mobile games again. Fuck games like this with predatory pricing systems and addictive gameplay loops. They're not even good.

games.name: Audiosurf
review: This game was awesome because you could put in your own music and it would generate a rhythm game for it! And it would even have its own associated leaderboard, so you could go super niche and be the big boss for the Yoshi's Island DS title theme or something. I loved doing this it made me feel special playing rhythm games with all my favourite Nintendo tracks. I can't comment on whether it was actually good, but I remember thoroughly enjoying it.

games.name: Pac-man
review: I've played the original Pac-man, actually in an arcade for sure, but also in like a Google doodle as well. It's everywhere really. I wouldn't say it's good though. Iconic, but not actually fun. It's really unsatisfying leaving uneated pellets around.

games.name: Sonic 3 & Knuckles
review: Absolute banger of a game that I adored as a child. The music, hello? So many iconic areas, Angel Island, Hydrocity, Marble Garden, loved them all. The Knuckles version with all the extra levels is also amazing. This was peak Sonic for me for my whole life (at least until Sonic Mania happened).

games.name: Infamous 2
review: Not sure how I ended up playing this as well as the original, but it's equally as dumb and the characters very ugly.

games.name: Tony Hawk's Pro Skater 4
review: Wow, looking back at screenshots of this game it looks so shit, but I swear this was the bees knees back then. I spent hours on it and got genuinely good at it. I did all the hard missions even on the unlockable levels like Carnival at the end. The licensed soundtrack gave this a punk rock vibe which I thought I didn't like but actually it's great. This is the best Tony Hawk's game for sure.

games.name: Bust-a-move 2 Arcade Edition
review: This is actually called 'Puzzle Bobble' but our version was called Bust-a-move for some reason. It's a banger! I struggled so hard against some of these levels and child me associated the pain with the little characters you were fighting against. There's a difficulty spike with the pink haired girl and I fucking loathed her.

games.name: Halo 2
review: I never really loved this game, but my brother played it all the time. Sometimes we played multiplayer, so I would just look for the purple gun because it looked nice. Shooting games like this were never my thing, I was too busy playing Diddy Kong Racing.

games.name: The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild
review: It's a classic! This game redefined open world gaming and said, no it doesn't have to be like Ubisoft like it. In this game, you go to a tower, you climb it, and you look out and see a bunch of cool shit that you wanna check out. There's so much cool shit! Shrines are fun and just hanging out and glamping is just great.

The music is super special. It's piano based and very sparse in the open world. The towns and battles all have that zelda style, but it's a bit different, the music is kinda kooky (look at the normal battle theme) but also light and airy, thanks to the acoustic instrumentation. I really love it.
The story is totally shit, but this game isn't about the story. You have to let that go.

games.name: Bayonetta 2
review: This is a porn game. Like it's embarrassing to play this game in the house in case someone walks in while you play, because it looks like porn. Bayonetta herself is of course designed to be a 14 year old boy's wet dream, but craziest part of the game is just the camera, which zooms in on her vagina and boobs so often it's insane. Then it turns out her clothes are made out of her hair, and she needs those strands of magic hair to do big attacks, so of course she becomes naked as she fights. You can't make it up.

Anyway. There's not actually inherently wrong with having sexualised women in video games. There was a time when this was an issue because that was all you got, but these days there's loads of great female representation so I'm not too bothered about this design. It's actually kinda fun and over the top. The game itself is also so needlessly dramatic, it's hilarious.

I will say one thing though, the vibes of this game are very good. They are very unique and fabulous. The music is its whole new genre. It's like music for unfurling your butterfly wings to. It's sassy and maximalist and I have to say it's fucking great and suits Bayonetta perfectly. I also enjoy all the religious imagery in the game and all the monsters from heaven and hell. It's all kinda classy.
I didn't really enjoy the hack and slash gameplay, and didn't really get good at the combos. This isn't my favourite genre of game.

games.name: The Legend of Zelda: A Link Between Worlds
review: This is where that stunning Zelda redesign came from. She looks so good in this game. I really enjoyed the game! It's pretty similar to link to the past but with a modern twist. Some great music tracks (Lorule Castle hello) and I enjoyed using the 3D on this game especially.

games.name: Super Mario Galaxy
review: I played this game to death as a teenager. I was obsessed. I never knew Mario could be like this. Jumping from star to star like an addiction. I distinctly remember abandoning taking out the bins, doing homework and other tasks in order to play more galaxy. This shit was fire.

I fucking love all the levels and different vibes. Space Junk Galaxy, Dusty Dune Galaxy, Buoy Base Galaxy, Melty Molten Galaxy... so many good ones with legendary music tracks. You've got these sick gravity mechanics and awesome planets to visit, such a good idea for a game! And then the green stars afterwards? Sign me up. Purple coins? With that music? Sign me up. The whole thing again as Luigi? Sign me up.

games.name: Pokemon Soul Silver
review: Is this the greatest Pokemon game ever? It might just be. I still remember my original Team. Business the Starmie, Zorbo the Alakazam, Rockwobble the Golem... OK I can't remember more than that. On a later playthrough I got Forretress, Yanmega, Mamoswine and other favourites. This generation has the best fucking pokemon man. I love Piloswine, Octillery, Magcargo. There are so many.

I played this game multiple times because it's that good. I associate so many good childhood memories with it. The music is so good, I even made a mix of it, available on the music section of the site. And I love that after you beat the game, you can go explore all the Kanto as well. It's like the ultimate cherry on top. It's so fun! The areas are remixed to be 3 years later and there's a super tough gauntlet of battles at the end. So great.
And omg the pokemon follow behind you. This was revolutionary. I remember having a Krabby and it just walks sideways because hell yes it's a crab.

games.name: Fire Emblem: Path of Radiance
review: I borrowed a friend's copy of this back in 2019, so I played it quite late, long after playing Radiant Dawn, but that's just the nature of hard-to-get games like this. I'm really glad that it's coming to the Switch online, because more people can finally play it!

This game is great, although I will say I prefer the sequel, Radiant Dawn. Nonetheless, it has a pretty good and straightforward story following Ike as he explores his feelings for Soren. This otherwise plain adventure is made spicy by the sexual tension between these two and I love it. Ike is so gay for his femme tactician.
The music is great and contributes to a very serious, high-fantasy vibe. I love the parts with the Black Knight.

games.name: The Legend of Zelda: The Minish Cap
review: A super fun zelda game! Some fun twists on the 2D formula. Shrinking down is a fun concept. It's not up there with the best zeldas but it's very lighthearted and nice!

games.name: The Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time
review: I mean this is a total classic. This game was present during my most formative years. I remember being a child and being too scared to fight the first boss, too scared to go across hyrule field at night, and DEFINITELY too scared to go anywhere near those redeads. This was the game of getting my brothers to do the scary bits for me. It's because this game is so moody! I was captivated.

It's got so many good moments. When the gorons hug you, the Deku tree dying, the whole of Jabu Jabu's belly, the part where the fat zora slowly moves over, seeing Kakariko as an adult, meeting the kokiri as an adult, stopping the rolling goron, the wild cutscene with sheik in Kakariko village, gerudo fucking fortress, all the little mini dungeons in ganon's tower, the FINAL BOSS I mean hello.

I loved the temples, they felt like such achievements to complete. I loved the world and the towns. I love the music. Forest Temple is the moodiest music ever, unlike anything else. I mean what a VIBE. Then spirit temple, water temple too, so good. Classics like Kakariko village, Kokiri forest, Zora's domain, still 10/10 to this day.
I think the best way to play this game is the 3DS remake but just hop on Switch online and play it if you haven't. This game is timeless.

games.name: The Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time 3D
review: Huge game, and huge remake. I think this is the best way to play this game. It looks great, plays great, and comes with a bunch of quality of life improvements. It also includes master quest! Master quest is like a hard-mode with really cool puzzles that was exclusive to the gamecube version that came with Wind Waker. And there's a boss rush mode, too!

games.name: Pokemon Yellow
review: I will never forget sitting at the kitchen table of our house in Brightwell and Dad gave all three of us pokemon games, Red, Blue and Yellow. Because me and my brothers kinda have this thing where these happen to be our colours, I was given Yellow and my brothers were sooooo jealous. This was the upgraded version with a special Pikachu that followed you around!

I have such strong memories of not being able to parse Venusaur's pixel art from behind, getting hit constantly by the move 'bind', really dumb computer AI, specifically aiming for rare and ugly pokemon. Even back then I had this weird taste in pokemon, I remember having Seadra, Kingler, Vileplume. Man, gen 1 has some of the best pokemon ever. As I type this I'm admiring my Gloom plushie. So ugly I love it. I love that there are so many pokemon that there is also room for silly and ugly pokemon next to the popular and beautiful ones.

games.name: Super Mario World
review: This might be the ultimate 2D Mario game. It's timeless. It still plays well today because it's seamless. It has its own special identity and is the real reason Mario is so big now. I love that the special world had a level called 'gnarly'. The castle and fortress boss themes are class. The yoshis were great. So much to love!

games.name: Earthbound Beginnings (Mother 1)
review: This is by far the most vibes NES game out there. It's an extremely kooky jrpg following a pretty loose story of a boy visiting a bunch of strange places. It is the blueprint for Mother 2 and 3, two of the best games ever, and fans of those games should definitely also check this out. This is where that gorgeous pink stage from smash comes from!

games.name: Temple Run
review: I got addicted to this in 2011. I'd never played an autorunner so it was very exciting. Funny how it got me hooked even if wasn't exactly a satisfying game. I guess it was novel and exciting to play mobile games.

games.name: Barotrauma
review: It's just like the name suggests, it's a traumatic and upsetting management game about running a submarine. I'm sure it's good but I don't want to spend my free time being this distressed

games.name: Mega Bomberman
review: I loved this game!! I played it on my friend's Sega but later on I emulated it on PC because it was so good. The adventure mode slaps, the music is class, the final boss is ridiculously hard, and the multiplayer mode is perfect. Me and my brothers played a bunch. Lots of core memories associated with this.

games.name: Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas
review: I loved playing this game when I was younger, but not for the normal reasons. This was the first time I'd played an open world game! You could go anywhere. I loved exploring the world and finding secrets and treasures. I loved free roaming and hanging out. Doing the missions was also cool I guess. There's a point in the game where you can just start stealing airplanes and fly them around. I remember feeling like anything was possible!

Wild that the first time I had those feelings was with grand theft auto! This game taught me everything I knew back then about black culture in America, as well as gang violence and prostitution. There I was, a child, going around shooting gang members, having sex with prostitutes, I even remember becoming a pimp in one mission. Looking back I think it gave me a kind of baseline understanding of a bunch of real issues in America that was totally warped. You can just fuck a prostitute then kill her to get the money back, it's totally fucked up. I remember really enjoying the missions where you just drive round in a fire truck and put out fires. Because I was a child. And there I was, also expanding the gang's territory in these crazy shoot-outs in the streets.

I'm not saying the game is bad. I think the vibe is super good, the music and especially the car radio stations are great, and the open world was amazing. But it's wild that so many of us played this in our formative years. I know that I didn't think about the wealth of social issues the game brings up with any sort of critical eye. Because I was a child.

games.name: Grand Theft Auto
review: All I remember of this game was being ridiculed by my brothers for enjoying taking a car and driving it properly down the streets without bumping into anyone. I enjoyed following the law. I guess that says a lot about me that I wasn't excited about murdering people and stealing their cars. Me and GTA have never really gotten on.

games.name: Tomb Raider
review: It's triangle tits herself! An icon. I definitely did not finish this, but I played it at I think a cousin's place as a child. I remember enjoying the mood and having to find cogs or something.

games.name: Octopath Traveler
review: This game had a lot going for it, and in two departments especially it truly excels: music and visuals. This was the first time we were treated to the HD-2D thing and I love it. I think it looks so nice! The soundtrack is also top class. It's perfect for use in your DnD campaign. The boss battle music is insanely good.

I really loved Tressa. She's a total babe and I made sure to play her story to the end.
