In order to do that though, I had to play the stories of all the other 7 characters, even though they were all completely unrelated. The game is split into four sections, and in each section you have to complete some story for each character. When I finally got to the fourth and final section, I just did Tressa's story then called it quits. Why? Because this game is fucking exhausting. It's so long. The boss battles take over an hour sometimes. I remember doing one of them while taking a bath, and deciding to get out of the bath before finishing the fight. Which is ridiculous if you think about it. I should be able to complete one boss fight in one bathtime. I feel like that's an unwritten rule that until this point has been largely respected.

The worst thing about this game though is the fact that it's 8 different stories which have no relation with one another. The characters barely even talk to each other! Why even have 8 stories like this if they don't interact? They could have built a beautiful world with tons of related characters and storylines but no it's super separated and therefore boring. And it makes no sense why they're all travelling together. This really pissed me off when trying to enjoy the story. For such a long game, having to play 8 very shallow stories with no meat to them was just lame.
I'm told the second game is better in that regard but I don't have the strength to even try it.

games.name: New Super Mario Bros. U
review: The New Super Mario Bros series had some great moments. The original had fantastic vibes, and the Wii version changed everything by adding multiplayer. But this version on the Wii U brings nothing new to the table. I think it's quite soulless. There is one level which isn't your standard Mario, this painted swamp level pictured here. That's it. The Luigi DLC was good though!

games.name: Pokemon Sun
review: After the disappointment that was gen 6, I got really into gen 7, I'm not gonna lie. I even made a mix of all the music from this game, available in the music section of this website! And it does have some great tracks, especially the Aether Paradise and Team Skull stuff. A lot of the town and city themes are also great. I think they smashed it with the Hawaiian islands setting.
This gen also introduced us to a bunch of hilarious new pokemon, including potentially my favourite pokemon ever, Alolan Exeggutor. It's just a motherfucking tree. So good.

This game has a lot of random ass bullshit though, I won't lie. The part where the evil CEO lady fuses with this tentacle squid ultra beast thing just so she can float in the air and have an ordinary pokemon battle? I think that is someone's sex fantasy. And what the fuck is up with these weird-ass ultra beasts. I mean I love it because they're totally insane, but hello? Guzzlord? Buzzwole? What were they smoking when they decided to make these the legendary pokemon. Also the main character just has this gormless look on their face all the time which both ruins the vibe and also makes it hilarious, in a laughing-at not laughing-with kinda way.
I dunno I guess this game still has a space in my heart.

games.name: New Super Mario Bros. Wii
review: It is insane that this game had just four playable characters and two of them were TOAD. I'm still upset about it I mean Peach is right there. Look at the latest mario kart roster and see how far they're come.

Anyway I remember when this came out and it was huge. Playing multiplayer was the best ever, specifically because you could purposefully make life harder for the other players. It genuinely created great party game moments with friends.
The vibes became a little stale after the DS game I guess but they added some new things like the beautiful underground volcano music.

games.name: New Super Mario Bros.
review: I understand that this is the first in a series of arguably boring looking mario games, so most people wouldn't say this is worth playing, but I stand by the fact that this is the best one in terms of vibes. The credits theme alone is fantastic. And I remember the look and style of this game being so fresh back then. Not to mention it came with these banger minigames that we played soooo much as kids.

games.name: Super Mario Sunshine
review: Banger alert! This game is so good. They thought up a whole ass tropical island for Mario to just go to and find some shenanigans to get up to. Something about being able to see the other levels from the various different points on the island is just cool. And I love the general sunny and positive vibe of the game. The piantas are all delightful, the missions are fun. SURE there is a lot of bullshit and I wouldn't recommend anyone to 100% like I did. But you can't deny the vibes are off the charts.
Also this is the game where Mario got a bunch of cool moves! Running and jumping around in 3D was revolutionised with this game. The FLUDD mechanic is great.

There are a bunch of great moments in this game. The sand bird, the underwater part, the local musicians in pianta village, the genuinely terrifying manta ray thing, the casino, and why on earth is the final boss battle just bowser taking a bath?

games.name: Pokemon Emerald
review: I have a strong memory of holding out on buying Ruby or Sapphire so I could buy Emerald. I even imported it from the USA! I'm so glad I did, Emerald was so much better than the others. I remember some of my original team. I had a Glalie for sure, because also back then I had an appreciation of ugly pokemon.
I love the Hoenn region, especially the watery bit at the end with all the cool pokemon. This gen had some banger pokemon! Motherfucking Wailord. I also love the music and general vibe a lot.

games.name: Super Mario 64
review: Classic doesn't even begin to describe this game! It's the ultimate classic. It was a banger then and it's still a banger now. Is there any better feeling than getting a star?
The music alone is so good. Dire, Dire Docks, Bowser's Road, Hazy Maze Caves are my favourites. This game changed everything back then.

games.name: Pokemon Silver
review: Gen 2 is my SHIT! I fucking love everything about gold and silver. It turned the unplayable gen 1 into banger games, added a bunch of amazing pokemon and a sick new region. It added night and day, which was huge.

I still remember so fondly having a Forretress which didn't even learn any good bug moves, and waiting until near the end of the game to catch a Piloswine, my favourite pokemon at the time. Maybe still my favourite pokemon I need to think about that.

games.name: Super Mario World 2: Yoshi's Island
review: I mean just look at this game. They really made a 'hand-drawn' style game on the SNES! It looks so good! I love the scenery in this picture and I have a painting in my room where I tried to recreate it.
The game is hard an nails though! Especially if you want to get perfect scores on the level. I never managed to do that, not to 100%, it's just too brutal, especially on those extra levels.

games.name: Ice Climber
review: As an ice climbers main in brawl times, I felt obliged to play this on the virtual console, really trying my best to like it. But it's shit. The characters control terribly, and the game gets boring after like 3 mountains. The swing music at the peak of the summit is great though.

games.name: Cut the Rope
review: One of the better early mobile games because it had a finite amount of levels.

games.name: Command & Conquer 3: Tiberium Wars
review: I played this because I loved Red Alert as a child. It's alright. I enjoyed playing as the aliens

games.name: Micro Machines V2
review: I remember having the time of my fucking life with this game. It was hilarious multiplayer and I got well into the single player too. I hope there's a spiritual successor to this one day

games.name: Tekken Tag Tournament
review: This is the only actual fighting game I played as a child. My brothers were always better but I enjoyed playing as Eddy to start with spamming the breakdance move, and when I grew up I mained Julia and Michelle, probably because I'm gay. Nina and Jun were other favourites, so yeah.
Anyway this game is great. Vibes, soundtrack, arcade mode, all great. What is going on with Paul's haircut and is King actually some kind of animal. Also what is going on with Tekken lore generally.

games.name: Tekken 3
review: I was very young when we had this so I wasn't able to play much and get good. But I remember loving that you could unlock a tiny dinosaur, Gon. He was my main

games.name: Xenoblade Chronicles 2
review: It is so fucked up that they hired a literal hentai artist to be the character designer for this game. The sheer size of everyone's badonkadonks is mind-boggling. There are multiple in-script jokes about them! Pictured here is Dahlia, the first optional 'blade' I encountered. She's a monstrosity! Then there's Pyra, whose ass you have to look at the whole game as she runs beside you in her skimpy pants. Her character is just a Mary Sue who is just all boobs and no brains. Hate it. Mythra also insufferable.

I hate so much about this game but I fucking finished it. I was so excited about the switch that I just did it. There were redeeming factors! I loved the regional accents, especially Nia's. I like Rex. I don't care I'll just admit it. Morag the only competent human being there, thank god they included her. I really enjoyed the environments, especially the stunning kingdom of Uraya. The cloud sea is a great idea.

games.name: Donkey Kong Country: Tropical Freeze
review: This is the greatest Donkey Kong game ever. They fucking knocked out of the park with this one. This is the best platformer ever I don't care, I'll say it. The movement is so good. I love how you can roll to go super fast and jump out of it, maintaining your speed. Actually this is kind of a speedrunning game! I even did all the speed challenges on all the levels to get the gold medals, and it was so hard! Donkey Kong games are unafraid to go there in terms of difficulty. Only being able to be hit twice is kinda hardcore if you think about it.

So the platforming is great, but what elevates this game above everything else is the incredible environments and music. The first level's music tells you everything you need to know about the vibe of the game. Then later on there's a world based on the Alps, then the African savannah, then some of the most gorgeous underwater levels ever, then this insane jungle island where the levels showcase harvest fruits, turning them into juice, putting them into moulds, freezing them to make ice lollies that the boss eats! Insane.

Everything in this game has a context. There's always a sensible reason for everything that happens. There are no floating platforms, but rather always contextual objects that are moving for some real reason. Donkey Kong and his friends all look great too.

And the MUSIC! I'm talking about the sax solo in Busted Bayou. Grassland Groove at the end when a choir sings 'Donkey Kong!'. Wing Ding when it fades out and gets really intense. The first boss Big Top Bop randomly goes SO HARD. Seriously check it out. The smooth sax in the credits theme. I'm obsessed. The frozen factory music! Actually I loved the vibes of the frozen levels so much, which surprised me.
Dear reader, please play this game.

games.name: Pokemon Alpha Sapphire
review: They made a bunch of new mega evolutions for Hoenn pokemon which somehow resulted in them taking one of the ugliest pokemon, Glalie, and making it even MORE ugly. I of course had to get one for my team. Mega Glalie is so fucking ugly, I'm obsessed with it. That alone gave me the strength to get through this game. Tragically, this game really doesn't live up to the original. It's just not fun, and crucially, the vibes aren't there. I would rather listen to the original soundtrack than the new one. The new one just sounds worse.
One good thing to come out of it is they put the team Aqua leader guy in a sexy skin-tight suit which looks super dumb and hot.

games.name: Wii Sports Resort
review: This game didn't grip me like the original. I mean it makes sense that the original was better because of the Wii hype, but I didn't ever sit down and get good at any of these games. I remember Shrobo once did a Swordfighting side event at a tournament. The main theme is great though.

games.name: Pilotwings 64
review: I tried this out on Switch online, mainly because I wanted to hear the birdman music, but I guess that comes later in the game, and I didn't find the early levels interesting enough to keep going.

games.name: Pilotwings
review: This game was super hard and made no sense. I don't think flight simulators are my thing. But let me tell you this soundtrack is super good. Light Plane of course a banger but also check out Helicopter, composed by Koji Kondo himself. Apparently later in the game, the story takes a wild turn and there's a serious shift in tone. Part of me wants to push through and get into it, but flight simulators just aint for me

games.name: Pokemon White
review: Mate Gen 5 is genuinely good. I love that they went for something new with a whole new set of pokemon, a whole different vibe with the kinda more serious story, and showing off these new fancy graphics. I remember being genuinely blown away by going over Skyarrow bridge into the big city.
The music of this gen is top notch! I love the instrumentation, it just has that unmistakable pokemon vibe present throughout the whole soundtrack.

A lot of banger pokemon were introduced in this generation. This is also the game where I found one of the only and by far most consequential shiny pokemon! It was an orange 'Throh' which I loved - the only time I've found a shiny on my actual playthrough. I also enjoyed having a Stunfisk, a Ferrothorn, a Cryogonal and a Durant. So many beautiful ugly pokemon to enjoy in this generation.

games.name: Soul Calibur II
review: This game was kinda ridiculous! I never owned it but a childhood friend did. I enjoyed playing as Link but never got good at it. Strong memory of asking my friend why does Ivy look like that (boob lady) and he said it's great that's she's so sexy

games.name: Kirby: Nightmare in Dream Land
review: This game is a remake of an older game, Kirby's Adventure on the NES, so it's pretty linear, but that doesn't mean it's not an absolute BANGER of a game! This is pure and perfect Kirby! The music hits the spot perfectly. Ice Cream Island, Butter Building, Orange Ocean, Rainbow Resort... there's so much to enjoy. To this day I am able to play the whole soundtrack on the piano because it's just something I automatically play when I sit down at the piano.

I played this game so much! If you beat it, you can play through as Meta Knight and I thought that was the coolest shit ever. Also it's wild how important the hammer ability is in this game. This is also where the Fountain of Dreams comes from!

games.name: The Legend of Zelda: Majora's Mask
review: An all-time classic. The vibes in this game are unmatched. Can you believe they made a Zelda game where the moon falls after three days and everyone dies? You sometimes forget about this premise, until you get to the third day and hear all the earthquakes, and see how people are evacuating and then on the final evening that music starts playing... JESUS! This game is dark. There were so many parts where I was scared as a child. Even the mask salesman with this face he pulls was scary. Everything about the Majora's Mask itself was terrifying. Like the it stares at you with wide-open eyes like a lemur, horrible. And most of all I was terrified of the aliens in Lon Lon Ranch. What the fuck.

This game is everything. The melancholic vibe which permeates the whole story is so remarkable. I love all the places you visit, and of course the music is perfect. As a child I remember simply not doing the first boss because I was scared of it, so I did all the goron stuff instead. I loved the Deku shrub. I loved the zora band. I was terrified of Ikana Canyon, like the redeads and the girl's dad, and also that part where the ghost plays an evil song in the cave and saps your life force. The Anju/Kafei thing as well oh my god.
This game stayed in my consciousness for many years. I love it so much.

games.name: Tetris
review: Tetris on our little GBA SP was an important part of the Bowen family. Everyone played, even my parents and my grandma. Everyone in the family can reliably get a rocket.

games.name: F-Zero
review: This game is fun! It still holds up today. The music is class.

games.name: Duck Hunt
review: I played this at a retro games convention with an actual zapper! It was a lot of fun, and I'm happy that I was able to dick off duck hunt from my list of smash characters whose games I want to play, complete and understand. I got kinda into it, and the technology works super well without any lag. It's genuinely a good game but it gets boring pretty quickly.

games.name: Angry Birds
review: I mean who didn't play angry birds at this time. Angry birds heralded the beginning of mobile gaming. I'm not saying it was good, but I did play it a bunch because I am a millenial, I guess.

games.name: Mickey Mouse: Castle of Illusion
review: Took me a while to figure out what the name of this game was. But I played it when I was very young indeed. I have just flashed of memory relating to it. I remember the castle itself, and after some time unlocking... upstairs.

games.name: Crash Bandicoot
review: What a banger! This game was hard as nails. But I loved it. It's a classic!

games.name: Fire Emblem: Three Houses
review: This fucking game goes on for so long! There's so much dawdling between missions that it's ridiculous. I beat Claude's route because it was the gayest and I enjoyed it, but I feel I missed out on a bunch of story and I don't have the strength to go through it all two more times.
Part of me still enjoyed it. Wild how they make this fun teacher and student dynamic when all these characters are committing war crimes.
If you're interested, I romanced Alois as male Byleth and have no regrets.

games.name: Nintendo Land
review: Nintendo Land is THE Wii U game. The only game to probably use the game pad for that asymmetrical gameplay. It's great. Luigi's Mansion the Mario chase and the Animal Crossing game were all genuinely excellent party games that we played a bunch. Single player, Donkey Kong, Yoshi and Pikmin were great. And I love the toy aesthetic of the whole thing. Great stuff

games.name: The Legend of Zelda: Majora's Mask 3D
review: This remake is fantastic! It nails the vibe of the original while making it look good, and it's in stereoscopic 3d, which is super fun. Quality of life improvements are there too. It's great! Actually maybe the better way to play the game if you can get your hands on it.

games.name: Wii Sports
review: The Mii aesthetic wouldn't be as prevalent today if it weren't for Wii Sports. This game made a whole genre of music, much of which went on to become memes. This style of 'Wii game music' is so iconic. And the whole vibe of the game, squeaky clean, goofy... it's good. And back in 2006 this is all we played! Constantly flicking our wrists when we realised we didn't actually have to swing to make a hit in tennis. Playing with miis that we'd made of the whole family... good times

games.name: Animal Crossing: Wild World
review: I remember my friend Oscar being excited about this game having read about it in the official Nintendo magazine while I was at school, so I got it and then magic happened. It's a super peaceful life sim and so much fun to just hang out and let the time past there. I have strong memories of trawling the beach for expensive shells, asking friends to give me their different fruits, having a mushroom themed house. The absolute excitement of waiting for Saturday 8pm for the KK Slider performance.

I regret that I lost the game cartridge, I would love to revisit my original town. I remember Friga the penguin the most, who wandered between mine and Oscar's towns constantly. The villagers were so sassy in this game. They were actually never as fun as this.

Most importantly, this game's hourly music set the bar very high in the world of peaceful background music in video games. The tracks are simple but iconic, and never boring. You can put it on and just vibe.

games.name: Donkey Kong
review: I played this as a part of Donkey Kong 64 but it totally counts. I don't think it's a good game and I don't recommend it. But true Donkey Kong fans should play it for their education.

games.name: Jetpac
review: This was part of Donkey Kong 64 but I beat it in order to get the silly coin you need to beat the game. It's not great

games.name: StreetPass Mii Plaza
review: This was the most exciting thing about the 3ds. Getting those puzzle pieces every time you got home from carrying around your DS all day... so exciting. Find Mii and Find Mii 2 were both super entertaining and I will always remember them fondly. I never played any of the other paid games.

games.name: The Legend of Zelda: Twilight Princess
review: The hype I had for this game was astronomical. I remember seeing the screenshots in the official nintendo magazine and my jaw dropping to the floor. Realistic-looking zelda with good graphics? This was going to be huge. And it was! When it came out I dropped everything and steamed through it, showing off to friends at school how quickly I was getting through it. It was amazing and I loved it.

They really went to a new, creepy place in this game. Such a shock after the delightful Wind Waker. The whole twilight realm is its own special version of creepy, but the characters and vibes of the normal world are also totally creepy too. The designs of the characters are very out there indeed.

There are so many great moments, like going to the bird city, the lost woods, the yetis, the bug collector, the ugly father figure, the battle on the bridge, the final boss. Also this game features one of the scariest zelda moments ever: the floating hands in the palace of twilight. Even as a teenager at this point I was fucking terrified.

The soundtrack is stunning. So many classics like Faron Woods, Hyrule Field, Lake Hylia, but also sleeper hits like the music when you're a wolf in Ordon Village, the Ordon Ranch music, the Fishing hole music, or all the miniboss music. So much to enjoy!

games.name: Fire Emblem: The Blazing Blade
review: Together with Sacred Stones this is a fantastic Fire Emblem entry on the GBA. It builds on the foundation of the previous game, the Binding Blade, which featured Roy, and actually turns it into a good strategy game with some depth. It's the story of Roy's father Eliwood and his two mates Lyn and Hector. The story is exactly what you expect from Fire Emblem but it's still a nice time, and you get to switch around the characters a bit which is fun. Lyn is very likeable!

games.name: Paper Mario
review: It's wild that this game exists! A game about being paper-thin, and it's a 3d game! You go around in a silly mario RPG except everyone is made of paper. Bit of a weird premise if you ask me, but this little RPG has some excellent writing, something which Mario games don't normally go for. You have all these adorable partners and go around and fight monsters in turn-based battles. A great soundtrack to go with it. Lots of iconic moments too!

games.name: The Legend of Zelda: Link's Awakening
review: I truly think that this is the first video game I played. It might have been lemmings or frogger on my dad's dos computer and it might have been tetris, but at the very least, this is when I became a gamer.

This game means so much to me. I know its world and soundtrack so intimately having played it so many times. It took me many years to complete it, because I was too dumb as a child to know where I had to go next. Although I admit the game does not signpost where you should go. You are forced to roam the world and find stuff, which today is kinda unacceptable bad game design, but back then resulted in me putting the game down and coming back when I was a couple of years longer. I remember the boss key in Bottle Grotto was a hard barrier for me for YEARS.

Later when I little by little discovered the delights the game has to offer, the trading quest, the animal village, the scene with Marin on the beach, the face shrine, and each time I was a little bit older. It was so cool. Eventually beating it was a huge moment.

This game has SUCH a kooky vibe. It's bizarre and almost creepy with a bunch of really weird stuff. The whole having your name changed to THIEF if you steal the bow and arrow is really funny. I remember being devastated when I did that as a child - you mean I can't change my name back??

But it's also quite melancholic. When you discover the truth of the island in the face shrine (incredible music by the way), the tone shifts quite a lot. The ending feels almost like death, it's kinda wild. Unlike any other zelda game.

games.name: Panel de Pon (Tetris Attack)
review: This is a puzzle game that I played on the switch online where it's like tetris and you have to swap adjacent bricks to form lines of 3. You can line up the lines to form a combo, and its surprisingly deep! I got quite into it and I challenge any readers to play me online

games.name: Balloon Fight
review: This game is pretty bad but it has a fun theme for the balloon trip mode. I feel like the remake of this in WarioWare Smooth Moves is better, also the Nintendo Land version.

games.name: Final Fantasy VIII
review: My friend Mariana gifted me this on steam and I played it for a bit. I really enjoyed the music and have since listened to the soundtrack a bunch, but the game itself was kinda annoying. I hadn't played final fantasy 7 at this point so I didn't really have a foundation for this kind of game and was very lost very quickly. One thing I enjoyed was having a GF and using her in battle.

games.name: Guitar Hero III: Legends of Rock
review: Funny how I viewed this game as a 'cool rock game' that cool people played (like my brother), but actually it's just a super traditional rhythm game! And rhythm games are probably viewed as lame by your standard Halo enjoyer (my brother), and yet it hit the world by storm. I'm grateful to it for introducing me to the genre!

Using the plastic guitar as a controller was a genius move honestly and I loved it, despite not really caring about rock music. I got so good at it! Interestingly, I ended up appreciating all the rock music after all, even things like Metallica. Cliffs of Dover I still love and I'm shameless but I enjoy Knights of Cydonia by Muse.

games.name: Stardew Valley
review: Wow, this game is so fucking good. It's like Animal Crossing on steroids! This is my go-to recommendation for people who are trying to get into gaming. And more than anything else, girls love this game! Something about the interactions and relationships with the villagers just appeals, also to me. I was very invested in giving Alex his egg everyday that he loved, so that I could get him to marry me. This is when I learned that I like soft jocks. Playing the rest of the game is great, mines, community centre and fishing, all fine, but I did it all so Alex would work out shirtless in front of our family house

games.name: Splatoon
review: I dunno about this game. I played the single player and enjoyed some online matches, but truth is, I wasn't built for team games, let alone online team games. I don't feel the need to start a new match. I'm glad I played it, because I could tick off Inkling from the list of smash characters whose games I've played.

The vibes of this game are off. It's going for this cool kids thing which doesn't appeal to me at all. I love sea creatures and I wasn't excited by the squids and octopuses theme. Actually I'm kinda blown away they made squids and octopuses work at all, it's kinda impressive. But the biggest offender is the horrible soundtrack. It's somewhere between rock and stoned electronic musician gargling mouthwash.

games.name: Pokemon Super Mystery Dungeon
review: People say this is bad but I really enjoyed it! Sure it doesn't have the magic of the first two games, but it has great moments, and also great music. The Nuzleaf twist was great. The recruitment system was a bit weird, I won't lie. I got that Salamence way too early. Maybe I wouldn't recommend this game, unless you're already a Mystery Dungeon fan. It's niche

games.name: Super Smash Bros. Brawl
review: Huge game. I will never forget when this came out and I got it in the post two days early. I went to some school event and said to my friend Oscar 'I love playing as King Dedede' and he was so shook! The hype for this game was through the roof. There was this sick website where Sakurai revealed new stuff about the game every day. At some point I watched all the cutscenes of the subspace emissary from the Japanese release out of pure hype, spoiling everything for myself. The build up was feverish.

I loved the Subspace Emissary. All my favourite nintendo characters all coming together in a massive adventure mode? Insane. I loved that you had to do the different levels with different characters, and I loved that they all teamed up, like Yoshi and Link, or Kirby and Peach, or Lucas and Pokemon Trainer, or Samus and Pikachu. That stuff gave me life. My favourite character, Ice Climbers, even got a little cameo towards the end and I loved it. I was devastated you only have them for one level, and that level with Meta Knight, who I hated.

This was the first smash game with an online mode, and looking back, that thing was SHIT. But I still played it. The connection terrible, but I still played it and loved it. I mained Ice Climbers and also Yoshi. I remember also seeing some competitive smash on youtube at that point, but I wasn't interested in that just yet.

In melee each represented video game got one or two music tracks for their respective stages. That was so fucking cool. But one of the amazing things about brawl is that each franchise got a whole bunch of music!! Actual remixes of all my favourite tunes to suit an upbeat battle theme. There is so much good shit! In legendary Stickerbrush Symphony remix, the Dark World remix, With Mila's Divine Protection, which was THE track of subspace emissary. Fucking Unfounded Revenge, Underground Theme, Luigi Circuit, Ending Yoshi's Story, Butter Building, Meta Knight's Revenge, Fire Field. And you unlocked them with CD items! Seeing one of those was crazy. Drop everything and get that fucking CD!!

games.name: Fire Emblem: Shadow Dragon
review: I did this for my education a long time ago and I remember enjoying it! The game is quite basic though. Marth is very plain but at least this remake makes FE1 playable with its quality of life improvements.

games.name: Mario Kart: Double Dash!!
review: A friend at school had this and I loved playing it, although I was more of a Mario Kart DS kinda guy. Loved bangers like Peach Beach, Mushroom City and Rainbow Road. I also liked how different characters had different special items, that was awesome.
Nowadays, I don't think the game is that good. Playing with another person where you only control the person with the item is super boring.

games.name: Fire Emblem: The Sacred Stones
review: A banger Fire Emblem game on the GBA. It's niche but it has a great story, is loads of fun strategy gameplay, awesome characters and an all round great vibe. I really like the main characters Eirika and Ephraim, and I think I had a weird crush on Seth.

games.name: Lylat Wars
review: I loved this game on our N64! As a child I just did the same route every time to the same planets, because I was too dumb to figure out how to go to different planets. When I grew up a bit and discovered there was a water level, a secret final boss, a bunch of sick fights, I fucking loved it. The ending with Fox's dad is iconic.

games.name: The Grinch
review: In this game you play as the Grinch and you go around stealing all the presents from the kids without them seeing you. It's a stealth game! I got so into and completed it as a child. And this shit was hard as balls! But I loved it. You could incapacitate the children by breathing toxic grinch breath on them. Banger game

games.name: Kirby Super Star
review: This is such a banger game. It's all that kirby goodness that you know and love, except it's 6 different games! There's a remake of the first game, complete with remixes of the banger music, there's the high-stakes Meta Knight's music again with amazing music, a metroidvania with the Great Cave Offensive, and of course Gourmet Race. So funny how the final boss of Milky Way Wishes is just called 'Marx'. This is definitely one of the best kirby games!

games.name: A Hat in Time
review: This game was truly made with love. There's a lot going for it, but it does look kinda shit and tacky. It plays quite janky and the story is very goofy. I appreciate that the main antagonist is Mustache Girl. That scary level in the forest was genuinely terrifying though.

What sets this game apart from other indie game labours of love is the outstanding soundtrack. It is so intricate, and the loops are so long. All the four main areas have amazing music themes in many variations. My favourite is definitely Mafia Town, but I love them all. There is nothing that does spooky forest music like Subcon Forest.

games.name: Tony Hawk's Pro Skater 2
review: I enjoyed playing this for a bit when I was younger. I can only remember the first level in the aircraft hanger.

games.name: Mario + Rabbids Kingdom Battle
review: Incredible that this game exists! I would never have played XCOM because of its horrible vibes, but I was so down to try out this kind of top down strategy game with mario characters! They all have guns, which is insane! Then they included the Rabbids? I guess because it's Ubisoft. Wild crossover. But I don't hate the rabbids. I love Rabbid Peach and would love for her to join Smash.

The music and vibe of this game is quite good, if a bit clean and tidy. I enjoyed beating it, it got quite deep, and the Donkey Kong DLC was great. They did a second game but it's not going to be as exciting once the novelty wears off, so I didn't bother playing it

games.name: Super Mario Maker
review: This game was so good, I loved it. I made a bunch of levels and uploaded them, and loved playing other people's levels. I really respect that online community of people who went through and beat all of the levels available online before it went offline.

games.name: Fire Emblem: Awakening
review: This game signals a very different direction for the series, and I really loved it. It's an engaging story with a really cool time travel element. The reveal of who Marth is is a classic nintendo moment.
I remember in my playthough, Miriel was insanely strong. Also Cherche. Also it's wild that they made Lon'qu an actual woman hater.

games.name: Pokemon Battle Revolution
review: It's not a great game, it doesn't do it like Stadium does. I played through it with my beloved Diamond and Pearl team but didn't love it.

games.name: The Legend of Zelda: Phantom Hourglass
review: It's something different! I enjoyed playing with the touchscreen for this game. I enjoyed the ocean temple that you kept coming back to. I enjoyed the character Jolene. This game is really let down by the lacklustre soundtrack though. Not having dungeon themes is tragic.

games.name: Super Smash Bros. Melee
review: Oh hell yes this game was everything. The upgrade from 64 was INSANE! All these amazing characters coming together and it looked so good! Me and my brothers played this constantly for years. I loved Yoshi and I loved the Ice Climbers. I loved adventure mode where you have side scrolling platforming, all star mode with the lobby music from Kirby, the events, I loved unlocking characters! For so long we didn't know how to get Mewtwo or Mr Game and Watch. I was blown away when we finally unlocked them, they were both so weird, and I knew nothing about them!

Later in life I've come back to melee, but of course as a competitive player. I got to know the melee scene a bit and enjoyed playing with Peach a lot. It's an entirely different game to the one I played as a child because I now know about L cancelling and wavedashing and stuff. Still great. I understand how it's timeless, gameplay wise.

For me, this game turned me into a nintendo fan. It's actually a huge history book about everything nintendo. I read the description of all of those trophies and loved it. I listened to all this music from the franchises and learned about the obscure ones. This game really had some of the most incredible tracks... I mean Brinstar Depths, Hyrule Temple, Jungle Japes, Fountain of Dreams, Big Blue, Pollyanna, the Trophies music, the list goes on.

games.name: Metroid: Zero Mission
review: This is where Zero Suit Samus comes from! This complete reimagining of the original Metroid, complete with an extra story at the end where Samus loses her suit. This game is so fucking good it's wild. It's been completely redone so doesn't have bullshit NES nonsense in there, but still features the OG story, Ridley, Kraid etc. Everything you could ever want.

games.name: F-Zero X
review: Awesome racing game! Maybe the first time I've felt like I'm going FAST! It's kinda hard though I won't lie, I remember not getting very far as a child. Later in the game there is this stage called the Big Hand which makes Rainbow Road look pathetic. There this game actually has its own Rainbow Road too!
The hard rock soundtrack is actually great. It's not my style at all but it's all bangers.

games.name: Donkey Kong Country
review: Talk about all-time classics! This is the best looking game on SNES, they made some kind of black magic happen for it. That being said, I actually played through this much later using an emulator. It's so good! I adore the music and environments in this game. This is where David Wise saw that he had to write a track for a gorilla riding a dolphin underwater and decided to compose the best video game music ever, aquatic ambience. Insane.

games.name: Into the Breach
review: This is a super fun puzzle game where you know exactly what will happen next turn. So you have to be super smart and engineer the perfect turn using your smarts and creativity. Over multiple turns your mistakes sometimes compound and it gets stressful. Also there's a roguelike structure to this which I don't really vibe with. I should come back to it at some point I think it's really good.

games.name: Croc 2
review: This game means so much to me that I have it hung up on the wall in my house. I played the shit out of this on my brother's playstation! The music is so fucking good and the moment I start listening to it I am immediately transported back. Just the happy vibes of Sailor Village... means so much. My faves are definitely the Mine, Roger Red Ant and Venus Fly Von Trappe, which literally plagiarises Shocking Blue's Venus.
The main theme was a meme between me and friends for a long time, because it's so repetitive and hypnotic, and arguably bad. I love how croc always shouts KER-SPLAT!

games.name: Celeste
review: This is a beautiful platformer about climbing a mountain, but it's actually about overcoming your mental health issues while making a significant transition in your life. Possibly it's a reference to the trans experience! It's stunning and simple and beautiful. The music is 10/10 - thanks to this soundtrack I became a mega fan of Lena Raine who composed it.

The game itself is a hardcore, hard as nails platformer which takes no prisoners, but respawns you super quickly so it doesn't even feel that bad to die. The game just feels great and when you get good at it, it feels so good. There is also the stunning free DLC where she goes into a dreamlike space. Here the music is at its best. It's so hard. But so good

games.name: Super Smash Bros. for Wii U
review: This is it, this is the one which finally got me into the smash community! This had an actual functioning online mode where you could play 1 on 1 - I used to play this so much and got relatively good at the game by doing so! I was maining Yoshi at the start, then switched to Wii Fit Trainer (I mean they put in a yoga teacher, come on I have to play her), then to Donkey Kong, then back to Wii Fit Trainer, then to Peach. It was a real journey of discovery, and I was really bad!

Being bad didn't stop me going to my first tournament in Southampton and loving it after I accidentally qualified for a national tournament in Birmingham. I went with my friend Charlotte and this exposure to the community was hilarious. Entering into it with a female friend gave me a pretty unique perspective, I have to say. Fast-forward a bit and I'm organising my own tournaments in Saarland and eventually Berlin.

I loved the new additions to this game, the new characters and just all the new content. It finally felt like a modern game. We were also treated to another whole bunch of great remixes to enjoy. From this game the highlights were Gerudo Desert, Mute City, Magicant and so much more. This is what inspired me to start making those music mixes you can download in the music section of this website.

games.name: Animal Crossing: New Leaf
review: Amazing game that accompanied me through university times. I loved logging in every day to work on my beautiful town. The game looked better than ever, and was on a handheld again, which is perfect. I love Isabelle and all the new content. The characters are all very cute and fun.

Crucially, the soundtrack has been updated with new hourly themes and I love them so much. They have such a different vibe to the previous ones, it's its own special thing. That alone gives this game a special flavour that wasn't present in New Horizons. In this game you could somewhat customise the island which was awesome

games.name: Mario Kart Wii
review: A classic of the Wii era, I remember its release fondly. Some of the best tracks in series history in this game. Daisy Circuit is my vibe. Otherwise, Maple Treeway, Grumble Volcano, Bowser's Castle, Dry Dry Ruins, Koopa Cape are some of my faves. The music is so good!

There was a time when I was younger when I got really into the time trial mode. You could compare your scores with your registered friends and people online. I always tried to outdo my friends James and Peter, and when it came to Shy Guy Beach I got an insanely good time and made it onto the leaderboards using the Magikoopa. Otherwise you just know I got that 3 star rating and did everything this game had to offer. I was truly obsessed, which is why I look back at these tracks so fondly.
I loved playing as Koopa Troopa! And I fucking hated Funky Kong. Everyone online just played Funky Kong in the same motorbike because it's a top tier combo and I resented it so much.

games.name: Pokemon Diamond
review: Gen 4 really took things to the next level vibe-wise. An insanely beautiful soundtrack ('Lake', 'Eterna Forest', 'Pokemon League', and many more...) which is particularly jazzy, a straightforward but still fun story, a fun new batch of pokemon. I remember really wanting a Burmy so I got a friend to trade me one. It was called Cpt. Burmy. I also had Kricketune, Lumineon and even Bastiodon on my first team.

Who could forget facing the champion Cynthia with that beautiful piano music, and she just sends out a brand new pokemon Spiritomb which has no weaknesses, then fucking Milotic then fucking Garchomp which just destroyed everything. I remember trying so many times to beat her and finally doing it at my friend Oscar's house.

games.name: Paper Mario: The Thousand Year Door
review: An absolute banger and a classic. This game is so funny! You visit somewhere which isn't the Mushroom Kingdom so the environments are totally different to what you're used to. That they based it on Rogueport (best music) is kinda wild, and then you visit the trippy Boggly Woods to play pikmin, a floating fighting arena, an Agatha Christie murder mystery on a train, the genuinely creepy Twilight Town (great music), even the fucking moon. So much to enjoy!
As far as I'm concerned this is the ultimate Mario RPG I think they knocked it out of the water.

games.name: Rampage
review: Wow, we used to play this all the time as kids! It's literally just destroying buildings, and eventually you stop and start again. It's just pure fun honestly. Destruction makes for good gameplay.

games.name: Mother 3
review: This is without a doubt my favourite RPG. It's a beautiful and heartwrenching story about societal change, family, and technology. This game goes places, and quickly! In chapter 1 an unexpected and horrible twist awaits you, with the most amazing music to accompany it. Chapter 3 puts you in the POV of a monkey who is tortured and enslaved for entertainment. Chapter 6 well, if you know you know. Chapter 8, right at the end of this Japan-only obscure-ass game, is New Pork City, the stage from Smash! Incredible that New Pork City of all places is represented in Smash.

This game's vibe is so immaculate. It's whole thing with sunflowers definitely kicked off my love for them. I love sunflowers so much that I got one tattooed on me! But what makes this game truly special is its soundtrack. It sounds unlike anything else and I am obsessed. Over in the music section of this website you can find the mixes I made - I did a mix of this soundtrack and just put every single track in, resulting in an almost 3-hour extravaganza. It's just that good.

I really encourage any readers of this site to consider playing Mother 3! Tragically it was never localised in English, but it's very easy to get a fan translation. Best is playing on original hardware, because the battles feature a rhythm game system which works better with buttons, but emulation on your PC will work fine too. Do yourselves a favour and get to know where this obscure smash character Lucas comes from, it's well worth your time.

games.name: Donkey Kong 64
review: I will never forget the pure delight I experienced as a child when my brother's friend offhand told me that I could have his copy of Donkey Kong 64. For me it was like a magical perfect game and suddenly I got to play it! I was absolutely enchanted with it. I loved all of the locations, I loved spending time going round with all the characters collecting a bunch of shit. I adored the music, the nonsense minigames, the jank. I accepted all the bullshit this game has to offer with grace because it was magical. I loved Lanky Kong and also Tiny Kong. Crystal Caves was my favourite level, possibly because I didn't know about it for many years! When I eventually got all the golden bananas, it felt like a monumental achievement. And can we talk about the legendary soundbite 'Ohhhhh banana!'. Classic.

I understand that it's a bad game. I get it. Looking back, I get it. But just understand that this game has a very special place in my heart because I loved it as a child so much. I played this before I played Super Mario 64 or Banjo Kazooie so you can imagine the impact it had.

games.name: Donkey Kong Country 2: Diddy's Kong Quest
review: This might be one of the few games I've actually played on the SNES! I was always missing it but when a friend in Saarland gave me his SNES I just popped in the game and played through! These games are really hard, especially without save states, and I will be completely transparent I didn't complete it, because I no longer have the patience I did as a child.
Anyway the reason this game is so legendary is of course the soundtrack. Hello, Stickerbrush Symphony? Insane.

games.name: Portal
review: What a fantastic concept! You can do so much with it, and this game does! You shoot these portals and can seamlessly travel through them. It's amazing that game can render the other side of the portal, it must have been a technical nightmare. This game is at its core a puzzle game, and I love puzzle games. Coupled with a cute and simple story with the iconic Glados, you've got a hit!

games.name: Gex 3: Deep Cover Gecko
review: Mate this game has everything. You can dress up as sherlock holmes and solve a mystery in a haunted mansion. In said mansion you can also turn into a vampire and fly! You can kill evil santa, fire cannons from a pirate ship, fly around as a superhero, become a greek god who maybe says 'I'm well hard' (at least that's what we thought as kids). There was this really difficult climbing the beanstalk level. Actually the greek level was the hardest. And I loved the vibe of the western world which has you on a massive pile of shit at one point. And I love Gex's one liners, like in the Christmas world: 'It's pretty, alright. Pretty cold!'. A classic.
I never understood why the box art and the cutscenes feature a human woman as the damsel in distress. What the fuck. Why does this have to be a sex thing.

games.name: Super Mario Odyssey
review: This game is so much fun and also super accessible for everyone, so I always recommend it. It might be the pinnacle of 3d platforming. It's so much fun to control Mario as he jumps and does all these crazy tricks with the hat in the air. And I love how you just go around and find a bunch of moons everywhere. Some easy, some hard. It's just satisfying.

I really enjoy all the worlds in the game. Some of them combine tropes (like Sand Kingdom has a Mexican-style town, Egyptian pyramids and Western-style music), but others have brand new ideas, like Steam Gardens or the Volcano level. My personal favourite is the Seaside Kingdom. First it looks stunning with the bubbly water. Who came up with the idea of a sea made of sprudel? Inspired. And the music is pure bossa nova bliss. The best beach music ever made.

They went all out on Bowser's Kingdom, and even added in fun, small kingdoms in between like the insane Ruined Kingdom. And I love that they gave Mario different outfits for once! Including my favourite 'nipples Mario'.

games.name: Paper Mario: Color Splash
review: This game is bad, and it wasn't good enough for me to actually sit through and finish it. They tried to 'innovate' the Paper Mario series again, and for yet another time it didn't work. This battle system is plain and boring. No good. The vibes aren't so great because all the characters look the same! All the Toads are the same, all the Shy Guys are the same.
However, there is one thing that is really good about this game, and that's the dialogue. There are some hilarious lines in this game.

games.name: Kirby: Planet Robobot
review: Genuinely one of the best Kirby games ever. This is when I realised just how mighty modern Kirby soundtracks are. Whoever is in charge of composing must spend so much time to make such rich and dense music. It really has its own special flair that is instantly recognisable as Kirby, AND they add all the mechanical/robot vibes seamlessly into it as well.

The game itself is super polished and fun, and these amazing boss fights. I don't think I'll ever forget the final boss either, which feels like an insane set piece. Kirby even copies the Halberd! Anything in order to deliver the classic Kirby cosmic horror final boss. Love it.
I also love that this game made a poison-type copy ability. That was my favourite for some reason.

games.name: Kirby's Epic Yarn
review: This game is way too easy! If you fall into a hole, you just lose some gems and that's it. It's meant to be a peaceful, mellow game, but it's so easy to the point where it's boring. I think there was potential for a yarn-based chill out kirby game if they made a good soundtrack, but this music is very generic and just sounds bad. There are some alright remixes of classic kirby tracks but nothing too noteworthy. Yoshi's Woolly World was way better.

games.name: Chrono Trigger
review: It's a classic, what can I say. Originally on the SNES but I played it while I was doing my masters in Saarland when I borrowed my friend Stefan's DS copy. I love all the characters, especially Robo and Ayla, the battle system is pretty fun too. Sometimes it was really hard and there this one boss in the middle which actually had me stuck to the point where I took a break. Glad I finished it though.

The music is insanely good. Corridors of Time, Schala's Theme, Mystery of the Forest, need I say more. Also a legendary battle theme, and a bunch of underrated huge hits like Undersea Palace. Guys, play this game if only to experience the soundtrack.

games.name: Pikmin
review: The original Pikmin is everything. It's a very special vibe indeed. It's quite dark and creepy, but also very beautiful. It's so kooky and idiosyncratic. The music and design of the creatures really reflects that. Also, the premise is wild. But I like that it's a very Nintendo-y real time stategy game.

There's a 30-Day time limit which is super terrifying. It feels like no time at all, but actually it's very easy to collect everything before 30 days. Games really do big game-long time limits like this after Pikmin, for good reason. It's super stressful! But this game is still resonating vibes so much harder than all the other games in the series.

There are so many great moments. The Beady Long Legs, being completely submerged with blue pikmin, the weird goo creature in the starting area, the Smoky Progg, the slideshow of all the creatures in the credits sequence. So much to love. This game is also very janky and is missing a lot of the quality of life stuff that Pikmin 4 really nails. Sometimes it's so hard to whistle all your pikmin, sometimes the pikmin just fall over while running and you have to wait for them, sometimes they just fucking die.

games.name: Wario Land 4
review: Huge game. This is one of the best 2D platformers ever! Not only does it feel super fun to move with Wario, but it's got this really good mechanic where you get to the end of the level, hit a switch, and then have to run back out of the level before everything blows up.

Let me tell you, the music that plays when you hit that switch is so intense. It's honestly super scary. Otherwise I also love the music for the levels. It's got that Wario Ware vibe but also nice, full-length tracks. Highlights are definitely Crescent Moon Village and Monsoon Jungle. I loved this game and completed the shit out of it multiple times.

games.name: Conker's Bad Fur Day
review: This is the most unhinged game to have ever existed. It's a game from the developers of classics like Banjo Kazooie and Donkey Kong 64, but it's aimed towards adults. It has tons of references to sex, drugs and rock 'n' roll, with the humour being extremely British. I played this on an emulator in the Wii days, and I don't think I got that far into it because it's not actually a good game.
I remember singing along to the 'great mighty poo', and will never forget the booby flower. I think I want to take mushrooms and play this while stoned. I feel like it would be hilarious.

games.name: Earthbound
review: Thank you Sakurai and thank you Smash Bros for including Ness so that I played this awesome game. It's got so much random shit going on! I love all the weird shit in the Mother series and this game arguably has the most.

This game is quite dark, even though it's jokey on the surface. True to form for this series, it dissolves into nightmare fuel by the end of the game. I really like the whole part where you go into the past and hear that shocking music as you approach Giygas. I remember playing this together with my friend Claire and she was truly shook by the imagery of this last part. I mean I hate to spoil the game a bit but if you play the game, you understand. Honestly, Giygas is very yonic and is very much giving 'vagina', and I totally agree with all the theories that the swirling red shape is a fetus. It becomes very shocking with the screen starts glitching and Paula starts praying. Like wow this game didn't need to go this hard.

I love the soundtrack so much. I love the battle music, it's so fucking weird. And the Sanctuary Guardian music is so wild, who came up with this as the boss music? It's so moody and I love it. There's this part where you get a bike and this awesome music plays. Except you can only ride a bike for a short while because soon after you get other party members who don't have bikes, so you can't ride it anymore. There's this amazing part where you have some coffee and this trippy music plays and you receive a pep talk about how far you've come so far. I love the music for Onett, Twoson, Threed and Fourside, and many other places. And huge shoutouts to 'Because I Love You', which plays everywhere after you beat the game. You can go back and talk to everyone in the game while listening to it, and they have some little gem of wisdom to share before you go home. It's beautiful. And 'Smiles and Tears', the credit song? Ugh. Amazing.

games.name: Portal 2
review: A super fun puzzle game that I loved! This one is so much bigger than the previous one, which huge expansive areas, tons of new mechanics and fun shit. This one also massively expands on the story and it's delightful. Honestly this game is kinda iconic. Also, it has this amazing multiplayer mode of which I have fond memories. Me and a flatmate Heather would play it in our student halls of residence, in the hallway so we could connect our computers somehow. The puzzle where you crash both robots in the air against each other? Genius.

games.name: OFF
review: This game was a popular indie game that is really giving Undertale, before Undertale even existed. It's way more creepy and atmospheric though. It feels like it was made with love which is cool and has a lot of cool imagery. I didn't make it very far in the game for some reason, hard to say why. I remember playing it in French (the original language) because I wanted to practice the language.

games.name: Farmville
review: This was the first major game to exist with microtransactions. At first, I was excited. It's a facebook game that EVERYONE was playing. It was so cool growing my plants and visiting all my facebook friends' farms to get rewards. I got hooked. Eventually though, more and more people at school quit it because they saw it for what it really was: a soulless money making scheme. I eventually got the memo and deleted it, but not before I spend 5 pounds on a decorative tea house for my farm. Why the fuck did I do that? It was an eye opening moment that really turned me off of games with microtransactions forever after.

games.name: Fishville
review: Another horrible facebook game that I played parallel to Farmville. No soul, no life, just a young me not yet understanding the power of microtransactions.

games.name: Insaniquarium
review: It's a browser game from Addicting Games dot com or something. It was great. A special time when there was just these flash or java games on the computer. This was the first time I ever played a browser game and I remember being blown away that it could remember how my aquarium looked without saving anything. That's the day I learned what cookies were.

games.name: Cookie Clicker
review: It's an idle game about making as many cookies as possible and it's really good. You can just get started on it already but make sure you don't play at work! I consider this the ultimate idle game

games.name: Universal Paperclips
review: It's an idle game about making as many paperclips as possible. I think this ends up being a commentary on AI. An AI, having been told to create as many paperclips as possible, will destroy humanity in order to do so.

games.name: Plague Inc
review: A game about spreading a deadly virus and killing everyone. I enjoyed playing this for a bit, it taught me about infectiousness and deadliness. I remember failing to infect Greenland because I thought they were insignificant but they ended up successfully isolating there and survived the plague.

games.name: Yeti Sports
review: A bizarre collection of games where a yeti does some extreme sports. It's all very weird and not good or anything but it was a serious conversation topic in primary school.

games.name: Falling Sand
review: This is a sick browser game which I had a lot of fun fucking around with. Physics! I feel like this little game is timeless. You can still play it here.

games.name: Flea Circus
review: I was so obsessed with Runescape that I visited the website of Jagex, the people who made it and sent them emails and shit. I also found this other game they had on there which is somethign like a tech demo. I loved it! Maybe this was the birth of my love of puzzle games. It was well hard.

games.name: Microsoft Pinball Arcade
review: This is such a throwback. I loved this, even though I never truly understood how to do well in it. I have a strong memory of playing this at my grandparent's house in France, having an insane run and asking myself how the fuck did I do that? At the same time, my brothers were in my room and called me 'fart boy' because I farted in my sleep all the time. I got upset and cried

games.name: Microsoft Hearts
review: I enjoyed playing this against the computer on Windows XP. This is a family favourite card game so I was good at it, even as a child.

games.name: Microsoft Solitaire
review: I loved playing this on Windows XP when I was bored. I really enjoyed the different images on the cards, especially the beach theme.

games.name: Words with Friends
review: A mobile game where you can play crosswords with your friends asynchronously! I played with my friend Charlotte and my mum and it was great. I always won and it was awesome. Scrabble still a great board game.

games.name: Bubble Trouble
review: This was a flash game from miniclip.com that I enjoyed, but playing it back now, it's total bullshit. Still, shoutouts to whoever made this for doing something new I guess.

games.name: Club Penguin
review: I didn't truly engage with Club Penguin but I dipped my toes in. I enjoy that it became a meme later down the line. I remember there not being anything to do there.

games.name: The Impossible Quiz
review: It's that old internet humour which back then, I 100% subscribed to. Playing this now I'm just immediately not interested in playing because it's total bullshit. But back then there weren't actual good games on the internet so I just bashed my head against this until I beat it. Also playing it now I'm asking myself, did the original have the Rocky theme tune in the background? It did, right? I have no way of checking that.

games.name: Cyber Mice Party 2003
review: I have a core memory of this flash game. Sometimes when I'm killing time and I have objects on a desk in front of me, I imagine the mice moving between the objects. Still to this day I think about it.

games.name: Minesweeper
review: Who didn't play the OG minesweeper on their Windows XP computer. This shit was so good. The excitement of finding a 4, the misery of the 50/50. The drama

games.name: Bug on a Wire
review: I can't say how this old flash game I found on miniclip.com ended up having such impeccable vibes, but it just does and we all have to accept that. The music is so good, it makes me feel like this bug's journey is truly endless. The premise of this game is wild. Why does the bug need to get over there so quickly? The game always ends at the same point because the difficulty spike is insane but for those two minutes, I feel some kind of peace.

games.name: Red Beard
review: For me a very formative platformer. I remember playing this on miniclip on the primary school library computers.

games.name: Twiddlestix
review: THIS is where I recognised Kuru Kuru Kururin from!! There was this nagging feeling at the back of my mind that I'd seen it before and lo and behold, this flash game I played on miniclip way back when was a blatent rip off of it. I played it again just now and it's so much worse than Kuru. The game concept is still great though so you should go play Kuru on the Nintendo Switch online!

games.name: Roller Coaster Tycoon 3
review: What a downgrade from the originals! The vibes are off and the game performs badly. Since then the series has nosedived, sad.

games.name: Line Rider
review: Genuinely fantastic game for your desktop! I spent ages making the most bomb-ass tracks for this little dude to ride down. It's all about momentum and controlling his speed. You can also add environment lines which don't affect the course which change everything. Suddenly, it becomes art. I know that many artists have uploaded amazing linerider tracks to youtube with beautiful drawing and sometimes even synced to music. So good. So much respect for Line Rider.

games.name: The Classroom
review: This is a seemingly innocent game about stealthing past the teacher to copy the answers of a smart person in a school exam without being seen. Except it has this FUCKED UP ending where there's a school shooting and you have to use your stealth skills to avoid the shooter. Looking back, fucking wild.

games.name: Kellogg's Frosties Gr-r-rand Prix
review: This is some copy and paste racing sim game from the deep depths of my memory. I remember playing it because it came in a box of frosties.

games.name: Lego Racers
review: My friend Tim loved this game and he's so right. Looking back, this had so much wild shit in it, like actual shortcuts. Mario Kart could never. You can build your own cart and that was the coolest fucking thing back then.

games.name: Snake
review: I mean it's a classic and when I had a Nokia, you know I was all over this game while waiting for the bus or something

games.name: Flow Free
review: A shitty mobile game I played about connecting dots. Really hard to find this one because of all the identical clones on the app store. What even is mobile gaming anymore

games.name: The Legend of Zelda: Oracle of Seasons
review: I liked it! This game is just like Link's Awakening but with more content. The seasons mechanic is fun and in general I enjoyed it more than Oracle of Ages. It's worth your time.

games.name: ARMS
review: This is actually one of the ultimate party games and nobody can convince me otherwise. The concept of having springy arms and fighting like that is hilarious, why the fuck not, and the game is wacky enough to make it fun. Also, in terms of being a competitive fighting game, it's surprisingly deep! Infinite different combinations of arms mean lots of strategies and stuff like that. I once commentating an online ARMS tournament and learned so much shit about all the different strats, it was sick. Tragically the scene isn't too big so getting good at the game isn't really a thing but it remains a hilarious party game (with motion controls of course).

Personally I enjoyed Lola Pop, even though she's the most basic character with no lore. She's just a clown who likes sweets and can inflate like a balloon like Lanky Kong. I also LOVE the main theme with the choir, what an absolute banger. There are also a number of other choice tracks in the soundtrack, like the credits theme or Mechanica's level. I made a mix for it, you can download it in the music section!

games.name: Pokken Tournament
review: This is a Pokemon fighting game which was very exciting at the time. When it came down to playing it, like with all fighting games, I didn't find time to get good. I played a bit with friends and enjoyed maining Machamp, but the truth is I love obscure pokemon and my faves aren't really represented. That being said, wow, Machamp is so ugly and I love him. I also didn't vibe with the 3d & 2d combination. And the music and vibes isn't really great.

games.name: Tomodachi Life
review: I was completely sold by this game when they did a mini Nintendo direct for it way back when. It was genuinely hilarious! This game has that special Nintendo humour that you can also see in WarioWare or Wii Sports. I love it. It's just so random. The stuff they come up with, is just so good. And then you get to put your own miis and your own little inputs and it's just hilarious. You can even make the miis sing songs and you can write lyrics for them. It's just so good. I loved making my friends and watching them get up to ridiculous shenanigans.
I do remember not playing the game for very long though, because a lot of the content starts repeating quite quickly. There isn't all that much to do.

games.name: Donkey Kong Country Returns
review: Alright alright this game doesn't quite reach the heights of Tropical Freeze but it's still a top-class 10/10 game. It looks great and is a beautiful reimagining of how DKC looks, the music is pretty good and the game is full of great moments. The spider level is genuinely scary, the factory levels are super cool, World 4 is just the super fun minecart and rocket barrel levels, which are great, and this game invented the amazing silhouette levels. The sunset level was so inspiring that I painted a picture of it for my house.

The game is also one of the best platformers ever, the rolling mechanic is so cool, because if you jump from a roll you keep the momentum, and it lets you fly through levels at breakneck speeds. After you beat the game you can try and speedrun the levels for these medals and I loved doing that! This was one of the only times I really got into the doing things fast aspect of gaming. Otherwise generally the game is kinda hard with only 2 health points. I remember this game taught me to git gud at platformers.

Also this game is great because everything has a sensible context. Like there are no floating platforms, but rather all the platforms are part of other structures that make sense in the context of the level. And you have to really pay attention to the environment because there are these puzzle pieces hidden everywhere in secret nooks and crannies. Man, this game also taught me to find secrets! By the end I was able to spot all the clues for hidden areas like it was nothing. Platformers since this game have got nothing on me, I can find all the secrets. Unless they're bullshit. Luckily, in this game secrets are never bullshit, they are always somehow signposted. Great game design, love it

games.name: Pokemon White 2
review: This game is super good! It takes the already fantastic Black and White and adds more stuff. Some highlights are the revamped gyms, I love them, especially the electric gym, and the new poison and water gyms. Shoutouts to some of the new music too, Virbank city and Colress's battle music. So good.

I don't think this game hits quite as hard as the first one, partly because we know this region now, and this time round there are old pokemon too. I remember having a Drapion on my team, a beautifully ugly pokemon. I don't remember too much about the story, I guess it doesn't hit quite as hard as the first game's story, which is the only actual notable story in the whole series.

games.name: The Simpsons Hit & Run
review: Wow, this game is a huge vibe! I loooooved it. 7 levels where you get to play as a bunch of different characters (including the kids because this is america) driving around and causing trouble, GTA-style. It's so fun! I remember driving around for so long just enjoying the open world, full of all the places from the cartoon. I loved all the silly jokes lifted directly from the cartoon as well.
I'm certain this game isn't as good as I remember and I specifically remember some of the zombie missions at the end was super hard, but whatever. The vibes are definitely there!

games.name: Pokemon Mystery Dungeon: Red Rescue Team
review: Where do I even begin, this game means so much to me it's insane. I have many core memories associated with buying this game. Oscar and I took the train to Reading with the express purpose of buying this. On the way back to Cholsey we started the game and I even named my two main pokemon after train stations close to home: Tilehurst (Cubone) and Pangbourne (Squirtle). When I had to make a team name I thought 'Tileteam' would be great because I was called Tilehurst, but then it called it 'Team Tileteam', which I also ended up loving, fuck it.

There's so much to love here!! You actually play at the pokemon for once, incredible. An actual story, not the very weak story of normal mainline games, and an entirely new kind of game that I'd never seen before. I loved it. I remember having a third party member, a Ledyba called Mavis who was genuinely an excellent addition to the team because she knew a confuse move. I was devastated when the two main guys go on a solo trip half way through because I couldn't bring Mavis along. But I was delighted when I beat the game and saw that there was a ton of other stuff to do, and now I could evolve all my pokemon! So good!
The vibes of this game are immaculate. The music is great. The finale with the Sky Tower is just fantastic. I loved it. There's also a remake of this which I highly recommend.

games.name: Mario Kart 64
review: Vibes for this game are off the charts. If you want to learn more about the vibes of this game, check out the Mario Kart rankings that I made. I've written pretty extensively about all the original tracks there. It's something I care about a lot and I feel that this game really nails a fantastic and fun vibe, more so than most Mario Kart games.

The title theme alone is enough to get you excited. It's a classic! And then there are a bunch of fantastic tracks like Toad's Turnpike, Rainbow Road, Bowser's Castle, Sherbet Land, Koopa Troopa Beach. The soundtrack to all of these is great.

I will say there are some duds in there too, like Wario Stadium or Choco Mountain, but whatever. Also I don't feel like the drifting is very good in this game. I don't have much control over the kart.

games.name: Super Metroid
review: My first Metroid game! I loved it. I love the opening section, and I love how when you land on the planet, you have to walk left, not right! It's a foreshadowing that in this game you're going to have to explore everywhere in order to progress. And doing that is hard! There were many points when I was stuck here. But when you do eventually figure something out and get a new power-up, it's the best feeling ever.

Music-wise this has some of the most iconic music in the series. I'm talking Brinstar Green and Brinstar Red, both classics. Theme of Samus, Maridia, even the fucking Mother Brain music is iconic. It's so insane and scary. It's a scary game!
Together with Zero Mission I really recommend this one for Metroid beginners. Also following the speed-run scene for this is super interesting.

games.name: Psychonauts
review: This is a game for kids! Luckily, I was a kid when I played this. I remember enjoying it a lot and completing it. I really enjoyed Milla's dance party, which might have been a sign that I was gay. The game had lots of super fun worlds to explore and despite its jank it had a lot of heart. It was made with love. I'm not sure if I played it again today I would enjoy it but my rose-tinted glasses say it was great.

games.name: Rayman
review: We had this on the playstation and I remember constantly restarting the game, I'm not sure if it's because we were unable to save for some reason, or if the game was just hard as balls and we ran out of lives all the time. I feel like it was the latter! I suffered so many times through the first levels, and then the nightmarish music-themed area. On occasion I would reach the blue mountains but never get further than that. I threw myself over and over at this game but it didn't relent, I just kept dying and dying.

It was all OK though because I was a child and had endless patience for bad games. Now much of the game art is ingrained into my brain as core memories. Even writing this review got me a little emotional and nostalgic remembering the mosquito boss, the look of the blue crystals, punching the cages. I loved this game so much.

games.name: Sonic Mania
review: By far my favourite sonic game, Sonic Mania takes that classic 2D sonic and elevates it to one of the best games ever. It consists of 12 zones, 8 reimaginings of old ones, and 4 new ones, and they're all fucking great. The new ones, Studiopolis, Press Garden, Mirage Saloon and Titanic Monarch are all 10/10 they just smashed it. They look fantastic and the music is top notch. The MUSIC!!!

The music was made by Tee Lopes who was actually a youtuber who posted remixes of the classic sonic tracks. Somehow he ended up writing the music for an official Sonic game and he fucking knocked it out of the park. He also remixed all these old tracks with such love, and for the new act 2 versions of a few of them, went ham on a remixed version of them. I just adore Green Hill's act 2, as well Oil Ocean's. The Sonic CD tracks are so fun and different, and then there's the Sonic 3 tracks which are very faithful.
I have played through this game so many times I just love it.

games.name: Fire Emblem Echoes: Shadows of Valentia
review: Arguably one of the very best Fire Emblems! This fun 3DS game changed up the mechanics big time, voice acted the whole thing, and it was a huge success! The music is amazing, and even the story is great, which is surprising since this is a remake of an old-as-balls game on the NES, out only in Japan. Still, Alm & Celica are great protagonists, and it's fun that they get split up and have their own little teams with them.

It also came with these weird 3D dungeons, but they weren't very good. I also feel like some of the battle maps are kinda boring and could have been updated. In terms of layout they are very faithful to the original which in my view (in this case) is totally unnecessary.

games.name: Metroid Prime Trilogy
review: Incredible that they packaged all three games together in one! Such value for money! I played this later in life when I was living in Saarland, and I'm so glad I did. Metroid Prime 1 is an all-time classic. Incredible how they took the metroidvania principle and translated it perfectly into 3D. It's just so fun and the vibes are so strong. I also played Metroid Prime 2 and loved it. Maybe it's a little less iconic but it's still got all that good stuff.

Metroid Prime 3 I didn't resonate with, it was way more combat-heavy and less exploration-y. I ended up not finishing it, which I regret, but I've since read online that lots of people feel the same way. Despite this, I'm giving the trilogy a perfect score because it contains Metroid Prime 1, which is one of the greatest games ever.

games.name: The Legend of Zelda: Spirit Tracks
review: This game's whole thing was that you drive a train around, which honestly wasn't all that. This train gameplay wasn't really speaking to me, even if the music for it is great. That being said I'm glad this game improved on Phantom Hourglass so much. It's easy to forget but this was controlled entirely with the DS stylus and it fucking worked!
That being said, I never truly loved this game.

games.name: SSX 3
review: Wow I played this so fucking much it's insane. This game was so fun! Going fast, doing tricks, and all the racetracks were so cool. They were even all connected together on the mountain! And it was possible to do races from the very peak to the city at the bottom, and I thought that was the coolest shit ever. No loading zones or anything!
So funny how in this game you can just jump and do a flip without a ramp or anything.
It has a licenced soundtrack and this is legit how I got into a bunch of new music. I will always be grateful to SSX 3 for introducing me to Röyksopp's 'Poor Leno'. Beautiful

games.name: WarioWare, Inc.: Mega Microgame$!
