review: Can we talk about how this game was really the first 'weird nintendo humour' game? The moment we in the west realised just how much weird shit the Japanese find funny. Personally I love it, and I think this is the predecessor to things like Tomodachi Life. The weird shit they make you do in this game is so out there and wild, I can't help but love it. The minigames are all about 4 seconds long, and it's about reacting to them quickly. Except you have to fight your bafflement and just do it without asking why you're making a lady sniff her snot, or why you're skiing down a mountain all of a sudden, or why you need to pick a nose.

The idiosyncratic and off-kilter vibe extends also into the soundtrack, which is honestly all over the place. I especially adore 'Drifting Away', one of the few times there is a music track that lasts longer than 4 seconds, which is a melancholic song (song! it's a gba game!) playing on the taxi stage. Suddenly it's such a vibe. I love it.

I played this game a lot when I was younger. I went through the individual games and got the little badges for all of them, even though at higher speeds they are insanely difficult. I've also come back to this game many times throughout the years because it's just so good. I'm just a fan of WarioWare, what can I say.

games.name: Jurassic Park
review: I have a vague memory of playing this game. It's hard as balls but the velociraptors were cool.

games.name: Pokemon Stadium
review: I loooooooooved being able to see all my favourite pokemon in 3D like this!! I can't describe how exciting that was. Being able to fully visualise the pokemon just like in the cartoon was just amazing. I remember loving making little teams of all my favourite pokemon and playing through the gyms and other battles. There was a cool rental system where you could take any pokemon at level 50, with inevitably shit moves, but whatever, it was its own kind of challenge trying to beat the game with these shit pokemon. During this time I didn't have the hardware to connect my gameboy to the N64 so the rentals were all I had but I was satisfied.
Looking back, the battles were insanely long with these long and drawn out animations, so I wouldn't play it again, but I have many fond memories. Also, the minigames were excellent. Truly fantastic.

games.name: The Legend of Zelda: A Link to the Past
review: I mean it's a classic. This old-ass game still holds up SO WELL! You can sit down and play through it today and still enjoy it to the max because it just nails it in terms of gameplay. There are times where you might be lost or confused, but largely this game is very well constructed and will help you find the way. For the time it was of course revolutionary, but also today it's just great. It's also the blueprint for so many adventure games that came after it.

It's also got a lot of fun quirks, like turning into a rabbit and other weird shit. A super fun part is how the world transforms into a 'dark world' just when you think you're done with the game and then the REAL game begins.
The music is also legendary. Dark World music is 10/10, and there are loads of other hidden gems there too. So much to love.

games.name: Sid Meier's Civilization IV
review: I had some great times playing this over LAN with mates from school! We would meet up and just power through a campaign together and it was awesome. Looking back, it was kinda flawed because after like one hour it became clear who was gonna win and we were all just forced to keep playing anyway. We were also too scared to wage war in case we harm our friendships. Still. It was fun!

If you care about these things, we always played the 'Beyond the Sword' expansion. I never got into Civ 5 or 6 I just stuck with what I knew always. I actually really like real time strategy, it's just that they cost so much time, so I haven't made much time for them over the years.
Also I want to shout out this game's soundtrack. Thanks to this game I got to know my favourite symphony, the 'Scheherezade'.

games.name: Tetris 99
review: I heavily associate this game with my relationship with Ichsan way back when, we both really loved it. This might be the best way to play Tetris! You play against 99 other players simultaneously in a battle royale type situation. I've won it a couple of times!

games.name: Yoshi's Woolly World
review: Can we talk about how they fucking nailed it in terms of taking the cutest character ever and making the cutest ever game? Making everything knitted is a stroke of genius and it works so well. It's the ultimate cosy game. Kirby's Epic Yarn can eat its heart out, it's got nothing compared to this! Just the way the fabric moves softly under yoshi's feet - delightful. I love the different coloured yoshis you can play as, and all the amiibo yoshis too.

I also really enjoy the soundtrack. It's not perfect front to back but it's very on theme and some of them are stunning. There's this one track near the end which is beautiful for no reason. Devastating that the smash bros stage based on this game was cut from smash ultimate.

games.name: Metroid: Samus Returns
review: This was the first proper Metroid game we got in ages and it's so good! It's a remake of Metroid 2 on the gameboy, which wasn't a great by itself. This remake totally redeems it and makes it super fun and atmospheric at the same time. I loved the 3d backgrounds on the 3DS and Samus looks like a badass in this game. There's also a fun twist on the ending which I lapped up because I'm a sucker for nintendo fan service.

The timing of this is a bit unfortunate because just prior to this, a fan game called Another Metroid 2 Remake was released, a really good labour of love by a single hobby developer. That game is also great and I had just played it before this was announced but... this actual official remake really tops it in every way.
I love the new parry mechanic, and also being able to aim anywhere makes a big difference when it comes to 2D metroid. Shoutouts also to the Brinstar Red remix half way through the game. Love it.

games.name: The Legend of Zelda: Skyward Sword
review: Skyward Sword is by far the most hilarious Zelda game and I do mean that with love. I mean, yes, I'm laughing at the game, because it's ridiculous and funny, but I love it. The characters all look so ugly, and I really love ugly things, so I just can't help it. It's also very camp for so many reasons. Those dragons? Fucking Ghirahim?? Coming up behind Link and licking him? This is some queer ass shit and I'm here snapping my fingers at the screen in delight.

Just the motion controls alone are hilarious. You run around with your sword raised like a madman and it never ceases to be funny. When he slashes it's like a total lunatic. The enemies wait there holding their shields in a certain direction patiently while you grapple with the controls. Love it.

OK but genuinely this game does have some of the best dungeons in the series, my favourite being the Ancient Cistern, literally a giant toilet. The vibes of that place are great. The soundtrack of this game is also super strong. Lanayru Sand Sea is an all-time favourite Zelda music track for sure.

Just to vent a bit though I will say that there's nothing to do in the flying around the sky sections, and it really bothered me that you fly around this cloudy place with only clouds below you, but then you land on the surface, look up, and there are no clouds. WTF.

games.name: Rhythm Paradise
review: What a banger game! This is probably the very first rhythm game I ever played and what an introduction to the genre it is. It's got that WarioWare-style kookiness and I love it. It's just so random. I never was able to get perfects on all the mix levels and part of me still wants to go back and get good at this game again. Hm.

games.name: SSX Tricky
review: SSX 3 was more of my jam than this but I did play this too and I loved the music when you got the Tricky, whatever that means.

games.name: Golden Sun: The Lost Age
review: I never even played the first one but my friend Oscar lent me his copy of this. I didn't get into it because I was halfway through this weird story and didn't understand anything. It's a shame because this series is apparently amazing and I missed out on the opportunity to enjoy it as a child.

games.name: Pokemon Stadium 2
review: Yeeeeeees more of that Pokemon Stadium goodness, this time with gen 2 people as well! Words could not describe my excitement for this game when I was younger. The rental system was still there, loved it, but this time I actually hooked up my gameboy in an attempt to get some actual good pokemon with good moves. Turns out the main campaign's level is the same as your strongest pokemon, in my case my beloved level 71 Piloswine, so all the opponents were level 71, but that was my only good pokemon, the rest were all like level 40 or something. NONETHELESS having an imported pokemon was so strong that I was able to get through on the power of my beautiful Piloswine. As a child I was baffled and so very proud.
Then these minigames are arguably even better than the first game's ones. The counting one I loved, the falling eggs one as well. Class.

games.name: Kirby's Dream Land 3
review: A nice little piece of Kirby history here. I love the hand-drawn artstyle and it's really fun to play with the different animal friends, of which my favourite is the dumb looking fish. Especially of note is the wild and varied soundtrack. I would recommend this game to Kirby fans, it still totally holds up today.

games.name: Skullgirls 2nd Encore
review: We were talking about fighting games and I was interested in trying out a new one, and since my friend Pomi raved about this, I gave it a go. It's fun to play and I can definitely imagine spending time with it and getting good with it (I was vibing with Parasoul), however I simply don't have the time to get into another competitive game. It's a shame because I would really enjoy other fighting games but they just require way too much time.

Also this game is so wild, it's like boob physics the game. I'm personally not into the sexualised women characters only situation although I will say some of the characters have really fun ideas with their designs. I think the overall vibe is a bit too creepy for me though.

games.name: Wargroove
review: I played this because I was missing advance wars! It came out at a time when I hadn't played a strategy game like this in a while. However I felt that it doesn't reach the heights of advance wars. I got very close to the end but there were some really long and difficult and honestly boring missions towards the end which sadly made me give it up. I also feel like that soundtrack was very forgettable.
I will say one thing though, you can play as a dog in this game. A commander that is simply a dog. It's amazing. Fantastic.

games.name: Hyrule Warriors
review: I had never played or even heard of Dynasty Warriors so going into this was a bit of a shock. This is a thing? It's like a one-man-army situation where you go around mindlessly murdering hundreds of people while listening to metal remixes of Zelda songs. It's alright, and although I did complete it, it was a struggle, and it was during the dry Wii U years when there was nothing to play.
I remember vibing with Sheik the most. And I thoroughly enjoyed the oversexualised villain OC who makes orgasm noises all the time, pictured here.

games.name: Mario & Luigi: Superstar Saga + Bowser's Minions
review: I played the original as a child on my friend Oscar's game for a bit but never truly played it. I wanted to make up for that by buying the remake on the 3DS but I also didn't get into it. I got maybe halfway through and gave it a good try, but in the end this is a game for kids. If I'm gonna play a turn based RPG I'm gonna need some depth.
The vibes are good though. I love the dancing that the Mario bros do during battles.

games.name: Super Paper Mario
review: I love Super Paper Mario so much. People (me) complain that they keep changing Paper Mario and they should just make everything like the thousand year door, and they're (I'm) right, but this game is the exception, it's so different but so good. I love the speedy gameplay, the 3D puzzles, all the various locations.

The game's soundtrack is so nice. Just Flipside has its own very remarkable music that gives this game its unique vibe. From there Mario will go to space, an 8-bit land, a samurai tournament, all sorts of weird and wacky places. This isn't your standard Level 1, Level 2 affair!

Then you have a genuinely touching story with the fabulous Count Bleck and his minions, and a very threatening-looking and ever-growing black hole in the sky that promises to destroy all the worlds. At one point the black hole actually destroys the world and you go to literal hell. This game is unafraid to go there.

I love that you can play as Peach and Bowser and Luigi too. I loved the pit of 100 trials. I remember as a child I 100%'d this game, which is actually insane because I cooked every recipe in the cookbook. There is no reason to do that! It was an important turning point in my gaming career though. I stopped being a completionist that day.

games.name: Super Mario 64 DS
review: I may have played the original as a child first, but the DS is the first time I actually PLAYED played it. Like got all the stars and visited all the levels. I loved it. I loved that you start as Yoshi! How fun and subversive. I also love how you can collect the hats of other characters to briefly become them. I think that's what Donkey Kong 64 was missing.
Also this game with a bunch of banger minigames that we used to play using download play all the time. Loved it.

games.name: Star Wars Jedi Knight II: Jedi Outcast
review: I played this for a bit when I was younger, can't say why. I remember enjoying using the force to zap people.

games.name: Mario Kart Super Circuit
review: An underrated Mario Kart game! Yeah it looks worse than Mario Kart 64 which came before it, but it's soooo much better than Super Mario Kart on the SNES. After playing a bit it's quite easy to get good at drifting. And the stages, although flat, are fun! The soundtrack is also fantastic.

games.name: Kirby 64: The Crystal Shards
review: Look I know this is a fan favourite but let's be real this game looks like shit and the music sounds like shit. It breaks my heart because actually I'm a huge kirby fan but I only completed it for science. I looked up the O2 fight online because I ain't spending anymore time in this game that I need to.
Combining the copy abilities was inspired that. I loved that.

games.name: Super Bomberman
review: I have this on my SNES in my current apartment and still sometimes bring it out for party games when people are over. Bomberman is a banger and it's fun to have a version of it that's so quick to boot up and so retro. It's lucky that the battle music is so good because it just repeats and repeats, very loudly.

games.name: The Stanley Parable
review: This game has the same vibes as the TV show Severance. It's about meaningless work in a meaningless office. A incorporeal voice starts narrating your life and you start following this bizarre yellow line on the floor. Weird shit starts happening and it becomes clear this is some kind of nightmare. As the game goes on and you follow more yellow lines, or orders from the disembodied voice, things escalate and become more and more conceptual.

Honestly I didn't learn anything from this. I kinda expect to learn some life lessons from arty games like this but I was just baffled the whole time. At some point it started feeling like a waste of time.

games.name: Puyo Puyo Tetris
review: I have genuinely played this game so much it's wild. Me and my mates from home play it online a lot! Well not so much these days because the servers are so bad. We also exclusively play one multiplayer 'Swap' mode where it switches between Tetris and Puyo Puyo every 30 seconds or so. That's the only competitive mode I think.

Anyway it's bad in the sense that this mode only has one battle theme and the colours and vibe are all a bit too much. But the core gameplay is class and we have had loads of fun with this game. I even made a little side event thing for it at BREXIT SUMMIT 100.

games.name: Kirby and the Rainbow Curse
review: Talk about obscure Wii U games! Nothing could stop this Kirby fan and Wii U owner. I played through this game and genuinely enjoyed it. What makes this game special isn't the claymation aesthetic, the bizarre gameplay or the general cuteness, but its excellent soundtrack! I mean just listen to this track. It was of course made my Shogo Sakai, my favourite vgm composer (he did Mother 3 and the smash bros themes). There's even a jukebox with a bunch of banger remixes of classic kirby tracks. Love love love.

games.name: Mario Kart 7
review: Definitely the weakest Mario Kart game. They simply didn't pull through on the fun tracks or fun vibes. I think the stages on the handheld look kinda lame and empty. A lot of the music is really sub-par, considering how good Mario Kart music normally is. This game introduced ultra-boring stages like Mario Circuit and Daisy Hills, and my least favourite I think Cheep Cheep Lagoon, whose music is an affront to beach themes.
I borrowed this from my friend Andrew way back when and enjoyed it for a bit but apart from Rainbow Road and Wuhu Island this didn't have much to offer.

games.name: Mario Strikers Charged
review: I played this at my friend James' place after school sometimes. It was a lot of fun but I enjoyed playing Brawl more with James. I never appreciated how the opponent can score 5 goals at once if you fuck up the supergoal thing.
The vibes of this game are saved by Daisy, who is unafraid to scream at any time and I love her for that.

games.name: Professor Layton and the Curious Village
review: What a fun game! It's a collection of puzzles and I fucking love puzzle games. It's very peaceful and comes with a cute story. The cartoon aesthetics are top-notch, the music is fantastic, and the characters just great. Lots of enjoy!

games.name: Cel Damage
review: This is a wild game on the gamecube that I distinctly remember buying from Blockbuster for 2 pounds. It's basically just Mario Kart battle mode with the cel shading popularised by Wind Waker. It was wacky and fun, but back then I didn't really understand that there was such things as bad games. The market wasn't oversaturated with slop back then so I couldn't really recognise this game for what it is, a clone!
I mained a character called Dominique Trix.

games.name: Advance Wars: Black Hole Rising
review: Loved playing this as a child! I missed out on the first game but that's fine because this one is all you need. I loved the campaign although it was really hard, and then the custom map builder was awesome. I really sank many hours into this! I was an advance wars fan way before I was a fire emblem fan for sure. My favourite CO was Colin.

games.name: Advance Wars: Dual Strike
review: This was also a great game but I never owned it. I remember playing it multiplayer on the bus on school trips. It had some extra mechanics which I thought were great, but I never played the campaign.

games.name: Monsteca Corral
review: What a trip. This is a weird ass game that looks more like someone's first ever video game than anything else. The story is wild, you control these robots and are trying to help a giant flying worm to hatch, or something like that. It was very conceptual and maybe it could be enjoyable if you took mushrooms.

games.name: Yoshi's Story
review: One of my all time favourite games and possibly one of the very first games I played! I got this game for my 6th birthday and I was thrilled! I loved it. I spent so much time as a tiny child playing this and not understanding anything. As a result I have a bunch of core memories associated with it. The music especially really means a lot to me.

My favourite level was 'Torrential Maze' but I could so rarely play it because I didn't understand that I needed to collect the hearts to unlock the stage. Other highlights were the Tall Tower, the beehive jungle level, the terrifying piranha plant grove, wanting to get enough hearts on page 4 because I really wanted to avoid the underwater levels. The ghost bowser's castle was so hard!

Later in life I learned that there's more to the game than just vibing through the levels and I attempted to collect all the melons, but that shit is hard! There are so many melons hidden in bullshit places, impossible minigames, and you eat other fruit by accident so easily.

games.name: SUPERHOT
review: I tried it because the premise is cool. The premise is that time is stopped and only progresses as you move. So you have all the time in the world to consider how you're going to shoot these red guys. I'm not great at shooters and I found this game to be too stressful for me. I heard it's really wild in VR!

games.name: Hollow Knight
review: When I talk about vibes in video games, I'm talking about how close other video games achieve the status of ultimate vibe like Hollow Knight. This game is such a vibe it's insane. There are endless 'ambience and music from Hollow Knight for studying' compilations on youtube for a reason. The music is so sombre and peaceful and unlike anything else really. Then when the boss music hits, it's fucking great, it's dramatic but still fits the vibe of the gloomy caves. When I listen to tracks like 'Hornet battle' I enjoy how it sounds like baroque music.

Specifically I love the main Crossroads area, Greenpath and the City of Tears. The music is stunning, and also the game looks amazing. The artstyle is somewhere between creepy and cute and they nail it. I truly don't think another 2D platformer can look as good as this.

Gameplay-wise this game is also a 10. It's super open, meaning you can go anywhere really, and for a metroidvania you'd think that would be a problem but it straight up isn't. At some point you learn about the goal of the game and you have some directions on the map but all in all it's just about vibing through the various locations at your leisure and finding all this cool shit. At some point everything changes when you can double jump and you just want to go through the whole world again looking for secrets.

The combat is sooooo satisfying! You have loads of short, fast attacks, but the enemies have lots of health so you have to hit them many times. But if you get good at it, you can kill stuff quickly with a flurry of blows and it feels great. The bosses are not your standard hit-them-three-times affair, but rather require you to fit in as many of these tiny hits in as possible between attacks. When you get hit yourself you it feels BAD, like the whole screen goes black and it HURTS. Sound design really helps with that and no game nails sound design like this one.

There's also just tons of fun stuff to find and see. The game can keep going forever if you want. I personally was never able to defeat the Radiance and to this day I feel bad about it, but that hasn't stopped me from replaying this game 2 times and getting enjoyment out of it that way. Also did I mention that all the characters in this game are bugs? It's an insect game! And it has INSANE lore. Genuinely worth getting into those hour long deep dives into the lore because it is sooooo detailed.

games.name: NES Remix Pack
review: This is a game where you are given little challenges from Nintendo NES games, maybe remixed a little somehow. It's alright but this version on the Wii U was pretty bare bones. I think they perfected the formula in the Nintendo World Championships NES Edition.

games.name: Kid Icarus: Uprising
review: Sakurai's fun little romp between smash games, why not! I appreciate that he brought back a dead franchise to life! They made Pit look good and made a bunch of new characters and made a fun little on-rails shooter out of it! Also some adventure sections, but actually this game is just about the story. The whole time you're playing, Pit will be constantly yapping with other characters with some altogether goofy dialogue.
The story is very eye-rolly but it's fine! It's nice to understand where all the references from smash come from. I also enjoyed the false ending! Actually it's an alright little game.

games.name: Super Mario Galaxy 2
review: I never loved this game quite like the first one. I enjoyed it the first time, but at some point (shortly before Odyssey came out) I replayed it on the Wii and straight up didn't enjoy it. It's missing some magic. I don't like that the levels are so short.
I do love the world map music, Slimy Spring Galaxy and also Throwback Galaxy!

games.name: Mario Kart DS
review: Mario Kart DS is so specifically awesome. I love it and played it constantly. I remember being shit at it, doing the awesome mission mode, then getting kinda good at it, then playing a bunch online, then being exasperated at the people who were snaking, and then eventually becoming a snaker myself.

I love the vibes of the tracks, and especially the soundtrack. Just the main menu music is so good. Also Airship Fortress, Delfino Square, Waluigi Pinball, Rainbow Road - just so good. It was so tragic that with the local download play you were only allowed to play on 8 tracks, it meant doing those easy tracks over and over constantly with friends on the bus.

games.name: Kirby & The Amazing Mirror
review: They made a metroidvania with Kirby! It's so good! This might be favourite Kirby game. It's so fun to get to know the world and explore all the various areas. I love the new copy abilities, it's such a step up from Nightmare in Dreamland. I remember freaking out that you could fight Master Hand from smash, and when you inhale it, you get Kirby's moveset from Smash Melee. So good.
The music is great, especially from my favourite area 'Candy Constellation'. I love Candy Constellation that I painted a picture of it, currently in my house.

games.name: Diddy Kong Racing
review: Diddy Kong Racing is a very important game. I never owned Mario Kart 64 at this time, instead we were a DKR household. I played this game so much because it has an absolutely banger single player mode. You go around doing all these races, there's a great hub world to go around with lots of challenges, and the story is all about defeating the ugly-ass Wizpig by beating him in a race. Love it. That wizpig race was randomly so fucking hard. But if you beat it you unlocked the space levels!!! Nothing was more exciting for me than after years to finally see the lighthouse turn into a rocket.

I love and cherish all of the racetracks and know them all like the back of my hand. I know all the shortcuts. Dear reader, you cannot defeat me at this game because I am a pro. Later in life I even learned how to go fast by tapping the accelerator button, and beat all the staff ghosts. This might be the first game I got good at. And unlike Mario Kart, there are no bitch-ass blue shells to make you lose even if you're the better racer. This game isn't socialist.

But no, the reason this game is one of the greatest of all time is its soundtrack, made by Grant Kirkhope who did Banjo Kazooie and Donkey Kong 64. It's iconic. All the tracks are timeless. I named my youtube channel 'Darkmooncaverns19' after the space-themed level on the same name. I fucking love these in particular: Fossil Canyon, Hot Top Volcano, Walrus Cove, Whale Bay, Pirate Lagoon, Boulder Canyon, Greenwood Village, Haunted Woods, Spacedust Alley, Darkmoon Caverns, Spaceport Alpha. I realise that's almost all of them but YEAH I just love them all. Fuck it. The music is perfect. The LOBBY MUSIC alone might just be the best song in the whole game.

I remember my Dad losing his mind about this game because of the plane mechanics - it was the first actual good racing game where you could fly in a plane. Personally I loved the hovercraft the most though. Ugh I also loved the silver coin challenges. I always mained Tip-Tup he was my main man.

games.name: Terraria
review: I played this many years ago when it was first a thing. I got kinda into it to the point where I got the wings, but ultimately it's a more stressful, not as cool version of minecraft. When I tried to play on an online server with friends during the pandemic I wasn't into it at all.

games.name: Pokemon Shield
review: This game is so bullshit. I can't believe they done did dirty Pokemon like that. It looks like shit, doesn't perform well on the switch and is an all-round disappointment. This is where it really dawned on me how little GameFreak care about these games. I found it devastating that so many people bought this as well... it's all just very upsetting.

It has some things that I like - as usual Pokemon continues to come up with excellently ugly and hilarious Pokemon designs. Cramorant, Centiscorch, Sinistea, Falinks, Stonjourner, Eiscue, all great. Also I lowkey enjoy Barraskewda. And the dinosaurs are SO UGLY I love it. I also fucking loved the Gigantamax thing, like what were they thinking? Some of the designs are so funny. Very entertaining.

The soundtrack is miserable. They tried to go for something special with the music for the legendary pokemon but it sounds cheap and shit. There is one notable exception though: when you start a gym leader battle in the stadium. HOLY that's a great moment and the music goes hard. But then after a while there's this crowd singing along and it sounds like shit again. But for a minute or two, I was carried away by the excitement.

games.name: Pikmin 3
review: I fucking love Pikmin 3. I'm already a mega fan of the series, and to see it all in glorious HD is just amazing. I feel like they smashed it with this game in terms of vibes. The undergrowth looks so good, the water looks amazing, and the levels are large and fun and full of stuff. No caves but it doesn't need them!

This time there are three captains meaning there is plenty of opportunity for efficient work between them, which is great. I remember attempting something like an 8 day playthrough and got a 12 day in the end, which is pretty good.

I think this is the most accessible Pikmin game and I've made several friends play it. I can only recommend it to people interested in the series! Maybe it doesn't have the wild and raw vibes of the first two games but it has a bunch of quality of life changes that make it seem so much less bullshit. The vibes are different but there's still those creepy undertones, especially with that final boss. The music is stunning.

This game also features a hell of a lot of beautifully rendered HD fruit. It's so nice to admire all the fruit at the end of the day. No idea why they went for fruit but it's great. The running out of juice thing is a total joke though.

games.name: Hey! Pikmin
review: This game totally has its merits: another stunning soundtrack that fits the vibe perfectly being the main one. However it really misses out on a big opportunity: making the player strategise about which pikmin to use. The Pikmin are just available in each level for you to find and use, there's not making your own Pikmin. As a result, you always have the colour you need. Part of the magic of pikmin is selecting your squad and solving puzzles with that, but in this game you just go through the levels and follow the motions. There's not puzzle or strategy really. The minigame between levels is lame, but the bosses are kinda fun!

I would only recommend this to hardcore Pikmin fans. There's not much meat on the bone, and it could have been something so much better. Soundtrack is great though, and I made a mix of it in the music section so check that out.

games.name: Animal Crossing: Let's Go to the City
review: I loved this game! I loved the DS game and seeing it with nicer graphics was great. It had a bunch of new features like this weird city (with its beautiful music) and I loved it. I spent a lot of time making a beautiful town and loving it.

At the time I can't remember if I was disappointed about it being so similar to the DS game, but looking back I see that it is a bit of a disappointment in that sense, especially when it comes to the music. The same hourly music especially hits hard. This feels more like Wild World Deluxe than anything else. Whatever, I still had a great time with this game.

games.name: Super Princess Peach
review: This game was wild, they finally give Peach her moment and it's platformer where the main mechanic is her hysterical emotions. She's super angry, crying, or elated depending I guess on where she is in the menstrual cycle. OK that's not true but this game is giving misogyny. She deserves better.

games.name: Yu-Gi-Oh! Ultimate Masters: World Championship Tournament 2006
review: I got well into this back when I was Yugioh with my brother. It's genuinely a banger game, I loved fighting the CPUs over and over again with all my various decks. I learned about all the nonsense this game has to offer, tried out a bunch of different strategies and eventually got quite good at it. My favourite deck was an insect themed one! At some point I lost it but I don't want to restart this on an emulator because it takes so long to unlock all the cards.

games.name: Super Smash Bros.
review: The game that started it all. Nothing could describe my excitement for a party game that let you play as all these amazing nintendo characters. Everything about this game is classic - the single player mode, master hand, the sound effects, the music, literally all the stages. This was the very first platform fighter and it was INNOVATIVE! Nothing like it.

I now know that the meta of this game is totally dead because it's very unbalanced. Kirby and Pikachu are simply way too strong. As a child I played Kirby for the unstoppable fly up and down B strategy, and eventually graduated to a real character: Yoshi. Nowadays people still play this game at smash tournaments but only for combo contests! They are amazing.

games.name: Tilt Brush
review: I played this at a VR shop in like 2016. Didn't play much of the other games because I spent all of my allocated hour on this game. You can draw things in 3D! It was a lot of fun. I made a bush and a tree.

games.name: Mario Kart 8 Deluxe
review: This game is a heroic amount of Mario Kart goodness! They honestly perfected the Mario Kart formula with this one. No Mario Kart before this one feels as good as this. We had this for 10 years and in that time it carried me through so many party situations. It's just the ideal party game, what can I say. It's accessible for new players but also great if you're good at it.

The base game back on the Wii U was awesome back then. Back then, I was excited about the anti-gravity, which I now realise is a total gimmick. You don't even realise you're upside down most of the time! After many years, I did get bored of those same tracks though. I will also say that those first tracks weren't as great as later ones, but maybe that's because I've just played them to death.

Then, they released some awesome DLC with those banger F-Zero tracks, as well as Animal Crossing, which I love. It was like breathing new life into this old game. Then they went ahead and did it AGAIN, with an insane battle pass which included twice as many tracks. They brought back tons of old favourites, as bunch of surprisingly good city tracks from Mario Kart Tour, and some new ones. I loved it. I love that they went for that. Once again, new life was breathed into it and here we are on a new console 10 years later, still playing it.

The music is so good, I can't even describe. They got a jazz fusion band to make all the songs and they fucking nailed it! Mario Kart music is already great but they took it to the next level with this OST and I am obsessed. The remixes of old favourites in particular are amazing. In the 'misc' section of this website I actually ranked all of this games tracks, and there are a lot of them, so if you want more detailed thoughts, go check that out.

games.name: Fire Emblem Fates
review: OK I know this game has a bunch of problems but that didn't stop me from loving it with all my heart. Genuinely one of my favourite Fire Emblems! Let's start with the negatives and get them out of the way. The story is ass. All three versions of the game have anticlimactic endings, and do not even attempt to tie up loose ends. Lots of lost potential for an otherwise alright premise. Many of the characters are ridiculous, for example Camilla, who is a sexualised crazy lady who constantly flirts with you (her sibling!). She has this strap of some material that runs between her huge knockers which I can only imagine is super uncomfortable. And she has a hole in her armour to show of her thong. OK I'll shut up about her. Corrin, the main character is the most bland and boring character ever. So plain. FE protagonists tend to be like this but they are the worst by far.

Also what the fuck is going on with the having children in an alternate universe and having them join the team as adults? Who thought of that?? The children mechanic is shamelessly copied from Awakening and they didn't even bother trying to explain it. Whatever, if it means that the fans can flirt with their favourite characters (read: touch Camilla's boobs with the stylus), then it's worth it. This game really is a mess.

Anyway, I love it. The main reason is I think that this soundtrack is one of the best soundtracks ever. It is huge and expansive, and beautifully made. It's honestly gorgeous. The world is split into two, a more folky/celtic vibe in the west and a more oriental vibe in the east, and these two styles are well represented in the music. I love the compositions, especially with the choice of chord progressions. Some faves include Past Light, Dusk Falls, Dark Wastes, Alight, Land Below, Road Token, Glory/Ruin. They are just so good. I made a really good mix of this music, available for download on the music page, which I listen to a lot to this day. It's great for long walks in nature.

I did play all three versions through to the end, which all things considered really is saying something. I really enjoyed the game in terms of its mechanics and strategy. I of course had my favourite characters (Oboro) and my OP characters (Velouria) and it's a delight to pick and choose your main peeps for the team. Ugh what can I say I just really love this game.

games.name: Okami
review: Absolutely wild that a game as stunning as this game out as early as 2006! Talk about being carried by an artstyle. This japanese-style cel-shaded goodness still looks perfect today, and that's because this game is timeless. It's epic and it's a classic! In the story you play as the sun god Amaterasu who is reincarnated as an awesome magical wolf, which on its own is sick (twilight princess eat your heart out this came out first!), but then you're taken down this wild rabbit hole of a story based on Japanese folklore.

There are so many points in the game that I love. When you dramatically run with Kimiko's body to the shrine, when you beat Orochi and realise this game is far from over, those awesome Owl bosses, the snow area in general, shrinking down inside the city, the jiggly boob lady who turns out to not be who you think she is, the gender ambiguous villain character, the final boss. so much to enjoy.
The music is amazing, it's full on traditional Japanese music and it's sooooo beautiful. Shinshu field alone should be enough to convince you to play this classic game.

games.name: Sonic Rush
review: This game has a unique vibe. The music sounds like Fatboy Slim! It's rock-y, punk-y and sounds great on the shitty DS speakers. Then it's just a normal 2D sonic, maybe not as fun as the originals, but still pretty good. They remix the levels for the Blaze levels which I really liked. Great game.

games.name: Turbo Turtle Adventure
review: I remember being so excited about being able to download games using an emulator when I was younger, and one of the first games I got into by doing this was this little game. It's a puzzle game where you roll around as a turtle collecting keys and going to the goal. It's actually great and I completed it! It's also hard as balls but luckily I'm a pro gamer.

games.name: 1080° Snowboarding
review: The main thing that separates this game from other snowboarding games is its Jungle soundtrack. It's got these sick breakbeats and is all-round vibe. Playing the game is really hard though. We played it a lot as kids but I don't think I was ever able to complete it. SSX 3 some years later was much more my jam.

games.name: Undertale
review: This game really has evolved into a juggernaut culture-wise. The image of Sans has somehow permeated into the mainframe. But back then, it wasn't everywhere! I played this while it was still very young and was completely unaware of the secrets it was hiding.
If you don't know this game and you're interested in playing, please stop reading and go do that! It's best to go in blind, because there is a lot of fun things which get revealed.

The best thing about it is the music, of course. It's heavily inspired by the Mother series (love) and has a huge range. I love Another Medium, the normal enemy battle theme, and Falling Down. And the characters are just delightful.

I played through the normal route, then the pacifist route, and loved them both. The Flowey reveal at the end of the normal route is fucking insane. I didn't have the heart to do the genocide run, but wow, what a thing that genocide run is. You have to go through and defeat all monsters, and there are a lot of them! It becomes tedious and the music slows down. The characters start treating you with hatred and you kill them all one by one. It's designed to be boring and difficult, really testing you if this is really what you want to do. It makes it more and more uncomfortable as you go, and the only real reason to continue is to see all the content in the game, even if that means commiting genocide. Then if you survive the upsetting marathon, you finally face Sans who says some iconic lines and still loses, it's very impactful.
This game is a total all-time classic.

games.name: The Legend of Zelda: Link's Awakening
review: I have so much love for this game. I died when it was announced. A HD remake of this game was something I wanted my whole life. I remember fantasising about it when the Wii was out. Imagine this game on the Wii all in beautiful 3D!! And now here we are.

This game is super faithful and totally manages to capture a lot of the moody kooky vibe. The remade soundtrack is perfect, and they ironed out all of the nonsense from the original and gave it tons of Quality of Life improvements. As a game it might be jarring for new players because after all it's a gameboy game, but it still remains one of my favourites if not my favourite Zelda game ever.

games.name: Super Smash Bros. for 3DS
review: I was so excited about this game! The year and a half slow stream of info and hype leading up to its release was like edging. Then it finally came and I obsessively played it and loved every minute. I remember going to the computer games club and challenging people there to games on the demo.

I eventually stopped playing it and moved to the Wii U version but I loved all the new stages and music for those stages, like Magicant and Gerudo Valley. Smash Run was great and a glimpse into another world were smash characters are platforming together. It was giving subspace emissary vibes which we love of course.

games.name: Fire Emblem: Radiant Dawn
review: This was my first fire emblem game! I bought it for 15 pounds at blockbuster and loved it. It's a slow burner, and sometimes you would restart long chapters just to save a dying character. The colours are also very grab and the graphics aren't great. But it doesn't matter because the story is banging and the characters are iconic. I love Nephenee with all my heart and also Ilyana. This is also where we see Buff Ike and his twink boyfriend Soren vibe the hardest. The gay content is right there you just have to look at the screen.
The music is very orchestral and dramatic but I really like it. I love the part in the story when everyone turns to stone and there's a sudden shift in tone.

games.name: Pokemon Mystery Dungeon: Explorers of Sky
review: I played this once through when I borrowed it from Oscar at a young age and I remember thinking it's super good, equally as good if not better than Red Rescue Team. I don't remember too much of it story-wise, but MUSIC-wise this game is peak. I will never forget the Temporal Tower music. Potentially an all-time favourite Nintendo song right there.

games.name: Pokemon Snap
review: Oh hell yes, this game was a total trip. Loved it. As kids we played this all the time, screaming at Professor Oak to rate our photos higher. Loving finding all the secrets over the years, falling in love with some of my favourite pokemon even more. My favourite stage was the River, but my favourite music is from the Cave.

games.name: Deltarune: Chapter 1
review: A surprise Undertale sequel! This was released as a survey about Undertale and I clicked it and then this game started! Then I played this free game for 3 hours and then beat it thinking wow, I just experienced something so great. Super cool.

It's got great music, a great little story, love the character of Susy and all the supporting cast. Love the environments and theming. I love Rouxls Kaard. It's still got that creepy vibe and I just wholeheartedly recommend it.

games.name: Cadence of Hyrule: Crypt of the NecroDancer featuring The Legend of Zelda
review: I will never forget seeing the trailer for this game for the first time. Absolutely iconic Zelda reveal. And for the music they picked Tal Tal Heights?? They have such taste. Ugh, I loved it.

And then the game came out and it was just as good as it looked! I love this wild promise of rhythm adventure game, and really enjoy these high intensity games. the music is sooooo good. I made a mix of it that you can download in the music section of this website!

games.name: Yoshi's New Island
review: This game is honestly super disappointing. It has a new look which is alright, but a lot of the magic is missing. There's also way less stuff. Like in DS you could play as 5 different babies, but here it's just Baby Mario. And there's so little variety in terms of gameplay and vibes. It's only new mechanic is having big eggs. And then there's this really annoying reveal for the final world where yoshi's island is just a planet. It's just not how I had it in my mind. The music is also disappointing. It has a beautiful title theme but then all the rest is just slight variations of that theme and not in a particularly nice way.

games.name: De Blob
review: I actually really enjoyed this game. Like sure it's 'bad' but I had so much fun playing it. It was so satisfying to just go around and colour stuff in. I love the music, especially of the opening area.

games.name: Mario Party DS
review: This is the only Mario Party that I ever owned and I actually played a bunch. This is gonna sound a bit sad though, I never played this with anyone else, just with the CPUs. I just really enjoyed the fun gameplay and beating the single player mode with all the characters. I don't think the music was good or anything so looking back I'm really struggling to think what kept me drawn to this game.

games.name: Mario Party Superstars
review: I mean I don't love Mario Party but I did say yes to a few round with keen beans who do love it. It's alright.

games.name: Mario Party Jamboree
review: With the release of this new game I have been playing more Mario Party. The RNG in the game is just too much, but this time you can play as Goomba, who is precious.

games.name: Snowboard Kids
review: This game was soooo fun! It's like a mixture of Mario Kart and SSX and I loved it. I don't think we ever owned it as kids but definitely played it with friends a bunch. It's got this wild mechanic where when you get to the bottom of the mountain you have to queue for the skilift to come and take you back to the top.

games.name: Worms 2
review: Absolutely iconic game that I played a whole bunch during secondary school. Most distinctly I remember doing so on a laptop in Sixth Form. Specifically I remember having a worm on my team called 'Mrs No-Nonsense' and everyone used to gang up on first straight away!! That is straight up misogyny that is. This also had a great little 1-player mode which was genuinely super hard. Also this is my favourite Worms game because this is where it's really important to be able to shoot a bazooka good.

games.name: Baba is You
review: This game is actually genius. No other game has made me feel like its creator was a total genius, and also ever made me feel like a genius myself when I complete a puzzle. This is definitely one of the all-time greats of block puzzle games.

Tragically I never beat it because it's so fucking difficult, and now I haven't played the game for a while, I can't just get back into it, because you really need to train up your lateral thinking brain in order to get these wild solutions. It's thinking outside of the box on steroids. I reeeeeally recommend it!

games.name: Star Fox 64 3D
review: A genuinely good remake of a great game! Worth your time if you are a 3DS owner.

games.name: WarioWare: Smooth Moves
review: This game is genuinely hilarious. The tai-chi introductions to new baton forms? Hilarious. The battle mode where your miis fly the sky as angels, Perfect. That Balloon Fight remix? Genuinely good. And it has an all-time best final boss ever. Highly recommended.

games.name: Advance Wars: Days of Ruin
review: A gritty remake of Advance Wars, this was quite a departure from the series. I still enjoyed it! It had a very serious story which I actually really enjoyed, it had this cool disease where flowers grow all over you. There's one really tough mission near the end and I suffered, but I did beat this game in the end.

games.name: Iggy's Reckin' Balls
review: I have strong childhood memories of this. Thinking about it this was such a fever dream. Wild that they made a racing game like this.

games.name: Command & Conquer: Red Alert
review: I played this a bunch with my brothers. Don't think I got very far in the campaign because I'm child but I enjoyed the multiplayer. I also enjoyed this one female agent called Tanya that you can deploy, and whenever you deploy her she just says in a really snarky voice :'Tanya!'

games.name: Super Mario Maker 2
review: This game is equally as good as the first one! Apart from the new 3D World vibes, there's nothing too new here. It's still a great game! I made some levels if anyone wants to come over and play them.

games.name: Pilotwings Resort
review: Borrowed this from Oscar on the 3DS and really enjoyed it! It's got some great music, that classic Mii + Wuhu Island vibe. A lot to enjoy, although I didn't play much into the game, I have to admit.

games.name: Pikmin 2
review: I love Pikmin 2 so much. This game really embodies the wacky and creepy Pikmin vibe, possibly the most out of all of them. In this game you collect treasure of real brands and items like Duracell batteries, which is awesome. It's like, are we on Earth? Nah can't be because there are weird monsters here. But I love it, and all the stuff with Louie towards the end, super cool. Love the montage of him on his own on the planet.

This game added in purple and white pikmin which are iconic. It also added caves which added a lot of fun gameplay to the game, but it just doesn't make sense that time stops down there. It's also kinda weird to be able to reset to the beginning of the floor all the time. It's like a completely different game to the time management stuff going on outside.
I love the vibes of the different areas, especially the forboding Wistful Wilds. And I love the Piklopedia with that music!
Maybe this is my favourite Pikmin game, I'm not sure. Highly recommend.

games.name: Yoshi's Island DS
review: I love Yoshi's Island DS! Everyone says the original is better and maybe they're right but I played the shit out of this! With all the different babies it's totally innovative and different. I also enjoy the music, although it is all variations of the same music. Speaking of music, the title theme is so beautiful. You need to listen to a minute of ocean sounds but then it comes in. Stunning. I loved this game, and completing it is just as hard as the original.

games.name: RollerCoaster Tycoon
review: Lovingly dubbed 'Roundabouts' by my dad, I loved RollerCoaster Tycoon and would play it all the time after school. You could make your own theme parks and it was so good! The system was super flexible and making rollercoasters was so fun. I loved the little scenarios and all the music you could play. I played this game to death!

games.name: Crypt of the NecroDancer
review: Absolutely wild premise - a combination of a dungeon crawler roguelike and a rhythm game. It fucking works and with a soundtrack like that? I'm sold. This game is so addictive and has so much shit in it, I ended up playing for ages!

games.name: Wii Fit
review: My mum bought me this! Did she think I was fat or something?? We used this Balance Board thing and were like wow, this is a thing. I barely played it but there was one really fun minigame with the board that I forgot the name of.

Later in life I have developed a new appreciation for this game, not for its fitness gameplay, but for its incredible vibe. No game resonates with Wii-era Nintendo frutiger aero as much as this. I went on to main Wii Fit Trainer in smash purely based off of the vibes.

games.name: Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney
review: This game is so good! Huge vibes are unexpected from a game about law and order, but it is so cute and funny. I love the judge, I love how extra everyone is. Why are Mia's tits that huge. Highly recommend this!

games.name: The Sims
review: This game is iconic for a reason: it's hilarious. These characters are so dumb and funny that the game just constantly remains entertaining. I have a lot of memories associated with this as a child. Training a lady up to level 10 cooking and the first meal she cooks she burns the house down. Letting the sims drown in the pool, showdowns with the robber, training up to be an Astronaut and then just sleeping in one day and getting fucking fired.

I also really enjoyed the house-building and selecting the furniture, which is funny because I don't like doing those things in real life. Character create of course, hilarious. Then they pee on the floor, great. I also really enjoyed the expansion packs I had a holidays one which was great. And I looooove the shopping music

games.name: The Sims 3
review: I played this for a bit at some point, but it's ugly in a really bad way! I didn't truly get into it like the original, although it does have a lot of potential for hilarity. I downloaded a mod to make sexy buff guys which is just typical gay nonsense really, incredible that I lied to myself so much about that back then.

games.name: Shovel Knight: Treasure Trove
review: I think of indie games as either before shovel knight or after shovel knight, because shovel knight was so high quality that it fucking revolutionised the platforming genre. From that point on, it was all about quality of life and making the user feel good. Shovel Knight was the first 'clean' indie game. It felt so good to play and was really well designed.

I like the world and the other knights. I especially liked the other campaigns with reaper knight and king knight, they were fabulous. This even comes with its own little platform fighter which is a lot of fun. The music from Jake Kaufman is top class. Some real chiptune magic.

games.name: Donkey Kong: Barrel Blast
review: The attempt at Donkey Kong Kart. It's really weird and not really worth your time or money. Some good music.

games.name: Custom Robo Arena
review: This game was wild. Genuinely a lot of fun to play the battles, but then there was this totally baffling story where you start each day with the same dialogue with your family over and over again. At points this game feels like a fever dream.

games.name: Runescape
review: Runescape was the real deal, man. My first ever MMO and I fucking loved it. Seeing all those people online for the first time like that was amazing. I learned that people are weird. I also made friends on here! I would message random players about this and that. Once I cried because mum told me I had to stop playing right when I was having a conversation with a new friend. After a few years I even got the membership for a year or so. I loved exploring the whole game, it was amazing. There was so much stuff!

A lot of the music is firmly ingrained in my brain. It was classic. I loved the 'newbie island' music. I remember getting really good at woodcutting, which is without doubt the lamest skill to grind. Alas, I was a child.

games.name: Bit.Trip Runner
review: This is a fun auto-runner where you play as a rainbow man. It was alright but didn't do too much for me.

games.name: Professor Layton and Pandora's Box
review: Another banger Professor Layton, loved it. Story was a bit more intense than Curious Village, but I would still recommend Curious Village over this to newcomers.

games.name: Minecraft
review: Minecraft is a top 10 game of all time for sure. It has become a cultural staple for a reason. It's like lego! Building endlessly to your heart's content. The simplicity of the blocks is super easy to understand so everyone can get involved. You can build whatever you want, it's like expressing yourself artistically in 3D. I've built so much cool shit. There's also adventuring and killing monsters and stuff and that stuff is alright, although I'm more of a builder than a fighter. More of a lover.

When this first came out, I played it a bunch and loved it, but only ever single player. Then during the pandemic I played it online with friends for the first time and it changed everything. I was able to log in at anytime, build stuff and my mates would see it when they log in later. It was so good. I made the mode amazing pixel art and was so proud. As I write this I'm currently involved in a new server with my friend Anni and it's so fun at the start when everyone has all this motivation.

games.name: Overcooked
review: Genuine banger party game! I played this through with my friend Alex and as a duo it was just perfect I think. We super harmonised and managed to beat the game. When you play this with more players than that, chaos ensues. It makes for a great party game, but for me the true fun is getting those 3 star ratings with ruthless efficiency. I main the chef in the wheelchair.

games.name: Overcooked 2
review: Can't say why but this game bugs me. I feel like it's worse than the first one, like everything is a downgrade. I always play the first one even though I have this one on my switch.

games.name: 42 All-Time Classics
review: We played this a whole bunch as kids! Some of the games are quite good and I kinda enjoyed play it, even single player. Some of the music is great, especially the Chess/Backgammon theme.

games.name: AM2R: Another Metroid 2 Remake
review: So sad that was released after 10 years development by one guy so shortly before Nintendo do their own remake! But that doesn't mean this game isn't fantastic in its own right. It's as good as a real game and way better than the original Metroid 2. Kudos to the developer I loved playing this.

games.name: Golf Story
review: This game really does have heart and soul. It's got a funny vaguely golf-themed story, nonsense dialogue, and some genuinely great core golf gameplay. Me and my mates did play some multiplayer of this in the early days. It's pretty janky, feels held together with glue.

games.name: Diddy Kong Racing DS
review: Devastating that this remake does not even closely live up to the original. How could they take something so perfect and make it worse. The soundtrack has been remade and it just sounds like shit. The soundfont sounds bad. There are new music tracks for some of the levels, because the original used the same music for multiple levels, but it just doesn't feel right to make those replacements. They got rid of Pirate Lagoon entirely what the fuck.

This game is straight up missing Conker and Banjo and it just doesn't feel right without them. Then we got this design of Tiny Kong that looks nothing like the beloved Tiny from DK64, and a bunch of other characters I don't like. They also changed the mechanics, especially of the hovercraft, and it's just worse. I also don't like the new silver coin challenge with the touchscreen, I preferred the old one. They did add four new tracks but they are lifeless.
This game is just disappointing. Although I will say one thing, the making your own track thing was great.

games.name: Chasm
review: This was a super cute point and click adventure that I found on Miniclip.com when I was a child. It's not easy but I beat it!

games.name: The Messenger
review: A fantastic indie game based on Ninja Gaiden. A lot of fun to play, great music, and I especially love the switch between 8-Bit and 16-Bit, and when it turns into a metroidvania. Highly recommend.

games.name: Worms: Open Warfare
review: I played this on my PC at some point when I was missing Worms 2. It's alright I guess.

games.name: Zoombinis
review: Strong core memories of this game being on the primary school computers! We used it as an educational tool. I remember making the pizzas with fondness.

games.name: Yooka-Laylee and the Impossible Lair
review: I like the idea of starting off with one impossible level and as you progress through the game, you get better at it and at some point eventually you can challenge the final impossible level and actually beat it. Except I hate to complain but the impossible level in this game is IMPOSSIBLE! The difficulty spike between it and everything before it is huge. I beat it in the end after many tries, but only out of spite!

I also don't enjoy the vibe of the game. I get that it's meant to look good with the fancy lighting and colours and it kinda does, but all the levels have this lighting and look the same. I did like how some levels had variations depending on stuff that happened in the overworld, that was super cool.

Yooka and Laylee don't speak to me as characters. They feel like copies of Banjo and Kazooie. Also this game is a total rip-off of Donkey Kong Country Tropical Freeze. Dear reader, go play Donkey Kong instead.

games.name: Zool 2
review: Strong memories of having the disc of this game and jumping around in this colourful game. Don't remember much else.

games.name: Prison Architect
review: I thought this would be a hard-hitting management game which makes you make difficult decisions and consider the obsurdity of the prison system. But it was a very shallow and boring game that I regret buying. I regret buying on switch especially as it's actually a mouse game.

games.name: World of Warcraft
review: I lost a year of my life to this game, when I was 16 or so. I played on my brother's account and loved it, although I didn't play this MMO in the same way as most. I got to level 80, and then just focused on seeing every single region in the world and getting the tabard for that. I just loved exploring in the game, the world was so huge and populated with players just hanging out! I especially loved it when I built my helicopter and just flew around the place. I was so proud of my helicopter.
My username was 'subtleperson' because I was playing as a rogue. I never played PvP because fuck that shit.

games.name: Return of the Obra Dinn
review: This game actually looks like this screenshot, that's the artstyle! Never had anything like it. It's wild! You have a magical item that lets you look at dead bodies and witness the seconds before their death. By looking at these scenes, you have to use detective powers to figure out who was on this boat and what happened to them.
It's so cool! There are a bunch of awesome twists. I really recommend playing this with your partner together.

games.name: Lemmings
review: We played this on DOS as kids because this is the only video game that dad has ever loved. It's great.

games.name: Mega Man 2
review: For my education I played some NES Mega Man games and they are tough and brutal, but I see why they are popular. This is the one with the iconic music and I enjoyed that. I even beat the game thanks to save states!

games.name: Mega Man 3
review: This is just the same as Mega Man 2.

games.name: Mega Man 4
review: This is just the same as Mega Man 2 and 3 except I didn't quite have the strength to finish it. And so ended my journey into the world of Mega Man.

games.name: Frogger
review: A very old game on my dad's DOS computer that we played when we were infants I guess. It was really hard!

games.name: Neopets
review: Ah hell yes I loved Neopets! If you know you know!! It's this awesome website where you can have Neopets like pokemon and raise them and feed them and stuff. You could play games to early coins and buy and sell stuff. I loved all the games and loved my little Chia called Frozenbluixi. My favourite game was Ice Cream Factory. The website had a bunch of cool stuff with other players, like a whole economy and stuff, but I didn't really engage with that. Neopets is where I had my first personal website though! They had a little HTML tutorial for the profile page and I learned some important life skills. Shoutouts to Neopets man, and to my dying, still alive Neopets. I'm sorry I can't feed you, but I can't find my password.

games.name: Lemmings 3D
review: The concept seemed so cool but it was fiddly and not very fun in the end.

games.name: VA-11 HALL-A
review: This game is such a vibe! The soundtrack is so good that I even have a CD of it! It's the ultimate vaporwave/japanese-inspired synthwave album. Throughout the game you barkeep at a rundown bar in cyberpunk future, and have a bunch of interesting conversations with the patrons who come in. You also make them drinks but that's just something to keep you occupied.
A little story unfolds but it's mainly something like a slice of life situation, a little peek into this world for a bit. It's awesome. Totally cozy.

games.name: Worms 3D
review: Played this at a friend's place and thought it was shit. Stick to Worms 2.

games.name: Yooka Laylee
review: I backed this game on Kickstarter! So I got bombarded with emails about it for like two years, and I was bored of it before I even played it! Something about doing this Kickstarter really takes the magic away. I saw every step of the development process and it totally ruined it. Also I don't think the game is that good. The worlds are way too huge and empty. I don't think I completed it in the end. I don't really like the main characters Yooka and Laylee.

games.name: Snake Pass
review: Shoutouts to Snake Pass for doing something entirely new! A game where you control a snake. It works! It's a fun little puzzle platformer and I really enjoyed my time with it. This came out at that time when the Switch just came out and I wanted to play anything and everything on it.

games.name: Shantae: Half-Genie Hero
review: I love Shantae!! And this game has the best soundtrack out of all of them. Jake Kaufman goes ham on this one, so many instant classics for me. I made a mix of its music available for download in the music section of this website, I just love it that much.
Gameplay wise it bothered me that it's just about backtracking with new abilities all the time. You go back to the first area all the time, but never to the later areas much.

games.name: Dandara
review: A great little platformer where you jump from wall to wall. It's got a nice vibey story where you fight abstract concepts more than actual things. What makes this game special is the absolutely fabulous soundtrack! I made a mix of it because it's that good (you can download it on this website). The boss music goes CRAZY!

games.name: Hyper Light Drifter
review: A beautiful pixel art 2D Zelda-like game. Really well done with a fantastic vibe. The colours and the mood are super unique. It's kinda gory and brutal too. I really liked the aesthetic and ended up getting a huge poster of this game for my hallway.

games.name: Owlboy
review: Stunning pixel art in this lovely indie game! It's different to usual platformers because you can just fly. There's lots of different sections but I guess it's kinda linear. It has a nice story and I really enjoyed it. It was made by one person over 10 years! Nuts how people devote their lives to these things.

games.name: Just Shapes and Beats
review: A super cool bullet hell game where the shit comes flying at you in time to the music. You can play with friends and it's really great! The music is pretty good too. I feel like the colours are a bit too much.

games.name: Guacamelee!
review: In this game you play as a luchador in a Mexican style, day-of-the-dead situation, and it really nails that vibe in a nice, humerous way. It is, however, just another metroidvania, and doesn't bring too much new stuff to the table.

games.name: Enter the Gungeon
review: It's a roguelike bullet hell game where everything is themed after guns and bullets. It's not a theme I really like if I'm honest. I played it at the start of my roguelike journey and although I did get kinda into it, this thing happened which happens with a lot of roguelikes. After several failed attempts, I got one incredible wonder run where I almost got to the end (having previously beaten the first boss like twice only). I played this one run for ages and everything was hanging on it, and then I lost. I tried to play another one but I could never reach those heights again. I blew it! Then I lost interest in playing it further. This happens with lots of games though, not just this.

games.name: Katana Zero
review: This game has a really cool concept in the story where if you take this drug you can have these time-rewind powers, but then you get addicted and if you stop taking the drug, time slows down for you and you eventually get stuck into eternity. Or something like that I can't remember
It's also good a really nice soundtrack and a satisfying gameplay loop. The ending is totally unsatisfying though.

games.name: Mega Man 11
review: Thinking that with a lick of paint, I might actually start to enjoy Mega Man I got this game. However I found myself frustrated at the formula with the robot masters, and some of the bullshit in the game, like the insta-kill fire in the fire stage. Didn't make it very far.

games.name: Rivals of Aether
review: The original Rivals is super cool! I downloaded it and really enjoyed playing it. However, the online on Switch is really bad and I don't have time for other fighting games, so I inevitably stopped. But it's a banger for sure.

games.name: Untitled Goose Game
review: Huge game! This is what video games are all about. Maybe you never fantasised about being a goose annoying people and causing trouble, but for a low price you can live out that fantasy and it's great. So simple and so funny. A delightful game that is really great for non-gamers.

games.name: Kirby Star Allies
review: This game is so fucking easy there's almost no point. It is polished and looks good, but it's definitely missing something. That being said, it has a fantastic and very expansive soundtrack. You can also play as almost any kirby character you like which is fun. I just wish it was more challenging!

games.name: Snipperclips
review: Switch launch title which I enjoyed playing with my friend Stefan. It was a lot of fun! Especially when playing with the new console with the joycons. The little characters were cute and fun with their facial expressions and the puzzles were fun too. I came back to play it years later but it didn't hit the same.

games.name: SteamWorld Dig 2
review: I was interested in this because I enjoyed the first one, it has a good vibe and people said it was good. With the exception of a scary section in the middle, this game didn't bring much to the table.

games.name: SteamWorld Dig
review: This is a fun little gameplay loop which doesn't overstay its welcome. Maybe not worth playing these days anymore but I remember enjoying it.

games.name: Dragon Quest XI S: Echoes of an Elusive Age
review: Everyone said this game would be so good, but it's just not. It's so plain! It's so vanilla! I'm not against having generic orchestral music like this but there are like 10 music tracks in the game, so you're constantly hearing the same song over and over. It's actually unforgivable considering how long the game is.

I played the demo and found myself enjoying it despite all that, because there was an interesting story twist. But then I bought the whole game and only made it about another 5 hours in before getting exhausted. I had no desire to connect with the mechanics. Even meeting the queer character wasn't enough to keep me on board. It features a small child girl who is actually very old and I just don't like that trope. Also the hero is very ugly.

I really want to complete this game for my project to beat every game that all the smash characters are from, but this game is just too lame and together with Roy's game might be the reason I don't complete the challenge.

games.name: Dragon Quest IX: Sentinels of the Starry Sky
review: I borrowed this from my mate Oscar back in the day and I got really into it! You could make your own character and name your teammates after your friends and that was just great. I got really into this but I have to say that I didn't beat the final boss because I didn't have it in me to grind levels. This was the real classic JRPG experience in that regard.

games.name: Cuphead
review: I mean vibes are through the roof with this game. No game has gone for the old mickey mouse cartoon look and this game nails it! The music is also fantastic. I highly recommend it for that alone!

You have to know though that this is an intense boss rush game and it's hard as nails. It's more like a bullet hell game than a run n gun! I played about half of it but eventually got exhausted. But big respect to Cuphead, it's great.

games.name: Worms W.M.D
review: It's a worms game available on switch. In theory it's good but I dunno it's missing the X factor. I would rather play Worms 2

games.name: Oxenfree
review: I fucking hated this game. It's just super American with a bunch of Americans being annoying. For visual novels, after playing this I decided to not play if it's about Americans because they annoy me too much. The supernatural stuff was just random and without any interesting premise. Ugh I just think it's lame. I completed it for some reason.

games.name: Firewatch
review: This may be in effect a visual novel about Americans, meaning I'm not interested, but it's actually alright. It has a nice loneliness vibe, and some really nice dialog with the woman in the walky-talky. There's a really lovely intimate moment there as well which I was quite touched by.
I like the lighting and tension in the forest as the threat of fire increases. Although one thing bothered me: the complete lack of wildlife. It was just a dead area with trees and no animals!

games.name: Valkyria Chronicles 4
review: I heard this is super good but I found it to be pretty boring. I don't like the characters and the story seemed pretty boring, but I admit I didn't make it far into the game. It has an attractive artstyle but it wasn't enough to keep me interested.

games.name: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Shredder's Revenge
review: As a lover of Streets of Rage I decided to give this a try and actually thinking about it I quite liked it! But I didn't love it. Not like Streets of Rage. Hmm, maybe I should play this again.

games.name: Minit
review: This is a super good little short game that I totally recommend! You play a 2D zelda-like game but every minute you just die, and you have to restart. So you have to beat the game in one minute! But each time you explore a new spot and learn a little bit more about the area. It's super smart and there's loads of cool stuff to discover. I liked the music and the ending!

games.name: Fortnite
review: I played this for the culture. It was free on switch so I played a few rounds but honestly I hated it. I'm not interested in micro-transactions or games that have them. I'm terrible at shooters

games.name: Bioshock
review: The cool thing about Bioshock is that it takes place in a destroyed underwater world. But I didn't enjoy the shooting gameplay, it's just not my thing. I wanted to get into because people say great things about it but it's not for me.

games.name: Nickelodeon All Star Brawl
review: I fucking bought this game full price! What a mistake. I did it because we wanted to do a side event at a smash tournament and everyone was excited about it. But it turned out to be a dud! It was glitchy and shit in the end. I enjoyed playing as Sandy. It's a shame because there were so many cool characters.

games.name: Don't Starve
review: I gave it a try but I found it to be stressful and too gloomy for me

games.name: Rayman Legends
review: People say this is good but I hated it. I thought it was heartless and boring to play. The music tracks were nothing special.

games.name: Crash Bandicoot N-Sane Trilogy
review: For some reason I didn't get into it. I remember enjoying it as a kid and sure this remaster looks great. But. Didn't get into it for some reason.

games.name: Bastion
review: I enjoyed Hades so decided to try another game from the studio, but I didn't like it at all. So much talking and the gameplay was really boring.

games.name: Desert Child
review: This is a vibes game, where you just enjoy the vibes of a cyberpunk hip-hop future situation. The trailer looks awesome. But then I bought it and booted it up and realised there is little to no gameplay. It's a damp squib. No reason to boot it up again

games.name: Heave Ho
review: This is a fun co-op puzzle game! I recommend playing it with gamers because the controls are quite difficult.

games.name: Superliminal
review: This is a game like portal where you go around solving puzzles using physics. You pick up items and place them down again, except they scale in a weird way. You can make items big or small and solve puzzles that way. It's meant to be a mind-bending game and it kinda is, but I got frustrated with it.

games.name: Scott Pilgrim vs The World: The Game
review: As a Streets of Rage fan I decided to pick up this classic beat-em-up but was instantly disappointed. Very boring to play and the soundtrack simply isn't good enough to keep me interested.

games.name: Marvel's Spider-Man
review: I get it that it feels nice to websling around town but actually it's dumb that you can't crash into buildings. No skill is requires to swing around. I just played the opening section for science but decided this isn't the game for me.

games.name: EyeToy: Play
review: This was a wild thing that was popular for a while, you could buy this webcam that plugged into the PS2, and then you would appear in the game! At the time, this was insane technology. You could use your image in the game to fight monsters and play minigames, and I loved it! I don't think I played it all that much but have fond memories of it for sure.

games.name: AirBlade
review: I randomly remembered this old Tony Hawk's rip off that I played at some point when I was younger. I was so impressed that you could skateboard with a hoverboard! I thought it was a revolutionary idea. Looking back, it's literally just a normal skateboarding game.

games.name: Desktop Destroyer
review: I saw an image of the hammer from this game and I was launched back into the past, kinda like when you smell something from your childhood and you have this moment where you are suddenly transported back. I used to love destroying my desktop with termites, flamethrowers and chainsaws and was endlessly entertained by it. It's a real blast from the past.
